031606792X|2.0|I would have liked it so much better if it wasn't a Twilight book. If it was a standalone book, not associated with the characters Steph created in the first 3.    SPOILERS!!!  +  +  +  +  +    I know change is inevitable, but COME ON. To me, Bella is barely recognizable. My stomach churns every time she says, \\"my daughter\\", \\"my baby\\", etc. Ugh. I mean, I want a happy ending for my favorite couple as much as anyone else, but this is ridiculous, nauseating, and I feel like it cheapens everything she built up in the first three. I mean, she took the time to detail exactly what Bella had to give up in order to be with Edward, and Bella came to terms with it. Now all of a sudden she doesn't have to sacrifice a damn thing. She had Edward, Charlie, Jacob, her baby, and now she's a strong and beautiful vampire.    I felt that Edward and Bella were written extremely out of character. The only parts I felt were actually in character were the scene where they sleep together for the first time after her change, and the very end where she allows him to read her mind. And, to some extent, the wedding.    I couldn't figure out what the deal was with Rosalie. First she was all crazy psycho baby stealer, then as soon as Bella became immortal it was like she said, \\"Oh, nevermind.\\"    I was extremely disappointed with the end, concerning the Volturi. I was expecting a battle of epic proportions and then Bella went all \\"Bubble shield: ON!\\" and again, it was like they decided, \\"Ok, nevermind. No battle today.\\"     I definitely felt like she tried to fit too much going on into one book. Part of what I loved about the first three is that they were simple, focusing on Edward and Bella's relationship. Trying to cram a wedding, a honeymoon, a pregnancy, her change, and a battle royale at the end made the whole thing too contrived.    That being said, there were some things I enjoyed. As much as I hated Jacob imprinting on Nessie, I was so glad it allowed him to be a part of Bella's life without destroying him. And I enjoyed the camaraderie that emerged between Jacob and the vampires because of it.    The chapters between Bella's change and when she is reunited with Nessie are, IMO the best of the book. As someone said earlier, THAT'S the BD I wanted.    Surprisingly, I didn't hate the bond that came about between Bella and Nessie (I know I just said it made me nauseous, but hear me out). The thing that really bothers me is that this does not feel like \\"my\\" Bella, for lack of a better term. The Bella we began with, that fell in love with Edward, etc. I know that characters are supposed to evolve, but this is not the direction I wanted her to go in. I can't picture \\"my\\" Bella as a mother living in a perfect little fairy tale cottage. As I said, I would have enjoyed this so much more if I hadn't been trying to force myself to see \\"my\\" Bella when I read this. Once I started picturing her as someone else, I enjoyed it more.    I can totally see why people would like this book. But to me it just feels so incredibly out of place when put together with the first 3, like it doesn't belong. It feels wrong to me, like reading a fanfiction I know has nothing to do with what really happens in the story and I keep waiting for the release of the real thing.    I just feel like this book ruined the whole series for me, and I'm having trouble remembering why I fell in love with these characters to begin with. I will have to re-read Twilight soon, just so I can begin to get excited about the movie again.    And so, my raging, violent hatred of this book has dissipated to a dull irritation with a nice heaping of disappointment to go with it. But that's not to say that YOU won't like it. So go see for yourself.

031606792X|1.0|I stood in line at my local book shop and purchased my copy of Breaking Dawn, my anticipation mounting. I had a bad feeling about the book to begin with. With all of the craze going on about this Saga I wanted to avoid the story of the love struck teenager and her vampire squeeze, but my mother and sisters finally persuaded me to read them. I seriously could NOT put them down. Sure, it was Dostoevsky or Austen or Shakespeare, but it was entertaining nonetheless. I read all three books in a three day span, and then patiently waited for my own closure with Bella and Edward, who I had grown so attached to through the novels. I am sure that there are other readers out there who feel, or felt,  exactly the same way. I read Breaking Dawn as soon as the novel was in my hands, and as my eyes wandered through page after page I realized that this was mixture between a cheap, poorly written \\"thriller,\\" a grotesque horror story, and a harlequin romance. Page after page my dislike for Stephanie Meyer grew as she tore down the efforts of the past three novels. It felt that she rushed through it, and through a lack of creativity on her own part, threw in as many ridiculous ideas as possible to \\"satisfy\\" her fans. I am so thoroughly disappointed. If she planned on making this saga work, she probably should have just kept it a trilogy and ended at that. This book makes no sense whatsoever, and if the ending wouldn't have been a silly happily ever after, I truly believe that her fans would never forgive her. I have read many of the reviews on this site, and those who have graded it well are right on. The readers who have given Breaking Dawn 5 stars are merely trying to salvage the brand. Furthermore, as I read this book, I imagined the film version of this being played before my eyes. While I am still anticipating the release of the film Twilight, a film version of Breaking Dawn would be ravaged by critics, would not be able to stand on its own, and would be as entertaining as watching The Notebook, Saw, and Catwoman all rolled into one with even worse lines and an even dumber plot. But nonetheless, all of us who are captivated by this romance will read this dreadful book, watch the movie, and walk away a little differently, knowing that another author has made too hefty a promise that they couldn't deliver.

031606792X|5.0|I'm a huge Twilight fan and honestly, I'm disappointed in many of the reactions I've read to this final book. I don't usually review books but I felt I had to defend this one. For anyone who hasn't read Breaking Dawn,<br /><br />........................SPOILERS AHEAD!.................................<br /><br />First of all, OF COURSE Bella is immature...she's a teenager! Teenagers are dramatic, indecisive, and have trouble seeing past the here and now into the future. I'm actually grateful that Meyer made her grow up a bit in this book. I love Bella but sometimes I just wanted to reach through the pages of the previous books and shake some maturity into her. For everyone that's criticizing her being obsessed with sex, again...she's a teenager. At least Meyer had them do everything the responsible way...love, marriage, sex, THEN the baby. Even with her wanting to extend being human for a little while longer because of the sex sounds very typical of a young person, and also a young married person. She doesn't think that a close physical relationship will be possible for a long time once she becomes a vampire...who can blame her for wanting more than a few weeks of a somewhat normal marriage before the bloodlust kicks in, especially once she realizes what sex is like?<br /><br />Bella doesn't react the way a normal teenage girl does when she finds out she's pregnant but then again, Bella doesn't react to anything the way a normal person should at any time in the series so why should this be any different? Plus, normal teenage girls aren't usually married to a 90 year old vampire with gobs of money lying around and in-laws that would do anything to support her. Takes a little bit of the edge off of the discovery, if you ask me. And, like I mentioned about her maturity, I'm impressed at the level she showed during the pregnancy (how many teenage girls do you know that wouldn't run right out and get an abortion?) as well as after her vampire conversion. Those that are criticizing Meyer for bad messages in the book, she's advocating waiting until marriage to have sex and having the power to make a choice over your own body. I'm in full agreement on those two.<br /><br />While the baby did surprise me, it also helped with several aspects of the story. It made friends of Rosalie and Bella, which may never have happened any other way. Rosalie had given up hope of ever having a child and, yes, I'm sure she was jealous of Bella but that's really no different than any other human person who can't have a baby and is jealous when someone close to them gets pregnant. Renesmee is a miracle though and Rosalie gives all the love to her that she would have given to her own child. Some may say that's not enough but it's a happier ending for Rosalie than I could have thought up. And of course Bella called Rosalie once she found out she was pregnant. She wanted to keep the baby and was afraid that choice would be taken from her and knew that Rosalie, of all people, would help protect that choice. Also, Edward was always so worried that Bella would miss out on typical human things. Childbirth is definitely one of those typical human things that she wouldn't realize she wanted until she got older and it was too late. I think it was wonderful that one of the last things Bella did in her \\"living\\" life was to bring another life into the world.<br /><br />Okay...the imprinting. I'm not saying that I saw that one coming but it really makes sense of the whole Bella-Jacob relationship, doesn't it? I mean, didn't anyone else think, even for just a minute, that Jacob really did imprint on Bella and just didn't realize that he'd done it? I did. His feelings were so strong for her that would have been a good reason. But, him imprinting on Renesmee explained those feelings and also cut those ties he had to Bella. My heart just broke for Jacob and the pain he went through over Bella and I'm happy that he was able to move on without Bella and Jacob sacrificing their friendship.<br /><br />On to another point of contention that I've read about several times in the reviews...Bella's power. I was actually very happy for Bella after her conversion. She had wanted all of this so badly I would have hated it for her if her looks didn't change, if she was still a klutz, and if she had no decent power except the ability to block people from her head. But Meyer gave her the looks and the grace that Bella had been lacking as a human and expanded drastically on the anomaly that she'd had when she was human and made her, as a newborn vampire even, pretty powerful. Bella had always been self-sacrificing, always wanting to protect those around her and it was fitting that her power allowed her to protect so many from Jane and Alec...and she'll only get stronger as she learns to control it better.<br /><br />Maybe everything did work out a little bit too neatly in the end, but it's a love story, a fairy tale, not a tragedy like Romeo and Juliet. We wanted a happy ending, right? Bella made the choices that she did expecting to give up everything for love but in the end didn't really have to give up what she thought. What's so wrong with that? She was prepared to make big sacrifices for love but in the end had her happy ending. Would we all have wanted her to never see her father again and spend years in Alaska because she couldn't control her craving for blood? Or would we have wanted her to back out of the wedding last minute because she couldn't give up what she thought she'd have to? For all of Bella's failings she knew her own mind and stuck with her choices and everything worked out for the best in the end. I don't see anything wrong with that.r point of contention that I've read about several times in the reviews...Bella's power. I was actually very happy for Bella after her conversion. She had wanted all of this so badly I would have hated it for her if her looks didn't change, if she was still a klutz, and if she had no decent power except the ability to block people from her head. But Meyer gave her the looks and the grace that Bella had been lacking as a human and expanded drastically on the anomaly that she'd had when she was human and made her, as a newborn vampire even, pretty powerful. Bella had always been self-sacrificing, always wanting to protect those around her and it was fitting that her power allowed her to protect so many from Jane and Alec...and she'll only get stronger as she learns to control it better.    Maybe everything did work out a little bit too neatly in the end, but it's a love story, a fairy tale, not a tragedy like Romeo and Juliet. We wanted a happy ending, right? Bella made the choices that she did expecting to give up everything for love but in the end didn't really have to give up what she thought. What's so wrong with that? She was prepared to make big sacrifices for love but in the end had her happy ending. Would we all have wanted her to never see her father again and spend years in Alaska because she couldn't control her craving for blood? Or would we have wanted her to back out of the wedding last minute because she couldn't give up what she thought she'd have to? For all of Bella's failings she knew her own mind and stuck with her choices and everything worked out for the best in the end. I don't see anything wrong with that.

Also, I was thrilled when Jacob imprinted on Renesme, why is everyone freaking out!!  Now Bella and Jacob can truly be family without the crazy love triangle that makes them both miserable!      One last thing--For anyone that hated this book or feel \\"disappointed\\" in Stephenie Meyer, take a deep breath and read it again.  Once you get over the fact that all of your brilliant theories didn't turn out exactly how you imagined, I'm sure you'll fully enjoy and appreciate Breaking Dawn. So all in all, I thought the book was completely amazing, I nice ending to an amazing series, and I'm still shaking my head in wonder at all of the horrible reviews I am seeing.      P.S. B00005JPY0|5.0|After hearing and reading all that is said about the Dark Knight, I can add that there are strong performances from all actors.  The Joker is the best I've ever seen, because he is defined as a \\"moralist,\\" and not just a madman.  His conviction is no worse than any belligerent nationalist, dictator, or ultra conservative.  In my understanding, everyone is either a madman or a saint; it depends on who needs what you have.  Nevertheless, Batman is as mysterious as ever, showing his human weaknesses, which makes him more charming.  Policeman, Lt. Gordon, doesn't distract from the big picture, but facilitates sympathy for the police department, and innocent citizens, maintaining sanity, while everybody else is variable.  Lucius Fox, gadget genius, is dedicated to always doing the \\"right thing,\\" and solidifies the trio of himself, Batman, and Alfred, the manservant, who all work together to keep Batman alive.  The district attorney, Harvey Dent, is as memorable as the Joker is, because he has a yin/yang quality, some light and dark all rolled into one that, when viewed objectively, makes their choices inevitable.  We just should be thankful that our environment hasn't driven us to such extremes.  I can feel some pity for the Joker, because he sees the corruption of government just as that of organized crime, and is truly \\"mad\\" trying to even the playing field.  Of course, he just adds to the problem, but the point is that the good guys are not all that good; they just fight on that side.<br /><br />All in all, this is a great movie.  I saw it in IMAX, which just adds more length and width to the screen, and more decibels to the speakers.  A regular-sized theater screen is probably just as good.  This film would be great viewing on even an iPod.<br /><br />In conclusion, The Dark Knight is like a finely blended alcoholic cocktail, made with 200 Proof liquor (100% liquor) and fresh fruit juices.  Although the natural juices will disguise the strong booze taste, in a little while, you will be affected by the liquor.  I left the theater feeling a little more deranged by the dynamic sounds, visions, and morality of it all.ill be affected by the liquor. B0000CF300|5.0|Folks, I never told you what happened to me some time ago. Since I am revealing great mysteries about me, I might as well tell you this. I was captured by the enemy (you know who you are!) and a sequence of A Clockwork Metamorpho went into effect. Yes. They strapped me to a chair, prodded my eyes open and I was forced to view a screen that alternated between a message that read \\"You Will Take Your Reviews Seriously!\\" and pictures of disappointed shoppers leaving a store and burning me in effigy. Believe me, this was unsettling. I was programmed, however Marshy and Sondra got me out of it with belly dances. But not totally. Thus, I am doing this one because it deserves it and because I am a victim of the past (but trying to escape it totally).<br /><br />Do know that I am dressed in my cosmic cowboy best to write this. One must get into the mood. But, Gene Clark, well, that's a Byrd of a different feather for sure. Who is he? Well, when the Byrds came into prominence he was an incredible songwriter and delivered some of their best tunes in the rock vein. Eventually he left because of band squabbles. And what are most squabbles about? Money, of course. He was getting royalties when the others weren't and so..... gone!<br /><br />But, everything he did subsequently was of such a high caliber (and not in keeping with the pure pop arena) that it beckons me to write this. This is a man who wrote absolutely superb songs that most people have not heard of. In fact, he is one of Metamorpho's best kept secrets revealed to you here for the first time.<br /><br />As life flows and moves, it has always been a mystery that there are people out there that can create such works of beauty but still go unnoticed by many people. Gene is one of those artists. He was never recognized fully in his lifetime, but this selection speaks volumes about his ability and his craft.<br /><br />Before I go any further, please realize that \\"No Other\\" is a rare find. There are reflections here that are very deep. On the surface, you don't recognize it. But, on many listenings you get into more and more depth. Gene was complex and very much into finding the elements of the soul to channel back to you. These are not songs to take lightly. There is much more here than anyone can imagine.<br /><br />\\"No Other\\" is not a rock/pop offering by any means. The songs here have an underlying country sound mixed with contemporary considerations. The outline is reliant upon Gene's acoustic guitar with bass, slide guitar, drums, piano etc. added in. The essence is acoustic though. Gene's vocal is reminiscent of a country vocal, but not quite. There is a world weary sadness behind his singing. I cannot describe it exactly, but I know it is there. In all the songs and the changes, there is nothing to throw you off the thrust of where the music is going. Yet, there are little tidbits here, little excursions of sound, that make this selection so pleasing to hear.<br /><br />But it's the content, the voice and words that come back to haunt you. I believe he was a poet, a modern day troubadour that never found the audience he deserved. He reveals himself so eloquently with the lines from \\"Life's Greatest Fool\\"<br /><br />Words can be empty, though filled with sound<br />stoned numb and drifting, hard to be profound<br />formed out of pleasure, chiselled by pain<br />Never the highest, and not the last one to gain<br /><br />Plus he offers inner wisdom with these words from \\"Some Misunderstanding\\"<br /><br />Maybe someone knows what fate is, maybe someone knows just why<br />All I know is it's all ... related, Maybe someone can explain time<br />But I know if you sell..your soul, to brighten your role<br />you might be disappointed in the lights...<br /><br />Gene never sold his soul. He was responsible to his inner muse, his inner calling only, and that calling produced songs of such beauty and finesse.<br />He certainly was the cosmic cowboy, but the songs here have a natural balance. You are never beaten over the head with the groove of it, in fact, it is so subtle that you work to bring it out to your own mind. This is his magic as a songwriter. He was overshadowed by many singer-songwriters of the era such as James Taylor, Carole King, Jackson Browne, etc. etc. But Gene is just as vital in his own unique style.<br /><br />This selection includes the 8 songs he recorded for Asylum in 1975 plus the addition of 7 out-takes from the session. In all honesty, the out takes are just as superb as the released tunes. They are stripped down to their essence and you can see what production accomplished. However, they perfectly convey the vision and what he was after in the studio. It has been documented that Gene had an undiagnosed bi-polar disorder. It has been told to me that these people feel things more in-depth than most. It is evident here. This wonderous artist died much too young. But, his testimony lives on and it would be criminal not to give him a serious listen. It would be an honest journey of reflection - but well worth the taking.<br /><br />Now, let me stop here before they take your poor Metamorpho away and force me to see that video again. You don't want me to stop my frivolity all together now, would you? O.K., don't all rush to the stage at once! Leave me a panic room at least!<br /><br />Your Kozmic seer -- Metamorpho ;)ing it out to your own mind. This is his magic as a songwriter. He was overshadowed by many singer-songwriters of the era such as James Taylor, Carole King, Jackson Browne, etc. etc. But Gene is just as vital in his own unique style. B000002BPS|5.0|I've been listening to the Offspring for about eight years now, but for some reason I never picked this one up until recently. It hasn't yet grown on me like Smash or even Conspiracy of One, but it has some great tracks, many of which are really funny.    I rate the tracks with all other Offspring songs in mind.    Disclaimer: 5/5 - Really hilarious and clever intro, probably the best of any of the Offspring albums, if not a little over the top...    The Meaning of Life: 4.5/5 - Great energetic opener, what you would expect, but not quite as powerful as Americana's \\"Have You Ever\\" and Smash's \\"Nitro\\".    Mota: 3/5 - This has one of those great little high-powerchord intro riffs that the Offspring are known for, and it really sets a good mood for this faced-paced satirical song. But not one of my favorite off the album, probably because the chorus isn't as cool as the verse.    Me & My Old Lady: 4.5/5 - Longest song ont he album, Really catchy riff and verse rhythm, and the brief lead guitar melody near the beginning is a nice difference from other songs. I think this songs \\"she aint no ball and chain\\" was probably influenced by the Social Distortion song, but maybe not...    Cool To Hate: 5/5 - Just an awesome well-paced song, the lyrics are brilliant. Probably the most memorable track from the album. I only wish I hated this song, so I could be cool    Leave It Behind: 4/5 - A good short and fast follow-up to that last song.  The opening riff makes me think of \\"Genocide\\".    Gone Away: 5/5 - Really not a typical-sounding Offspring song; The intro and verse vocals sound more like they are off a grunge or alternative rock album. The chorus is very memorable, too. This rates as one of the Offspring's best slower songs.    I Choose:  3.5/5 - Hahaha, the first 1.5 seconds of this always throw me off because it sounds like that Van Halen song \\"Unchained\\". The main riff and rhythm of this song are cool, but I just don't like the vocals on this song. I'm sure others mightstrongly disagree with me. Though it does have a nice solo about midway through.    Intermission: 5/5 - Ahhhhhh....    All I Want: 5/5 - So the guitar parts aren't quite as interesting as other songs on the album, but this quick song has an awesome vocal melody.     Way Down the Line: 4/5 - Song about how kids turn out just like their parents. Has one of those Offspring choruses similar to One Fine Day or Walla Walla.    Don't Pick It Up: 4/5 - I like how this song almost sounds like its gonna be serious at the start. This is the obligatory ska-punk-sounding song on the album and its pretty funny.    Amazed: 3.5/5 - Not-typical-Offspring in a similar way as \\"Gone Away\\". If you've listened to the Conspiracy album, the chorus sounds similar to \\"Vultures\\", but a little better. I think the main thing I don't like about the song is its placement after \\"Don't Pick it Up\\". The guitar is pretty unspectacular compared with other songs on Ixnay except for the interesting little lead melody at the beginning.    Change the World: 4/5 - Starts with that mysterious interesting guitar riff that ended the song \\"Smash\\" on the previous album. I like how it builds off of that with drums, 2nd guitar etc. This song always reminds me of that song \\"Revolution\\" by the Beatles.    I should add that I don't really listen to any punk, mostly classic rock, progressive and instrumental rock, and some metal. But the Offspring is a great band with diverse albums I love to listen to straight through. it never gets dull, it never gets old. If you're just getting into their music, definitely go for something like Smash first instead of the newest albums; but if you have that one already, Ixnay is an excellent choice, as is Ignition or Americana.

For thousands of years, the world of humans and the world of supernatural creatures has been at peace, but an angry Prince Nuada is determined to bring about a war between the two.  Knowing that Hellboy is shunned and repulsed by humans, the prince tries to lure Hellboy to his side.<br /><br />  The sequel is more emotional than the original.  It involves love found and lost.  Hellboy's relationship with Liz Sherman is strained; they are on the brink of separation.<br /><br />  There is a secret world of goblins, faeries, hags and trolls hidden beneath Manhattan's Brooklyn Bridge.  This reminded me very much of the \\"Harry Potter\\" series where witches and other supernatural creatures have their own banks, trains, and shopping districts hidden behind magical walls.  However, many of the creatures in \\"Hellboy II\\" bore a closer resemblance to the aliens found in \\"Star Wars\\" or \\"The Fifth Element.\\"  Indeed, the institution where Hellboy lives is becoming more like the one in \\"Men in Black.\\"  Furthermore, the prince reminded me of an emaciated Vampire Lestat in \\"Interview with the Vampire.\\"<br /><br />  Yes, \\"Hellboy II\\" does seem to imitate a lot of classic science fiction movies, but it still remains unique in its own way.  Every one of us can identify with Hellboy because we have all been rejected at one time or another.<br /><br />  \\"Hellboy II\\" is packed with gruesome, terrifying creatures.  The most horrific are the Tooth Faeries - four-legged insect-like creatures with round heads and big mouths full of razor-sharp teeth.  They are like piranha with wings; they fly in swarms and ferociously devour all flesh, bone, and muscle and leave no trace of the victim except when they defecate.  Simply gross!

031606792X|1.0|As the, er, dawn of Breaking Dawn edged closer, and the spoilers started coming out, I found myself refusing to believe them. After all, they went against so much of what had happened in the previous books (case in point: vampires having babies). I was in disbelief even as the chapters themselves started to trickle in. It was just too bad - horrific fanfiction. The characters were out of character (Renee is psyched for her daughters wedding, after three books of being vehemently against marrying early. Bella dreads marriage, only to discover after the ceremony that it is everything she has ever wanted. She loathes the idea of children only to find, again, that she loves it after it happened). Bella, basically a Mary Sue before this book, loses absolutely nothing. Everything goes perfectly for her. Meyer, again, pays no attention to her previous books as Bella finds herself pregnant (supposedly impossible), Edward finds himself unable to recognize this (despite two rounds of medical school), and no one realizes that the baby might want blood (even though it is half-vampire). The list goes on, really. And, oh, look, a deus ex machina! And another! What to do with Jacob? Let's have him imprint on the demon spawn! That's handy! So not only was the new book complete with Meyer's usual sub-par writing, but the plot was awful as well. I found myself aching for the book to be over with already. The ultimate showdown with the Volturi, billed as a major plot point, barely happened. What a let down.     And the morals! Meyer claims that Bella is a strong female character, but the only way that would be possible would be if strength was basically the equivalent of getting a man, a baby, and nice cottage in the woods, and giving up every bit of one's own character and beliefs. She refuses to grow as a person, instead preferring to be attached to a man she likes mostly because he is hot (it cannot be anything else - they never talk about anything but how much they love each otherand, later, the demon spawn). It's an empty book with bad morals full of empty people and bad plot contrivances.     I really, honestly, wish I had not wasted the time to read this piece of trash. If, after reading all of these negative reviews, you still want to read this massive piece of fail, I beg you not to give any of your money to such an awful writer, as well as whatever sort of editor would allow this to be published.

B0018AK9RA|5.0|Another metal band has once again proved that metal contains historical, mythological, spiritual, and even scholarly substance. Concept albums like Judas Priest's new album \\"Nostradamus\\" are a rare find these days and something the music world has been lacking.<br /><br />Following the life of the 16th century prophet Nostradamus, Judas Priest captures the social and historical ramifications of one person's quest still felt 500 years later. With brilliant packaging, and a bonus box set version, Priest offers not one but two full length discs with 23 tracks and nearly two hours worth of music. We can imagine the guys in Iron Maiden kicking themselves for not thinking of this one.<br /><br />This album may not be their prime work, but it showcases their diverse talent and the evolution of a band that spans four decades. Now that I've reminded early fans just how old they are, it's important to remember that the guys in the band are in their 50s! Songs like \\"Visions\\" sound like they are right out of the 80s prime of metal, but the album has the overall depth and maturity that even the best 80s metal bands never achieved. Most bands didn't and still don't get past a decade.<br /><br />All of the guitars are solid and Rob Halford tops every English metal singer in the world when he breaks into an Italian chorus in the melodic \\"Pestilence and Plague.\\" Halford's grown into a diverse and interesting voice. I'd like to see his listening collection. \\"Alone\\" sounds like Neil Diamond on metal-- a great thing! Other songs like \\"New Beginnings\\" sounds like it's right off of a Phantom-esqe Broadway show. But before I scare you off with these comparisons, there are some heavy hitters like the opening \\"Prophecy\\", \\"Revelations\\", the violent sounding \\"War\\" and \\"Nostradamus\\" at the end of disc two.<br /><br />While it's no surprise that this album isn't a headbanging thrash album, there are songs on it that you can bang your head to. Here is a metal album that you can rock to, that will make you appreciate history, make you want to learn Italian, and make you want to read more. Any metal album that makes you rock and think at the same time is a sure hit.make you want to learn Italian, and make you want to read more. Any metal album that makes you rock and think at the same time is a sure hit.

B00140PK6O|5.0|I just finished watching the BBC's Cranford miniseries and it was wonderful.  The series is set in a small town in 1840s England.  Cranford is a town full of unmarried women (very common at the time with all of the men who had died in the Napoleonic wars and those who had gone to the colonies--India, etc) where social decorum and gossip are equally important.  Change is afoot in Cranford as the railroad comes into the area and small town life threatens to change forever.  The miniseries aptly captures the mood of the age, showing the emotion of the townspeople in a memorable way.<br /><br />This is a wonderful ensemble piece, even though Judi Dench really does steal just about every scene she's in.  All of the main characters are well developed, and as you learn their back-stories you like them even more.  When the miniseries was over I wanted more--so I will definitely be renting the other BBC Elizabeth Gaskell movies.<br /><br />I had never seen any series based on Elizabeth Gaskell novels before, so if you are in doubt, I would recommend this series to anyone who enjoys Jane Austen, Louisa May Alcott, or even the recent BBC version of Bleak House.  The miniseries is done with all of the usual BBC taste so be ready to enjoy some quality period fun!

Perhaps we anticipated too much how the series was going to end? Going into the final books in other series, I've never been this disappointed, so I just don't know. All I know is I wasted a sunny Saturday being saddened by something I'd been looking so forward to.<br /><br />Oh well. I'll read her again - I just won't read THIS book again any time soon.
1416550518|5.0|This book owes a great debt (duly noted in the acknowledgments) to Upstairs, Downstairs, Remains of the Day, Gosford Park, The Blind Assassin and anything by DuMaurier, and I think that Kate Morton does her literary and cinematic ancestors proud.<br /><br />The story is cunningly written, and though I often gripe about being able to spot plot points in advance, I did not see what would happen ahead of time.  This was a refreshing change.  There was only one instance where I knew a plot point before the protagonist did, but it was tangential to the main storyline, and the clues laid out before us were meant to lead us in that direction, so I don't consider that a flaw.<br /><br />These are the kinds of sprawling, layered novels that I love most.  Someone looking back over her life reveals a lifetime worth of secrets and reading the novel is like peeling an onion.  I tried to ration out my reading of it, because I knew I would never want it to end, but finally I had to give in to my desire to see what would happen next and how all the ends would tie together.<br /><br />Fascinating reading - on the basis of this book I already have The Forgotten Garden on my wish list.

B00005JKNF|4.0|In a screenplay by Julian Fellowes, and through the imaginations of Bob Balaban and the late director, Robert Altman, viewers find themselves transported to the upper crust society of 1932 England, where  the devious Sir William McCordle (Michael Gambon) and his elegant and aristocratic, but cold wife,Lady Sylvia(Kristen Scott Thomas) host variegated guests at their country estate for a weekend shooting party.     Young Mary Maceachran(Kelly Macdonald)accompanies her employer, Constance, the Countess of Trenham (Dame Maggie Smith)to her niece's estate, encountering actor/singer/composer, Ivor Novello, Sir William's second cousin (an amiable and very gifted Jeremy Northam), on the road with friend and producer, Morris Weissman (a crude Bob Balaban) en route to the same destination.    Others arriving at the estate on that rainy November day include the hostess' sisters Louisa and Lavinia(Geraldine Sommerville, Natasha Wightman) and Lord Stockbridge and Commander Meredith (Charles Dance and Tom Hollander). The McCordle's daughter Isobel (Camilla Rutherford), greets her suitor, Lord Rupert Standish (Lawrence Fox), who is accompanied by his friend, Mr. Jeremy Blond (Trent Ford). The Nesbitts, Freddie and Mabel (James Wilby and Claudey Blakely) are a couple who happen to be broke, and their relationship is tense and volatile.   The butler, Jennings (Alan Bates) greets the guests at the entrance and directs the servants upon their arrival. Indoors, the downstairs set are directed by Mrs. Wilson ( Helen Mirren), the chief housekeeper. The other notable servants in this drama include Mrs. Croft (Eileen Atkins), Probst, the valet (Derek Jacobi), Robert Parks (a subtly charismatic Clive Owen) a gauche and mysterious Henry Denton(Ryan Phillippe)who tries to seduce Mary at one point, and head housemaid, Elsie (a hard-bitten Emily Watson), who, like more than one before her,  knows her employer quite intimately.    During an afternoon tea, Novello finds himself at the receivingend of Constance's caustic views of his career, but also on the receiving end of Mabel's admiration.    In the style and tradition of episodes of \\"Mystery\\" and \\"Masterpiece Theater\\", we are led through the upper crust rituals of formal dinners, games of pool, and the shooting party itself.    After one of many scandalous  secrets is revealed, Novello is called to ease the tension by playing a few numbers. \\"I Can Give You the Starlight\\" was composed seven years after this story takes place. Yet despite this inaccuracy, I found myself glad it was included. The piano stylings of Jeremy Northam and/or his brother, Christopher liven things up more than a little, and the well-enunciated, Broadway-ish singing voice of the former, allegedly developed during a real-life stint as a singing waiter, is a pleasant one. Watching the servants dance to the distant sound of his tunes is priceless, emphasizing the spontaneous joy of the downstairs set.    When the host is found dead in his study, with his ever-present dog close at hand, the reaction of those present is one of temporary stunned surprise and horror, even by the widow.    Stephen Fry's Inspector Thompson is called in, along with assistant Constable Dexter (Ron Webster).   While some tears are shed, generally, the crisis is met with stereotypical British reserve, as the widow and daughter entertain their guests clad in mourning. But more unflattering secrets about the departed are revealed, along with the pretentiousness of some of the upstairs set. Constable Dexter's summary of this world is one of dead-on precision: \\"It's a poisonous paradise.\\"    Soon, many of those involved find themselves making life-altering choices, and those unable to do so are left to new dilemmas and/or to their grief--not just over the deceased, but also in several instances, to issues pertaining to his treatement of them.   The reprise of Novello's \\"The Land of Might-Have-Been\\" proves a fitting conclusion for the piece-- a sweet and sour slice of upper-crust life of a by-gone era, that makes fine viewing for quiet evenings in.

B0018O4YSQ|4.0|\\"Dark City\\" was ahead of its time a year to be precise. Examining many of the same themes (an example of simultaneous evolution of ideas, themes and \\"the look\\")as \\"The Matrix\\" (with a somewhat different mystery/plot at its core although ironically \\"The Matrix\\" used some of the same sets) Alex Proyas' \\"Dark City\\" looks at the nature of memory and its definition of our humanity.<br /><br />The Blu-ray looks quite good although there is an overuse of Digital Noise Reduction to eliminate the film grain (something that is an important part of the \\"look\\" of the film as much as the color scheme is for \\"The Matrix\\"), the images are crisper with a great deal more detail than on the previous DVD (having seen a DVD rental copy for comparison the DVD looks quite good as well) but some fine detail does occasionally get lost in some of the darker noir influenced sequences of the film due to the overuse of DNR. Still, it is a step up from the previous DVD edition which looked quite good for its time. It doesn't look as bad as \\"Patton\\" (where complexions had a waxy, pasty sheen to them and, again, fine detail in the faces were often lost)but looks better than some digitally overprocessed films. The Blu-ray has both editions of the film--the original theatrical cut and Director's Cut of the film both subjected to DNR to about the same degree,while the DVD has ONLY the \\"Director's Cut\\" of the film. It's a pity because the original DVD certainly is in need of a decent upgrade.<br /><br />Audio sounds terrific.Both the DVD and Blu-ray editions come with a Digital \\"bonus\\" copy of the film that is Windows compatible. Unless you watch it a lot on your PC, you may pull it out once or maybe twice. It is NOT compatible with Apple or ipod devices however.<br /><br />This new edition ports over almost all the original special features from the DVD including the commentary tracks plus adds additional ones as well.  Some special features are in 480i while some others are in 1080p and these include a new documentary \\"Memories of Shell Beach\\", \\"Architecture of Dreams\\", a production gallery, introduction by Director Proyas and the film's champion film critic Roger Ebert (from a 2005 video interview for this edition), text essays, a review of the film by Neil Gaiman and a \\"Director's Cut Fact Track\\" that is a pop-up trivia text extra that notes differences in the \\"Director's Cut\\" vs. the theatrical version of the film, various subtle changes, etc.<br /><br />As to whether you like the \\"Director's Cut\\" or the original theatrical cut that depends on you. I personally preferred the DC because it adds footage (including some alternate angles of shots that Proyas prefers)while subtracting the distracting narration that Keifer Sutherland had to read (it was forced on Proyas by New Line and he never liked it feeling it gave away too much of the plot of the film and was somewhat like the \\"Blade Runner\\" narration--it's not THAT bad but it doesn't add to the enjoyment of the film for me). We get the original theatrical trailer as well.<br /><br />For those who HAVEN'T seen the film a synposis of the plot: John Murdoch (Rufus Swell)awakens in the bath to find two things--1) He doesn't know who he is and a trio of mysterious people are after him 2) there is the body of a prostitute in his hotel room who is the latest victim of a serial killer. He has no memory of having committed the murder nor does he know who he is or why he's there. Murdoch must complete the puzzle of his what happened, figure out who he is before a detective (Willim Hurt)catches him and figure out how the wife he has never seen before (Jennifer Connelly)figures in this mystery. His only guide aside from the clues he can find is a mysterious doctor (Keifer Sutherland)who claims to know who he is, how he lost his memory and that he is involved in some bold, bizarre experiment.<br /><br />Regardless of which version of the film you like, \\"Dark City\\" is well worth seeing as it prefigures \\"The Matrix\\" a over a year. While it didn't catch on at the box office the same way, it did earn critical raves including Roger Ebert naming it the Best Film of 1998.<br /><br />Film- 4 stars<br />Video-3 stars (Too much Digital Noise Reduction used to eliminate film grain)<br />Audio-4 1/2 stars<br /><br />Overall--a terrific film gets its due even if the video isn't perfect it looks stunning at times (although there is a signficant amount of edge enhancement througout the film to compensate for the DNR).<br /><br />Great extras from New Line.<br /><br />Recommended.ox office the same way, it did earn critical raves including Roger Ebert naming it the Best Film of 1998. B000YAA68W|5.0|This is an animated film based on a true story of a young woman growing up in post-Shah Iran. It is absolutely brilliantly done--the story, the animation, everything.  There is bonus material on the DVD where the author can be seen making the movie and telling some back stories about her life.      It is emotionally powerful as it desribes how she does not fit into society--neither her own in Iran, nor anywhere in Europe where she is sent to live and go to school for her own safety.  The political situation in Iran is clearly described and we get  a real sense of what it must have been like to live in that society. We see innocent people murdered on whims, others hiding their social lives, and all doing their best to survive various religious regimes.    The author's own personal struggle is heart breaking and it is wonderful to know that she eventually found direction in her life, culminating in her success in creating this movie.  Very deserving of the Oscar.

031606792X|3.0|First, I can (to a degree) understand the frantic worry that seems to be bothering some of the readers on here about how Bella's detour from reality might negatively influence some of the more impressionable readers of this series. However, I think that most teenage girls (or boys, not to be prejudice) can decipher the difference between the over-the-top fantasy that this book is and what real life entails. Sure, Bella doesn't end up a feminist hero or gain any real insight or depth in this book-but why would anyone expect her to? Although I waited during the course of the other three books for Meyer to play up what could have been some very interesting and movingly literary character dilemmas, all the opportunities that I saw for character/story development were passed blithely by as the characters in the books face minor (on a vampire scale) challenges, but then ultimately end up the exact same people in the exact same situations by the end of their lengthy adventures. Why would the finale be any different?     I enjoyed this book because I took it at face value. I did not expect true depth, and I was not disappointed. While it might not be the most creative or thought-provoking ending, as far as teen-vampire-romance novels go, this entire series has been well-articulated and provides better reads than 99% of other books marketed towards readers of this demographic. I hope that some of the more vicious attacks on the book won't deter Mrs. Meyer from furthering her writing career.

031606792X|5.0|To start ***SPOILERS***. (I don't know if that is needed because I've never written a review here before but felt the need to speak up on seeing the negativity.)    I've been a fan of these books for the past year- not an obsessive one, although I may have done a happy dance at seeing the movie trailer. I did read the series through twice and was eagerly anticipating the conclusion.  I even did the midnight thing (even though I'm, oh, a skosh older than the average fan).    Before reading anyone else's opinion, I loved the book.  On further examination, I may have a FEW regrets with the extremely happy conclusion, but not nearly enough to take away from my total blissed-out read. I thought I knew where this was going about a hundred pages in and was weary at the thought of 600 pages worth of Bella flip-flopping over her fate and ending up playing the martyr and selflessly staying human to give birth while Edward died valiantly to save Bella and his child during some sort of siege. Frankly, I was mad.  So, I was surprised by the gutsy choices Meyer made and thought this was a great read.  Anyone who thinks that Bella didn't make any sacrifices must have skimmed the second third of the book- even if it isn't told through her eyes, I think we see our heroine MORE than earn her happy ending.      I loved it.  It's worth the purchase, make your own decisions.  And for heavens sake steer clear of spoilers, because I'd probably have run for the hills if I'd gotten the plot of this book in a paragraph or two- I went in spoiler-free.  If you're reading this, you already love these people.  Spend a little more time with them, because even if the more dramatic plot twists throw you off, the dialogue is still completely right- just read Bella's reaction to Jacob's nickname for her daugher and you'll KNOW it's still her. (Great scene.)    Lastly, if I could deduct a quarter of a star for the name Renesmee, I would.  Someone please tell me how to pronounce this so it doesn't sound awkward.  I would have voted for 'Carlie Renesmee'.  Not that big a leap.

I've known smart people, and lost people, and some who were both. Nicholson's \\"Joker\\" projected vicious insanity outward. Ledger's projected it inward. Even his flaking facepaint worked to convey what lay within, the way that ivy, lichens, and crumbling mortar convey what lies inside a ruin.<br /><br />Bale's \\"Batman\\" goes out on Ledger's limb with him. Batman retains enough sanity left to know that people need sanity; Ledger's \\"Joker\\" has spiralled in on himself, so that nothing remains for human contact. Somehow the Joker recruits cronies, despite their remarkably short working lives.<br /><br />In the end, they sit around discussing what all other the citizens of the city ought to be allowed to know - the six (or so) deciding for the six million (or so). If the road to hell is paved with good intentions, these guys have a fleet of trucks standing by to pave it for you.<br /><br />It's not for young kids. If you take your tweener or young teen, have a long talk after. Back in the day, good guys won, bad guys lost, and we all went home knowing who was who. That day is gone, and good riddance. Today, people need to think, even after a superhero/action flick. Is that so bad?<br /><br />-- wiredweird, reviewing the theatrical release
031606792X|5.0|Breaking Dawn was truly a mixed bag of a book for me. There were some things I really liked, but some things that really annoyed me. One of the plot lines sounded like an ill conceived fanfiction I had read, while other plot lines left open from Eclipse were conveniently resolved with little to no problems. The book was separated into three books, two of them narrated by Bella and the middle one narrated by Jacob. I was hoping for an Edward book, but I guess I'll have to wait for Midnight Sun for that. Jacob is not my favorite character, so reading through his mood swings and craziness was a little painful for me. Another problem was that the insights into characters that were commonplace in the first three books are pretty much absent in this one. The literary allusions (also a characteristic of the previous books) weren't as involved as in the past.    Despite its obvious flaws, I was riveted. I bought the book at a midnight release party and had to sit and read until I was finished. That is a staple of a good book. I went from being happy to sad to outraged (to the point of yelling at the book) and back. I was on the edge of my seat for much of the novel. I deeply care about what happens to these characters and I wasn't disappointed. My favorite scenes are in the last third of the book, including the face off with the Volturi. Even if many of us thought at one point or another in the novel, \\"Stephenie, what were you thinking?\\", this book was a great conclusion to an awesome saga.

There is no greater love than that of a child and to have that many people involved in protecting said child is an amazing thing.     All that being said, I think it could have been a better book but it wasn't as horrible as people are making it out to be. I think a lot of it depends on your view of the world and life experiences to really understand the dynamics of the book. Open your minds and read it a few times and I think it will grow on you.

031606792X|3.0|***SPOILERS WILL BE IN THIS REVIEW***    I've read a ton of the negative reviews, and they all say basically the same thing.  That there is no sacrifice, and everything conveniently falls into Bella's lap.  This is absolutely true, but are these reactions justified?    I wish I had a picture of my face when I figured out Bella was pregnant.  I'm sure it was absolute misery and horror.  While I completely disagreed with this direction, and Bella's immediate reaction, there were some points to this decision that cannot be overlooked.  Edward did struggle, but stood by his wife's decision to keep the child.  I would like to point out HER decision, because she is a woman, it is her body.  Bella also gained some level of maturity because of this, which one thing she has always been lacking in.  Do I think it was the right way to go, not really.  I soldiered on, even though I had a deep desire to stop.      I loved Jacob's section.  You could tell the ease that Stephanie has writing this character, it isn't as forced as Bella.  Did I like the fact that he imprinted on her child, not really, but I knew he was going to imprint on someone.  Bella would have been off the hook the second Jacob imprinted anyway, so the object--while messed up--doesn't really matter.    The overall writing in this book was the best out of the four.  Bella's changes in this book were constant and fitting for the time.  Her teenage insecurities seemed to vanish and she became a woman, which is a natural if not necessary progression for Bella's character.  While Bella's choices may not have been the ones you would make; you have not been courted by a vampire.  Her choices are going to be different given the circumstances.    I began to enjoy the book much more once I separated myself from all these stigmas I was putting on the author, and that most of you have.  \\"This doesn't set a good example for teenage girls,\\" \\"Life isn't like this,\\" you get the point.  The truth is, it isn't the author's responsibility to impose moral values and life lessons on their readers (thought I think overall Meyer did an excellent job).  This book is a work of fiction, meant to entertain.  Enlightenment, life lessons, etc are good things to put in literature, but since when are they a requirement?  If you don't want to instill these silly, and irresponsible ideas in your child's head then don't let them read it.  It isn't Stephenie Meyer's responsibility to instill values and life lessons upon the youth of America (Bella was married before having sex, that is a good thing).  Don't fool yourself into thinking that girls don't want the fantasy, otherwise why would Disney movies be so popular?  Let them have their fantasy world while they can, they will grow up someday.  Stephenie Meyer simply provided what everyone wanted, it was the curve balls she thew at you along the journey that most didn't approve of, including me.     I agree that Bella got off easy, but with everything she has been through don't you think she deserves a little time in the sun?  Read it again, for fun, as entertainment and you might like it a little more.  Let the teenager in you come out and enjoy the fantasy, because the world that we know sucks enough, why not escape for a little while?  If you're unable to do this then do what the entire world did with the Matrix squeals, and simply pretend this book doesn't exist.
031606792X|1.0|The first three books in the Twilight Series have flaws. But I loved them FOR their flaws, not despite them.  The mediocre writing, the bad dialogue, the fact that Edward is (IMHO) a watered down version of Mr. Rochester from one of my favorite books, Jane Eyre.  The questionable message sent to young girls about their own self worth, the near total glossing over of the pitfalls of immortality.  These books are still fun reads, suspenseful plots, decent fight scenes, and I will keep them in case I want to re-read in the future.    Breaking Dawn, is a whole different story.  Besides going back on specific claims that Vampires in her universe are unable to make babies, the author doesn't even really explain the mechanics of it.  I'm left wondering what the hell happened.  And in the end, nothing much.  This book is one big anticlimax.  All that time leading up to the grand battle with the Volturi...and there is no fight, everybody goes home okay.  All that time spend wondering what will happen when Renesmee (OMG that name) grows up too fast... and nothing happens.  Turns out she's going to live forever.  All that loooong, draaawn out time wondering what's going to happen with the vampire/werewolf/human love triangle and....Jacob inprints on Bella and Edward's creepy spawn instead of being allowed to live and grow away from Bella naturally and realistically.  All that time wondering about Bella's vampire power and it turns out to be a Lily Potter-esque \\"love shield\\".  Cop out after cop out after cop out.    Now for the good, the reason this book actually deserves one star instead of zero:  Jacob's book.  Despite my not liking Jacob in any of the previous books, I sympathized with him in this one, and found myself really interested in what was going on with the werewolves.    To sum up:  this book sacrifices all rational and interesting plot lines and ideas to give every single character a \\"happy\\" ending.  I recommend this novel ONLY to those interested in seeing everysingle thing tied up a nice, neat bow.

031606792X|4.0|This book, highly anticipated was absolutely a stunner. The longest book in the Twilight series, this finishes Bella and Edward's story from Bella's perspective.<br /><br />First, Breaking Dawn begins with Bella remembering when she told her father, Charlie about her engagement to Edward Cullen, a vampire. Of course, Charlie has no idea that Edward and his family are vampires, or that his daughter is planning on marrying Edward and becoming a vampire herself. Surprisingly, Charlie isn't too surprised by her announcement.<br /><br />The first 7 chapters are about Bella's wedding and honeymoon to Isle Esme, her new vampire mother-in-law's private island. (Apparently, vampires are very rich, or at least the Cullen family is) Making love with Edward is a problem: he is supernaturally strong, and very afraid he will loose control and hurt her/bite her. Even with those risks, they somehow manage to have a decent honeymoon. Until...<br /><br />Bella starts feeling funny. She is throwing up, having strange food cravings, and her period is 5 days late. But, she's only been honeymooning for 2 weeks, it couldn't be possible that she is pregnant, can it?? Apparently YES, she can be.<br /><br />Now, this is where the story really lost its reality: vampires are DEAD. Having children should NOT be a possibility, but for Bella and Edward, a reality they will have to face, VERY soon. Bella's pregnancy is VERY accelerated, and no one is sure what sort of child she will have, vampire, human, vampire human hybrid??<br /><br />Now the point of view switches to Jacob, Bella's best friend, who is a shape shifting werewolf. He is devastated by Bella's marriage, deeply concerned for her safety while honeymooning, and can't stand the thought of her a)becoming a vampire and b)being with someone besides himself. Now, Jacob and his pack have to make a decision about Bella. The Cullen family promised that they would never bite a human, and if they did, the wolves could hunt them and kill them. Obviously, Bella's situation is NOT something the wolves bargained for: a human WANTING to be willingly bitten.<br /><br />Without spoiling the ending, Twilight fans, this book DOES wrap up the story with Bella and Edward nicely. SHE DOES become a vampire, and its worth reading, my favorite part of the novel. (Last half) There is closure for team Jacob fans as well, the Volturi come into play, and NONE of the Cullen's die.<br /><br />I'd say this was a SHOCKING read, it presented MANY surprises I was not prepared for, and went a very different way than anticipated. Many reviewers have been disappointed with Breaking Dawn, and I think they expected something very different too. I loved the book, after I got used to the idea of Bella getting pregnant. If you ignore how far-fetched that idea is, you'll enjoy the book more. 031606792X|2.0|A formulaic, uninspired ending to a mediocre yet fun series. Mrs. Meyer's conservative beliefs have permeated every word in this book, making it feel more like right-wing propaganda than a young adult goth romance novel.<br /><br />Bella, who until now has been dead-set against marriage (let alone motherhood) takes to marriage like a fish to water, and instead of reacting with a normal amount of shock, she embraces pregnancy at 18 as if it were her lifelong goal. The first three books portrayed Bella as a pragmatic (if needy) teenager who knew domestic bliss wasn't for her; Breaking Dawn nonsensically throws all that out the window.<br /><br />Breaking Dawn is deeply anti-feminist. It insists that all women (no matter what they may think) really just want to be barefoot and pregnant. And even though vampires should be the epitome of sexual equality -- men and women are equally strong -- Meyer can't let that happen, so it turns out that the reason vampires can't procreate is because of the WOMEN. Men are perfectly capable of fertilizing normal, weak women.<br /><br />I thought that the entire series provided a less than perfect example for teen girls given that Bella is obsessed only with guys (and one guy in particular), but it took a real nosedive with Breaking Dawn.

031606792X|5.0|I just finished the book -- it kept me reading right up to the end just like the others.  I understand the surprise (although not really the disappointment) of others. Getting to experience all of their triumphs after all of their struggles was very satisfying to me.      I also understand where we would all like to have some nice message in there somewhere... but guess what??? I wanted Bella and Edward to be happy, and I got what I wanted.  Now I'm happy!

Its is mythological fiction, after all, and as such, Stephenie took liberties with the qualities that her characters have in their lives.  Fine. Its her story and she has that right.     I went into this book wanting two things - that Bella & Edward get married and that she is changed into a vampire.  I got both.  So I'm satisfied with that.      New characters are introduced, and while I would love to learn more about them, I understand why more exposition wasn't done on them.  Things are shaken up quite a bit for our favorite Vampire family, and everything does have a conclusion.  Even Bella's family is wrapped up in the ending.     Is it unrealistic?  Absolutely - -that's why its fantasy.      But if you don't put so much stock in \\"what it should be\\" and just read it for the fun of it, you will enjoy it.

031606792X|5.0|When reading this book, you need to keep some things in mind:    1.  This is not Fordyce's Sermons to Young Women or the Book of Virtues. Although some readers argue that Stephenie Meyer has an obligation to hold Bella to the highest moral standards due to the wild popularity of these books, do you honestly think girls who are smart enough to read 600 page books are going to go do everything Bella does? I think not.  Besides... they got married before anything happened. Jeez.   2.  This is a FANTASY BOOK. Stephenie has every right to do whatever she wants with her own fantasy world that SHE CREATED.  If she decides vampires can sprout wings or talk to animals or become invisible, then that's what they can do in HER FANTASY WORLD.   3.  This is not an epic work of literature that will be read in classrooms 100 years from now, and was never intended to be.  If the Mrs. Meyer crank out 4 600+ page books in 4 years, do not expect them to be Romeo and Juliet or Pride and Prejudice, or even Harry Potter.  4.  If there was no happy ending and Edward or Bella or Jacob or Alice died I would cry my eyeballs out and SO WOULD YOU!  Don't deny it, you would be crushed.      Personally, I totally enjoyed this book.  There was a lot going on, but Bella turned into a character that I really grew to respect (I disliked her in the previous books) due to her willingness to sacrifice her life to protect the people she loved.  And she kicked butt.  I got my happy ending in a nail-biting, action-filled, overall great fantasy novel.

031606792X|3.0|Twilight was definitely my favorite.  New Moon and Eclipse went in a direction that I didn't particularly like, but I was still excited to read Breaking Dawn and finally have the love story resolved.      Well, it was certainly resolved.  I've been reading what others have written and I agree with much that has been said.  I honestly had no preconceived expectations and therefore was not as disappointed as some other readers.      There was not much of a love story in this book.  I just didn't feel the magic was there between Bella and Edward.  I frankly don't care about Bella having a baby with a vampire - it's Stephenie Meyers' story and I just read it - but I thought it was a little fantastical for the baby to grow SO darn quickly and just about kill Bella while she (of course) acts overwhelmingly immature and self-sacrificial.  And why the heck did she have so many dreams about a baby boy if it was going to turn out a girl?    The baby's name didn't bother me - and even Jacob imprinting on the baby didn't bother me as it was introduced previously with Quill.  I did think (to agree with some other readers) that it was a little too nicely wrapped up.  So Jacob can't have Bella?  Well, let's just let him have her daughter when she's all grown up.  I actually really liked the baby.  The way she was described was very sweet and likable. It wasn't explained though as to why the baby only liked blood, even though it was part human and had a beating heart...shouldn't she need SOME human sustenance?    The last section of the book was the best in my opinion.  Bella had been so whiny and grating and self-sacrificing for SO LONG.  FINALLY, she had some redeeming quality about her - she was MADE to be a vampire.  I liked that she took to it so well.  The story would also have been good if she had had more trouble as a newborn - but with so many storylines already, that would have muddled the book even more - better to simplify the story so that Bella only has to hunt like maybe one time.  ;-)  I thought her power was a good power.  I mean, she's not going to suddenly have some super weird new power.  The shield thing was a natural extension of who she already was.      Several people are upset about this book because Bella is married at 18, has a baby at 18, etc. and they're complaining about what kind of message Stephenie Meyers is sending young girls...well, just remember, Stephenie Meyers is of a particular religion that tends to marry and reproduce young anyway.  I don't think she was consciously trying to send some message to young girls that you should depend on a man, etc.  I think it's just so commmonplace in her life experience that she probably didn't realize how some people would feel about that kind of plotline.    All in all, it was a good book.  Not my favorite, but it ended the series in it's way.

When his neighbor's poodle is found murdered by pitchfork one morning, Chris is almost blamed for the crime and decides to find out who the real dog killer is.      I flew through this book in less than 24 hours because it was just that good of a read.

031606792X|1.0|First I'd like to say I'm 27 & I've loved every second of the first 3 books.  Now I'd like to say ARE YOU KIDDING ME??? 031606792X|1.0|This has to be the single greatest letdown in literary series history. But this hunk of junk - I can't even call it a \\"book\\" - is TERRIBLE. I was disappointed by HP6, but that sentiment was a grain of sand compared to the absolute landslide of indignation I'm bubbling with now.    I'm pissed she ruined a decent series. I'm insulted that she thinks so little of us that she had the audacity to publish something like this and assume we'd all love it. I'm heartbroken that I'll never get to obsess over it again, because it was fun and mindless and took me away from reality to some never-land with fictional creatures and improbable romance. I know this all sounds melodramatic, but I'm young and have a tendency to become totally immersed in book series.    This is horriffic. It's almost surreal, it's so awful. The entire novel's basically about sex and childbirth. I thought we were going to have a decent romance novel free from details like that? She completely avoided subjects like that before, including the topic of Bella's - y'know - only to haul them right out into the open. \\"PMS\\"? \\"Stud service\\"? \\"Lingere\\"? I never thought I would be subjected to those terms, or all that accompany them, in this relatively innocuous series. This is not what I signed up for. Everything was just TOO MUCH. I understand teenagers are hormonal, but the details were just too - graphic. The wrong ones. I literally got queasy about an eighth of the way in. How could she do this, knowing all those small girls would be reading?    I'm not going to see the movie, or have anything else to do with the series. This one ruined the entire thing, and I was embarrassingly obsessed. I can't even go re-read Twilight for the zillionth time because I know what's coming, and it literally makes my skin crawl. The whole \\"imprinting\\" thing has a vaguely incestuous overtone to it that makes me squirm. The honeymoon was ridiculous and too much about consummation.    I have a very high tolerance for questionable material. One of my favorite books ever, second only to Wilde's Dorian Grey, was Hannibal - and I loved Harris' ending (the book was radically different than the movie, to clue in the unenlightened). But this is just disgusting.     Every single character except Jacob acts like a zombie... it's like Invasion of the Body Snatchers. Were it not for the names, you wouldn't recognize anybody.    It's not a letdown. It's a flat-out HORRIBLE book, in and of itself, considered independently of expectation. It's worse than fanfiction I would roll my eyes at.    What psychopath editor allowed this cacophony of half-baked idiocy to get published? What was Meyer thinking??     Am I dreaming? Will someone PLEASE kick me into consciousness?    Is this some elaborate joke? Is the real book coming out next month?    Have I been Punk'd?
