B00008YJH5|5.0|The 80s was for the most part, a horrible decade for music.  But as you look closer you find that the underground was where all the truly great music was.  Groups like Fang, The Replacements, NWA, Public Enemy, and Husker Du pushing against the mainstream Warrant, Bon Jovi, Wham..etc.  The Pixies were of course in the brilliant rather than the popular, which seemed to happen with many underground great bands, and never completely came up to the surface (Except for developing a huge cult following).    Everything you have heard about this album is deserved.  Abrasive as the most hardcore songs on Husker Du's Zen Arcade (\\"Pride\\", \\"I'll Never Forget You\\"), yet with a small allowance of melody.  It makes sense that Steve Albini from Big Black would be willing to produce the band, because this music is intense.    Now, while I prefer the Pixie's second full release Doolittle for songs, Doolittle is essentially the same album with catchier melodies, and Surfer Rosa is nothing if not raw.  Listening to the album is a lot like having toasters thrown at you while you ride your bike down the street: It's exhilarating but you wouldn't want to do it all day long.     On to the actual songs.  One of the two best songs Kim Deal ever wrote is here in \\"Gigantic\\", while her other best is now featured on VH1 countdowns, go figure.  \\"Bone Machine\\", \\"Break My Body\\", \\"Broken Face\\", and \\"Vamos\\" are all brilliant intense songs, but \\"Where Is My Mind?\\" is the climax here and maybe the best song the Pixies ever wrote.    If you're going to get into Pixies, I wouldn't recommend diving headfirst into Surfer Rosa, Doolittle is much easier the first time around.  But while Doolittle is their most melodic and fun album, Surfer Rosa is by far their most intense and one of the greatest albums of the 80s.
0812974611|5.0|Robert Harris does a terrific job with this book.  It's filled with suspense and fascinating historical details.
031606792X|1.0|Goodness, where to even start?  I am 30 years old and I have been an avid fan of Stephenie Meyer since she was first published.        Breaking Dawn on it's own is a fantastic book - if analyzed completely separate from the rest of the Twilight series. BUT I believe that many fans will be severely disappointed (as I was) with the final book for the following reasons, which is the reason why I gave it a 1 star rating (I am sooo sorry, Stephenie):      1.  The tempo of the book is off. Stephenie's writing style is pleasantly rambling with beautiful descriptions of scenery, emotions and action in Twilight, New Moon and Eclipse.  Instead, Breaking Dawn felt like she was trying to fit 2,000 pages of material into 800 pages (which she probably was).  It would have been better to have allowed this complicated (and mature plot line) to have unfolded over two or more books instead.  Too much happened too soon (imagine books 5, 6, and 7 of Harry Potter all being crammed into one book - it would have been HORRIBLE, non-sensical and irritating).      2. The themes of the book take a sudden mature turn (i.e. this is not a YA novel).  We were all warned that Book 7 of Harry Potter was more mature and we felt it coming.  We were warmed up to the complicated themes of love, death and destruction through the series.  I am SHOCKED that Little Brown did not warn readers of the mature themes in this book.  Sex, Sex, Sex, pregnancy, vomiting fountains of blood and infantile imprinting.  I'm not saying it isn't a great story line, I was just shocked by it because it does not mesh well with the first three books.       I laughed when I accidently came across some spoilers on Amazon on August 1st and almost posted how silly people were for believing \\"fake\\" spoilers that were so obviously taken from a fan fiction site - to my horror, as I read, I discovered they were real spoilers.      While I was standing in line to buy my book yesterday morning I got into a conversation with a father inline behind me buying two copies of the book for his young daughters (probably 11 and 12).  Now that I have finished the book, I wish I could rewind time and WARN him that this is ABSOLUTELY NOT a young adult novel.  It contains VASTLY more mature content than Stephenie's supposid first adult novel The Host (which was excellent).  This book contains seriously mature themes (sex, violence, teen pregnancy - sorry, guys, I don't care if she's married) and I would not recommend it for teens under 15, personally.  And even then...    3.  Poor, poor Twilight Moms.  One of the reasons why I LOVED this series was because of Stephenie's gift for \\"the tease.\\"  She created beautiful characters with a beautiful, passionate, and strangely realistic relationships that were defined by emotion, BEFORE physical intimacy.  True love.  Realistic?  I don't know.  But we all wanted to believe that it was possible for two individuals to be completely head over heels in love without ever being able to express it with more than a peck.  This is classic old world romance in a modern day form.  And gosh, what a fantastic example for youth today!  Did we all know that Bella and Edward would eventually find a way to consummate their relationship?  Well, yeah, but the story before that was so much more interesting and fulfilling, especially in a world that already revolves so much around sex.  So I felt cheated when it finally did happen, regardless that marriage was involved.  And pregnancy at 18, even if you are married, is just not cool.  Sorry.  That's my personal view, but I don't think I'll be alone.     4.  Inconsistencies - Stephenie bends the rules of the Twilight universe to attempt to give everyone a happy ending.  Ugh.  I'm not going to go into detail, but beautiful themes in the first three books (like the  emergence of the werewolves in New Moon and the love triangle and Victoria's revenge in Eclipse) were planted and cultivated in the previous books.  But vampires have no bodilyfluids other than their venom - they can't cry but they can produce... ahem, fluids to make children?  And yet those fluids don't contain vampire venom?  Uhm... sorry that's too much of a stretch.  Themes in Breaking Dawn were sudden, unexpected and though some fit (Jacob's imprinting was made \\"realistic\\" by being foreshadowed by Quil and Claire in Eclispe), but were just plain weird.                I will attempt to pretend the series ended with Eclipse and try to forget this craziness so that I can fully enjoy the Twilight movie when it comes out in December.  I hate to say it but I wish I had stopped at Eclipse and imagined my own conclusions to Bella's fate and resolutions with these beloved characters.
031606792X|1.0|Fans of the series are often very emotional about this book, and rightly so.  It is a magical thiing when an author can create a \\"universe\\" that the reader can step into.  But after all, it is a work of fiction and I would like to comment on the book from that standpoint.    Good writing has a consistent voice throughout a book(s), the voice of this trilogy has been Bella's.  I Breaking Dawn there are varied voices which causes the storyline to feel disjointed.  Unresolved conflicts are played out in scenarios outside the realm of the Twilight universe leaving the reader feeling there isn't real closure.  Many of the details are downright laughable and one has to wonder if someone other than Mrs. Meyer had a hand in writing the book because it ventures so far from the storyline throughout the trilogy.  Mrs. Meyer's skill at maintaing a balance of tension and excitement was not present is this book.    Like many books with much loved characters and skillful writing, one anticipates that the author will stay true to his/her writing style.  This reader felt a sense of loss and with disappointment with Breaking Dawn because the book is so very altered from the previous books.  I have donated my book to our local library and have chosen to leave the trilogy to stand on its own.  Breaking Dawn only tarnishes a memorable story.
031606792X|1.0|Just as a warning- there will be spoilers in here. And there will also likely be lots of incoherent sentences.     I need to vent. I can't help myself. Let's begin with the wedding. Everyone thought it was going to be such a big deal and that it would pretty much be the main point in the book. But no. The event we all have been highly anticipating happened within the first 50 or so pages in the book.     Then she gets pregnant. Pregnant. That's right- pregnant. I heard the rumors, saw the spoilers, even accidentally came across some of the scanned chapters, but I still didn't believe. I thought there was no way that Stephenie Meyer would have Bella, the girl who practically raised her mother and who cringed at the thought of marriage, get pregnant. Then she gets pregnant and she freaks out for a second. Um, let me tell you- I'm 18 and I'd have a heart attack, perfect vampire husband or no. I know the whole point is that Bella is always strong and doing what no one expects but PLEASE. Then there was the whole \\"all bodily fluids are replaced with venom, sperm dies, vampires can't have babies...\\" SM quote that people kept coming up with on the spoiler messageboards. What happened to that? I snorted, audibly, at the section of the book that explains this away. Correction- tries to explain it away. I read fanfictions that talked about this and every time, I xed them out because I thought it was ludicrous. I don't have to tell you my devastation when I realized that this would be central to the book.     I understand why SM decided to have a Jacob POV section, though I didn't like it. I got that we had to see things from this angle for the story. But did there have to be SO much? I put it down so many times through that. This is BELLA & EDWARD's story (even though that seems hard to believe a lot of the time).     Edward. I know it sounds silly but I feel like he was barely in it. I feel like none of the characters were really IN it. They all seemed miles away from who they were by the end of Eclipse. Alice, one of my favorite characters, felt really far away. I felt like Bella & Edward's love story got lost somewhere and then every once in a while SM would go \\"oh, let me pop in a significant glance!\\" They had fleeting romantic scenes, but most of them failed to ignite the spark that the others in the series had (and those were more chaste, for goodness sakes!). Ch 20 in Eclipse lives on.    Then Bella's shield. First of all, it annoys me that throughout the series, various obstacles have been placed before the characters that they stress over the entire book and yet, in the end, nothing happens. At all. Twilight was the only one where a little something happened- Bella gets attacked. New Moon was okay in the drama department. Then Eclipse comes along and the scene with Victoria happens in about two pages after all the hype. Then in this book we finally see the Volturi again, the threat that has been hovering over everyone since New Moon. What happens in the end? Nothing. They retreat. Aro apologizes for bothering them. Though the book ends on a note that things might not be completely over with the Volturi, we won't ever see that.     Now for Jacob's imprinting. All I can say on this is why? I've read the other reviews that have talked about this so I feel like there's nothing more to be said on this subject. One word will suffice- ABSURD. Oh, and WRONG.    The thing that really disappointed me the most, and that I already mentioned, is that I felt like we didn't get much time to spend with Bella & Edward as they once were. I felt like I was dealing with two different characters entirely, though some characteristics were still there. It was just weird.    I've heard people complain that the message SM sends out is all wrong but I never really paid attention to it until now. Sure, at times when reading the series I'd ask myself, \\"Doesn't this girl have any other interests besides Edward?\\" but then I'd remind myself Edward was a godand that, had I been in her shoes, I'd probably be pretty dazzled myself. But still. No one in real life is as perfect as Edward. Then, when I read this book, I finally got what people were talking about. Bella doesn't even mention college after she's changed. She has no other interests or desires other than Edward and her child now. I get the love and the bond and the inexplicable feelings that come along with that but I can't help but feel bad she has nothing to herself. It actually sends out a really bad message, especially in today's world. Edward is consumed with his love but he still has some hobbies, like his music.    Enough rambling. All I really wanted to say was that I was very upset all of my anxious waiting was for nothing. The disappointment I felt when I realized all of those horrific spoilers were true was acute. I can understand now when people spoke of boycotting it and now, I only wish I had followed in their example. My memory of the series is marred now and I'll think of my own ending after Eclipse. I'm happy there was a happily-ever-after but I couldn't feel anything at that point for the characters. They just didn't feel the same to me. Anything would be better than this- even fanfiction.

0670020745|4.0|I debated over whether to give this book three, four, or five stars.  The information that Dr. Taylor presents about the brain and stroke is worth five stars, without question.  But I have a few complaints about how she presents this information; and lots of complaints about the \\"self-help\\" aspects of this book.  I almost wish I could post two reviews of this book -- a five-star review for the information about the brain and stroke; and a two-star review for everything else about the book.  I ended up giving the book a (somewhat charitable) compromise rating of four stars (but in some ways the four star rating is too low; and in others it is way too high).<br /><br />Let's start with the positives:  This book is a must-read for anyone who is interested in the human brain and how it functions, any health care professional or caregiver who deals with stroke patients, anyone who has a friend or family member who has had a stroke, and anyone who is concerned about the possibility that they might someday suffer from a stroke (a statistical possibility, since about 700,000 Americans will have a stroke this year).  If you want to know about what it's like to have a stroke and to recover from it, this is the book to read.  Dr. Taylor is a brain scientist who had a stroke and lived to tell her story of survival, recovery, and rehabilitation.  The information she provides about her personal experience is priceless for anyone who wants to better understand what happens when someone has a stroke, and what is needed for recovery and rehabilitation.  This information is also of extreme value for anyone who wants to better understand how the brain works to make us who we are.  Five stars for the information on the brain and stroke.<br /><br />But now I must deal with the negatives, and comment on the \\"two-star\\" aspects of this book.  First of all, the writing style is a bit amateurish; but we can excuse Dr. Taylor for that, since she's a brain scientist, not a professional writer.But I do have a bit of a problem with how she tells her story.  What bothers me about her account is her description of what was going on in her mind while she was having the stroke and during her recovery.  She describes herself as having certain thoughts that just don't seem plausible given her description of the mental impairments she was suffering at the time.  She makes a point of saying that the language centers of her left cerebral cortex had been impaired, silencing the inner voice in her head, leaving her mind in a state of peaceful quiet.  Yet she goes on to describe thoughts that were running through her mind.  (How could she have such thoughts without that inner voice?)  I got the feeling that she was actually describing the thoughts that went through her mind years later as she was recalling her stroke experience.  (But, given the fact that our minds actually \\"construct\\" our memories as we reflect on our past experiences rather than simply recording our experiences and playing them back for us with perfect accuracy, this sort of thing is to be expected.)<br /><br />But what really annoyed me about this book was that, in the last few chapters, it turned into a sappy, shallow, self-help book of the \\"learn-to-love-yourself-and-think-happy-thoughts\\" variety; and includes what has to be the single corniest sentence ever written in the English language:  \\"When my bowels move, I cheer my cells for clearing that waste out of my body.\\" (p. 156)  In these later chapters, the book even delves into \\"New Age\\" stuff like \\"energy dynamics\\", Feng Shui, and \\"Angel Cards\\".  I felt that this seriously compromised the integrity of the valuable information that Dr. Taylor presented about brain science and stroke recovery.  This information is so valuable that I would still recommend the book in spite of its many shortcomings; but I would encourage you to take the last few chapters of the book with a grain of salt.
B001AZI1PA|5.0|Whenever you think of Jim Henson's Muppets, the fuzzy kooky variety shows and entertaining adventures of Miss Piggy, Gonzo and Kermit the Frog come to mind.<br /><br />But these versatile puppets have been used for far more dramatic effects in \\"The Dark Crystal,\\" an exquisite little fantasy story that happens to be entirely populated by puppets. Not a live person in sight, from start to finish. Henson and Brian Froud conjured up a gloriously detailed world -- full of fantastical flora and fauna, crystalline castles and strange creatures -- and wrapped it around a solid coming-of-age story.<br /><br />On another world, there are two strange races that appeared one thouysand years ago -- the enormous, gentle, peaceful Mystics, and the nasty, vulture-like, vicious Skekses who ruin the surrounding lands. Both races are somehow connected to a massive crystal that was broken a thousand years ago, and now a shard is missing from it. What's more, three suns are about to come into conjunction, and the shard has to be back in place when that happens.<br /><br />The Mystics have cared for one of the last Gelflings, an orphan named Jen whom they rescued from the insectile Garthim. As the conjunction approaches, they send him out to find the lost shard. Along the way, Jen gains the crystal shard for himself, and meets the only other living Gelfling, Kira. Now they must both evade the Skekses' Garthim henchmen and bat-winged spies, and somehow infiltrate their castle. But what will happen when the suns line up, and the crystal is completed?<br /><br />Many fantasy movies slap together a story that has been told many times before, but increasingly without interest -- throw in swords, some monsters, a brave prince or farm boy, and some evil witch/queen/wizard/Dark Lord. But fortunately nothing is so simple in \\"The Dark Crystal\\" -- although the origins of the Skekses and Mystics are pretty obvious from the very start of the movie, the journey along with Jen is what really makes this interesting.<br /><br />Instead of some pan-medieval land, \\"The Dark Crystal\\" aims at portraying a truly alien world, and Brian Froud's slightly weird designs make it seem so -- strange swamp reptiles, colorful anemones, vast crystalline castles, desiccated vulture-like creature, shrieking fuzzballs, and gorgeous forests full of strange plants and animals that tend to move and act in unique ways. \\"The Dark Crystal\\" leaves you feeling like you've been transported to some other planet.<br /><br />Additionally, this film also has the honor of being the first major movie to entirely star puppets, with nary a human being in sight -- some of those puppets still walk in a herky-jerky Muppet manner, but their design is utterly detailed and believable, from Jen's sort-of-human, fawnlike features to the vast four-armed Mystics, and the rattling armored Garthim soldiers. And the special effects end up being pretty spectacular, especially during the chaotic literally earthshattering climax -- while the finale is rather predictable, it is no less awe-inspiring for that.<br /><br />At times it feels like the characterization gets a backseat to the movie's visuals, but Jen and fellow Gelfling orphan Kira are fairly likable, naive young heroes who develop a cute little romance throughout the story. The various Skekses are given individual quirks and personalities (such as the annoying Chamberlain who won't stop humming).  Not to mention the abrasive, lumpy witch Aughra, who's an absolute riot (\\"Whole world might burn up... hmph... end of Augra!\\") and Kira's toothy fuzzball Fizzgig.<br /><br />\\"The Dark Crystal\\" has some predictable plot twists, but it is also a glorious visual feast and a coming-of-age journey with the Gelflings, leading to a finale both awe-inspiring and bittersweet. Definitely a must-see.me pan-medieval land, \\"The Dark Crystal\\" aims at portraying a truly alien world, and Brian Froud's slightly weird designs make it seem so -- strange swamp reptiles, colorful anemones, vast crystalline castles, desiccated vulture-like creature, shrieking fuzzballs, and gorgeous forests full of strange plants and animals that tend to move and act in unique ways. \\"The Dark Crystal\\" leaves you feeling like you've been transported to some other planet.    Additionally, this film also has the honor of being the first major movie to entirely star puppets, with nary a human being in sight -- some of those puppets still walk in a herky-jerky Muppet manner, but their design is utterly detailed and believable, from Jen's sort-of-human, fawnlike features to the vast four-armed Mystics, and the rattling armored Garthim soldiers. And the special effects end up being pretty spectacular, especially during the chaotic literally earthshattering climax -- while the finale is rather predictable, it is no less awe-inspiring for that.    At times it feels like the characterization gets a backseat to the movie's visuals, but Jen and fellow Gelfling orphan Kira are fairly likable, naive young heroes who develop a cute little romance throughout the story. The various Skekses are given individual quirks and personalities (such as the annoying Chamberlain who won't stop humming).  Not to mention the abrasive, lumpy witch Aughra, who's an absolute riot (\\"Whole world might burn up... hmph... end of Augra!\\") and Kira's toothy fuzzball Fizzgig.    \\"The Dark Crystal\\" has some predictable plot twists, but it is also a glorious visual feast and a coming-of-age journey with the Gelflings, leading to a finale both awe-inspiring and bittersweet. Definitely a must-see.
0143038419|4.0|This is a story of a woman who after going through a messy divorce and an even messier affair decides she needs to find out who she really is. When the story started she never really seemed to know who she is and what makes her happy, so she comes up with an idea to travel for a year and discover herself in the process. She spends her year traveling equally among Italy, India, and Indonesia. In Italy, she spends most of her time eating and making friends. While in India, she spends most of her time in various forms of meditation and prayer. When she finally makes her way to Bali she is looking for balance, but she ends up finding love. While I can see where she has grown and has become more comfortable with who she is in the end, she seemed to spend a lot of time in all three locations engaged in excessive behaviors no real balance. It took me a little while to get into the story, I really wanted to like it and found it to be a decent little story.
0321544080|4.0|Mr. Steffens makes a number of very solid points in his thoughtful review of this book, and I would certainly caution potential readers to take note of what he is saying as I was hoping for more direct insight in terms of how to recreate some of the truly amazing photos that Mr. McNally has captured over the years.  If you are looking for a point by point instruction set on how to pose a subject, or exactly where to place lighting (in more than general terms), this is probably not the book for you.  That said, I still give the book high marks.  There is plenty of information that is useful for the experienced photographer about how to make some informed decisions when working on an assignment.  The work presented is certainly inspirational, and it's hard to imagine a step-by-step guide from a photographer who has had worked with any number of celebrities and captured award winning images.  The vast majority of photographers simply are not going to find themselves presented with many of the types of work that Joe has encountered (we can always dream though).  I still recommend that anyone who wants to learn more about Joe's work pick up this book, both for a source of inspiration and instruction.

B000001GQH|3.0|If not for the excellent recordings of \\"La Mer\\" and \\"Bolero\\" (both worthy of 5 stars) this would be a one star review.  The trumpet playing in \\"Pictures\\" is unacceptable by modern standards.  The \\"Samuel Goldenberg\\" track is particularly bad.  It is poorly articulated and out of tune.  For reasons I can't explain, continental orchestras of this period lagged far behind their British and American counterparts in the area of brass playing.  You should still buy this recording for \\"La Mer\\" and \\"Bolero,\\" but look elsewhere for \\"Pictures.\\"  Better choices include (but are by no means limited to) Szell/Cleveland, Reiner/Chicago, and even Mata/Dallas.  Karajan's earlier recording with the Philharmonia Orchestra is far superior to this offering on DG, and offers excellent brass playing throughout.  It is available as part of the \\"Karajan 100th\\" box on EMI.

Not a very challenging read but engaging and simple and interesting.  What I didn't expect was a published mess of fanfiction.    (Spoilers follow)    First I have to say that the character that she developed through Twilight, New Moon, and Eclipse were for the most part gone. Not only were they missing, in their place were characters straight out of a nightmare of a fanfiction.  Bella was much too nervous in the first book. Much too stupid in the second, and totally unbelievable in the third. Edward was somehow blind to these dramatic changes and continued to be overbearing (and I love Edward, but come on). Jacob seemed relatively sane. Until he imprinted on Bella's child. And then pretty much everything went to hell.    Breaking Dawn not only set a poor example for young girls, it also made me really creeped out. I didn't have a big problem with the whole imprinting on a child thing. Not only did Bella risk her life for what could have been a monster, (Which turned out to be a very very very badly named freak) but then after she was allowed to see her and hold her she didn't seem like a mother. Only like a babysitter. She seemed to be more focused on Edward than she was on her child, more concerned with having sex with Edward than with being a mother. In my eyes that's wrong.    The plot also lacked any originality (I was surprised to see immortal children, an idea that I had first read about in Interview With A Vampire by Ann Rice, even though those immortal children mentally aged, and I'm sure that that was a concept that already existed). The whole pregnancy disaster at first stuck me as a joke, in fact when I saw a spoiler that said Bella was pregnant, I didn't believe it. Boy was I wrong.  It seemed to me that Ms. Meyers paid a little too much attention to fanfiction and forgot that there is a lot of it that's filled with very very bad ideas.  This whole book was something out of a terrible sci-fi paperback.    I have to say that I am greatly disappointed. If I had wanted 754 pages of fanfiction I would have stayed online and not bothered wasting my money.    I'm forced to wish the series had been ended with Eclipse as to avoid the disappointment of having an (up to this book) solid series.

031606792X|2.0|**SPOILERS**    I found this to be an interesting read, but I was ultimately disappointed with the conclusion.  The entire series has played up the sacrifices Bella would need to make if she became a vampire: her family, her ability to have children, possibly her soul, etc.  Bella's relationship with Jacob showed how difficult and poignant this choice could be: she could see her future with Jacob, and part of her wanted that future.  But ultimately, she makes the choice to be with Edward and sacrifice everything.    But as it ends up, Bella sacrifices NOTHING for her choice.  She conveniently becomes pregnant before she is turned, Charlie is told--more or less--about her condition, and Jacob can still be a part of her life in a purely platonic sense.  All in all, the book seemed very anti-climatic. I didn't mind the idea of him imprinting on a baby--when Quil did the same thing in \\"Eclipse,\\" it was explained that those relationships remained purely platonic until the child came of age. Bella and Jacob were in love, and it was visibly painful for them to be around one another after she chose Edward. 031606792X|2.0|As the final book in the Twilight series comes to and end, I can't help BUT to say, HORRAY! The series itself has been over hyped, and therefore disappointing more and more, however, this book, hits a whole new level.  Without going into the 'substance' of the book, the author manages to change the beloved Isbella Swan, to a stupid girl who enjoys sex more then her own existence, Edward Cullen, to a self-loathe pity-party of a person who keeps on having relations with the aforementioned girl even through the bruises, and basically, changing the whole story from a romantic RELATABLE tale, to a supernatural freakfest, that comes off feeling rather cheap, and boring. The only shining beacon from the book is when it's written from Jacob Black's perspective, but even then, she manages to erase all of the progress he made as a character, and make him cheap and dull as all of the other characters in her book within one page. Simply to put it, Stephenie Meyer has ended up erasing all that we've come to enjoy from the characters, and turned them into shells of their former selves. With all of that being said, the only saving grace in this book is, at it's core, the mythology of the Vampires and the Werewolves, which helps this story become somewhat passable. For anybody who needs something to pass the time, then this book is perfect. However, to the fans who've followed the series for a long time, I feel that they won't enjoy the book at all, and even more so, I feel that she should've ended it at Eclipse.
0394800192|4.0|Three animals compete in the first half of the book to see who can have the most apples on top of their head. During the second half of the book, they escape an angry mob, happily collide with an apple truck, and end up giving the entire town ten apples on their heads as well. (What fun! Ten apples up on top! We are not going to let them drop!)    This is a good book both for early readers, and for young children learning to talk. Very simple, rhyming vocabulary, of the sort with intuitive spellings (so much of English orthography is a mess...!)    Please note that I do not recommend the board book version at all. They cut out the entire second half of the book, as well as good parts of the first half. In addition, the board book is poorly constructed. Just wait and get the real version instead.

0064430227|4.0|One night, the self-reliant Harold couldn't sleep, so he decided to go for a walk in the moonlight.    Using his crayon, he makes everything he needs - including the moon. He gets himself into accidental trouble with his crayon (accidentally making a sea, not making the second half of a mountain, making a city full of windows to get lost in), but he always manages to save himself with the same crayon (making a boat, a hot air balloon, and finally his own window \\"right around the moon\\").    He even puts himself to bed at the end, knowing he's tired.    Who wouldn't want a kid as independent and responsible as this kid?    It's truly a fantastic book, and you should definitely not ignore it.
031606792X|4.0|***An update 6 years later***<br /><br />I have friends who are talented singers, but I hate sitting next to them during someone else's performance. They can hear all the flaws in the music and can't help cringing or grimacing at the performer. Not being musically inclined myself, I can usually listen with enjoyment even if someone is hitting the notes a bit flat.<br /><br />This is sort of how I've come to feel about Twilight.<br /><br />When I discovered the series, three books had already been written.  I was pregnant and sick and blew threw them pretty quickly.  I was able to suspend disbelief and just read on auto-pilot, not really stopping to deeply consider the writing itself or any of the plot devices.  I had to wait a bit for book 4, and then read it straight through in a few hours, again, largely on autopilot (and still sick and pregnant, btw).<br /><br />Since then, I've been studying grammar and writing and the things I'm learning (still have a long way to go myself) have opened my eyes and have made reading a little less enjoyable than it used to be.  I've actually discarded and abandoned books when the errors and weaknesses started to get in the way of the story; something I'd never experienced before.  I'm certain that if I went back and read Meyer's books today I would have this same problem.<br /><br />I can already appreciate more of the critics' points:  Bella is a bit empty-headed and vapid, her obsession with Edward (at cost of all other interests: friends, college, etc) is pretty unhealthy, Edward is controlling and kind of awful, and Bella getting everything in the end makes her a Mary Sue character.  I also recently read an entertaining blog called &#34;Reasoning with Vampires&#34; that highlights hundreds of grammar mistakes and writing problems from Meyer's books.  The blog is harsh and sometimes overly critical, but I did find it really interesting and I learned a lot.<br /><br />I also read something interesting by the woman who worked as the continuity editor on the Harry Potter books.  She talks about the important notes a book needs to hit to, well, be a hit.  Characterization, plot development, etc... but notes that if a book hits just one thing really well such as 'emotion' it can find an audience despite the flaws in the other categories.  She says this basically sums up Twilight.  It made a lot of sense to me, because I certainly was able to get caught up in the emotion of it and either not see or ignore the other problems.<br /><br />All that said, if these books hadn't seen such immense commercial success, they wouldn't have come under such close scrutiny, either.  I guess to sum up this update:  I can better understand where the critics are coming from, but I still admire the sheer accomplishment of having written a complete novel, let alone four, and don't begrudge Stephenie Meyer her success.  It will be interesting to see if she'll be able to filter through the vitriol and improve her writing over time.  I'll likely read whatever she serves up next.<br /><br />*** Original review below ***<br /><br />Reading all these one star reviews is totally killing my post Breaking Dawn buzz, y'all.<br /><br />--Please note:  this review contains spoilers, as most of the reviews here do.<br /><br />Bella's happily ever after is heart warming and tidy just like any other fairy tale you might enjoy from childhood, though with quite a bit more blood and (fade-to-black married) sex.  Many of these one star reviews criticize the happy ending, the early marriage, and motherhood in place of a college education, among various other complaints.  I'm suspecting these reviewers would be much happier with an independent Bella who marches off in her human form to get a Masters degree in Psychology before marrying Edward.  Or heck, not marrying Edward at all, and eschewing the idea of something so base and demeaning as becoming a wife or parent.  Though perhaps it's more the youth of the heroine that causes their lament.<br /><br />I however, like happy endings and am thrilled she gets to be a mother.  Many people I spoke to who were in &#34;Camp Jacob&#34; expressed their reason:  &#34;Because she could have a family with Jacob&#34;.  Well, surprise; she had a family with Edward.<br /><br />Yes, Jacob imprints on Bella's daughter, but because imprinting on babies/children had previously been introduced in the series, I didn't find this unsettling, a bit weird, yes, but not perverted or anything.  All this shouting about pedophilia is a little... intense for what really happens. Jacob makes it clear that it isn't a sexual thing at all while the object the affection is still so young.  Jacob imprinting on &#34;Nessie&#34; means they all stay a family, which is what Bella wanted all along.<br /><br />Which brings me to another common complaint:  Bella gets everything.  Goodness!  After fighting for it, tooth and nail, yes, she does.  Isn't that what makes most of us smile at the end of Cinderella?<br /><br />Some have suggested that having Jacob imprint on someone else would allow Bella to make a sacrifice by finally fully letting him go as well as remove that feeling some reviewers have that she gets everything.  I do see this point, and perhaps this happening would have made it a more critically acclaimed book, but as I was reading the story, I was fully involved in watching Bella's story unfold and these things did not negate my enjoyment of the book.<br /><br />As for the complaint that Bella should have gone to college first -- she has the rest of eternity to obtain as many degrees as she wants. So... shrug?<br /><br />For those worried about the impact this book may have on impressionable young teen fans, if you're allowing them to read the books at all (I know some parents aren't), why don't you read the book along with them and talk about the real life application of Bella's choices?  Of whether or not an extremely intense relationship with a vampire who watches you while you sleep would be a good idea in real life?  Sounds like a great excuse for some good conversation.<br /><br />One complaint I completely agree with: Bella names her daughter Renesmee, which is hard to read, hard to pronounce, and impossible to spell.  I'm amazed that made it past the editors.  I also found the ending anti-climactic; there really should have been a battle scene.<br /><br />Critics argue that you can't shout &#34;But it's fantasy&#34; to cover gaping plot holes.  Perhaps to a more critical, serious eye, plot holes exist and are bothersome.  But I truly was lost in Bella's story and as I read, very little jumped out as completely unreal or impossible to me.  I thoroughly enjoyed the book and consider this rating a 4.5 stars.<br /><br />Stephenie Meyer has been able to create characters that feel real.  I was able to lose myself in the story through all four books. While the first in the series is the best in my opinion, the characters remained almost tangible people that I cared about and rooted for throughout.<br /><br />Stephenie admitted herself that pleasing all of her fans would be impossible, but insisted that this was the story she wanted to write all along.  I've been a happy voyeur for the ride, and remain a happy fan.o were in &#34;Camp Jacob&#34; expressed their reason:  &#34;Because she could have a family with Jacob&#34;.  Well, surprise; she had a family with Edward.  Yes, Jacob imprints on Bella's daughter, but because imprinting on babies/children had previously been introduced in the series, I didn't find this unsettling, a bit weird, yes, but not perverted or anything.  All this shouting about pedophilia is a little... intense for what really happens. Jacob makes it clear that it isn't a sexual thing at all while the object the affection is still so young.  Jacob imprinting on &#34;Nessie&#34; means they all stay a family, which is what Bella wanted all along.  Which brings me to another common complaint:  Bella gets everything.  Goodness!  After fighting for it, tooth and nail, yes, she does.  Isn't that what makes most of us smile at the end of Cinderella?  Some have suggested that having Jacob imprint on someone else would allow Bella to make a sacrifice by finally fully letting him go as well as remove that feeling some reviewers have that she gets everything.  I do see this point, and perhaps this happening would have made it a more critically acclaimed book, but as I was reading the story, I was fully involved in watching Bella's story unfold and these things did not negate my enjoyment of the book.  As for the complaint that Bella should have gone to college first -- she has the rest of eternity to obtain as many degrees as she wants. So... shrug?  For those worried about the impact this book may have on impressionable young teen fans, if you're allowing them to read the books at all (I know some parents aren't), why don't you read the book along with them and talk about the real life application of Bella's choices?  Of whether or not an extremely intense relationship with a vampire who watches you while you sleep would be a good idea in real life?  Sounds like a great excuse for some good conversation.  One complaint I completely agree with: Bella names her daughter Renesmee, which is hard to read, hard to pronounce, and impossible to spell.  I'm amazed that made it past the editors.  I also found the ending anti-climactic; there really should have been a battle scene.  Critics argue that you can't shout &#34;But it's fantasy&#34; to cover gaping plot holes.  Perhaps to a more critical, serious eye, plot holes exist and are bothersome.  But I truly was lost in Bella's story and as I read, very little jumped out as completely unreal or impossible to me.  I thoroughly enjoyed the book and consider this rating a 4.5 stars.  Stephenie Meyer has been able to create characters that feel real.  I was able to lose myself in the story through all four books. While the first in the series is the best in my opinion, the characters remained almost tangible people that I cared about and rooted for throughout.  Stephenie admitted herself that pleasing all of her fans would be impossible, but insisted that this was the story she wanted to write all along.  I've been a happy voyeur for the ride, and remain a happy fan.
0394806220|4.0|This book is a quick (rhyming) runthough of the wonderful sounds Mr. Brown can do, starting with the prosaic (moo, moo, choo choo) to the obscure and absurd (a \\"goldfish kiss\\" (pip!) and a \\"hippopotomus chewing gum\\" (grum, grum, grum), those are just two examples).<br /><br />This book is short, which makes it great for early readers and for toddlers learning to talk, as well as for those hurry-through-bedtime days.<br /><br />It's also really interactive, so it's terrific for group storytimes, especially with more active little kids who don't just want to sit down quietly. Every page ends with the narrator asking if you can make that noise too - and trust me, they can.

0394800389|4.0|This book is nothing more than a list of tongue twisters.    Each set of tongue twisters gets progressively harder and harder (not to mention more and more disastrous in the illustrations) until Mr. Knox throws his hands up in frustration, and it all starts over again.    Definitely read it before you read it aloud! I'd also recommend this book for the late stage of early readers - the words are just simple enough for them to actually be able to read them, while the wordplay is tricky enough to make it a really fun challenge.    There are a few minor concerns. First of all, the fox really is a nasty character, and uses language that I know some parents object to - calling Mr. Knox dumb, that sort of thing. And of course it shows some violence in the tweedle beetle battle.    This sort of thing doesn't concern me, but if it does concern you, as always, read before you buy.
031606792X|3.0|Breaking Dawn is, while a satisfactory conclusion to the story of Bella and Edward, not particularly necessary to the series overall.<br /><br />At the end of Eclipse, we were left with a hope for a promising future with Bella and Edward, and while the fact that she hadn't been bitten yet was troublesome, who truly could doubt that it would happen? With Breaking Dawn, Meyer brings us back to our favorite characters, but it wasn't such a happy reunion for me.<br /><br />I admit, that I enjoyed seeing the reaction of Charlie to Bella's wedding, and there were many revelations that enriched the story as a whole. But writing an entire novel to fit these things in seemed superfluous. Overall, I found much of the book melodramatic and slightly annoying and I believe that these things could have just as easily been incorporated into a short story or two; and would made it a much more enjoyable read.<br /><br />What Breaking Dawn lacked, compared to the other novels, was real substance and conflict. While I have never read the Twilight books for their intriguing plots (which are quite predictable at times), they still have included major dilemmas for characters I loved. There was also strong motivation for the choices the characters made, and the actions that they did. In this installment, however, all major conflict was resolved nearly within the first half of the book.<br /><br />Much of the last half of the book is spent describing preparation for a major event that ultimately amounts to nothing.<br /><br />All in all, I think that this last book was just a piece of fluff that, while it happily ends the series, was not quite necessary.
0689878451|4.0|So, let's clear it up at the start for all of you who may be shocked, shocked I say, at the content.    This is a story about a same-sex penguin couple and their adopted chick. It's a true story. This behavior is actually pretty common in the non-human world. If this disturbs you, hit the back button on your browser now.    *waits*    Okay, now, for the rest of you. There are two ways of dealing with a \\"controversial\\" topic. You can put it in the background, normalizing it, or you can make it the focus. This book chose the latter option.    I was a little worried that the text of the book might be too stuffy, because, after all, it's an \\"issues\\" book, right?    I was wrong.    It really is well-written, as just what it is - a sweet story about two penguins in love who really want a little chick of their own. It's not heavy handed, it's not overdone, it's perfect. (And, bonus, my nieces both loved pointing out the animal clock by the zoo. We stop by there every time we're in the area, because I used to stop by there with my dad. Nice connection for NYC families!)    I definitely recommend this book for anybody who is not against the message of \\"Love makes a happy family\\". (Or the other message of \\"Penguins are really cute.\\")

031606792X|2.0|Just be on alert: This review will have spoilers in it. I'll try to keep them to a minimum. Also, I would have given it 3 stars (well really 3.5 but that's not an option) but it wasn't until after I posted that I realized I clicked 2, and it cannot be changed.    Now, I am not a big fan of writing reviews, but I just couldn't pass up this opportunity. Breaking Dawn. I just don't even know how to describe what I thought of it. This book felt out of place in the series. As a book alone, it was great. Yet, it felt, I don't know, as if it were written by a different author. Or maybe it felt like it was written about different characters--characters that just seem to have the same names as the ones in the previous books of the series.     After I read Twilight, I felt like I was in a daze. The time I spent by myself driving, after reading Twilight but before I read New Moon, was consumed with everything Twilight. Edward. Edward and Bella. What the next two books, and eventually the final one, would hold. I just couldn't help reliving scenes in my head. How much love radiated from Edward. How much love Bella felt for him. It was indescribable, but Meyer did her best.    New Moon was a whole new ball park of emotions. Pain, agony, ripping, slowly healing in a new way. Then, finally, Edward was back. That made the book worth it. I looked at New Moon as a connecting book. Just something meant to pass time so that Jacob could be developed.    Then Eclipse came along. I was satisfied with the book. After all, it still has another one coming, so there are some questions that just won't be answered. Bella grew to be utterly annoying, but I got over it. Maybe she'd finally grow up. Eclipse was a great continuing story. I finished the first 3 books back to back to back and turned on my patience light while I waited for Breaking Dawn. Eager. Ridiculously eager. Can't stop thinking about these books eager. Enough so that I convinced numerous friends to read the books, just so I could talk about the series with them. Breaking Dawn couldn't get here fast enough.    And now, Breaking Dawn was finally in my hands. Maybe waiting long enough for the high to wear away had something to do with it. Maybe reading other series between the months I waited took its toll. Who am I kidding? That's not it. All I could think of while I was reading was, \\"Seriously, this book is meant to go along with this series, right?\\" Something about this book didn't fit right. I had flown through the first 3 books. Finally, another series I could get into! This book, not so much. I finished it the day after I got it, but it wasn't a can't-put-it-down-to-eat read.     I will say that the beginning seemed to flow kind of normally. I was so surprised to see that Bella choosing Edward had actually played out and in the first chapter, even! Then the book just turned weird on me. I know, I know. It a fantasy novel about a girl who falls in love with a VAMPIRE! Still, this was weird. Pregnancy from a vampire? I thought Meyer's vampires couldn't.. well... biologically.. do that. I mean, that can't even produce tears for crying out loud! (No pun intended.) Then, we have a 3rd of the story told from Jacob's POV, and all of the sudden, when it shifts back to Bella's POV, Jacob has become a background type of character! Then there is Alice, sweet bubbly Alice. She hardly gets much in this book! I missed her. Rosalie gets more say than she does. I just don't get it. The book was, well, okay. I did like it, just not as much as I wish I had. No where near as much as the other 3. I kept looking at the amount I had left to read thinking, \\"What else is going to happen? Bella is a vampire already, so what conflict is going to take place?\\" When the conflict did arrive, it wasn't much a conflict at all. More of a mind battle than a physical battle. I was glad it was somewhat unexpected. It had a happy ending, which I did appreciate. If you want a real one, go read non-fiction. The problem was,the happy ending wasn't earned. There was no sacrifice. No one had to give up anything. There was a thought of it, but that's it. Ah, well, its done now.     I can finish this book and honestly continue on as if the series was just another series I read. Not exactly a favorite, not exactly a waste of time. I am not even THINKING much about it, like I had after the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd ones. Take this as you can. Sorry the review was so long, but I had to get it all out.

031606792X|1.0|I cried, not tears of joy mind you but tears of confusion and frustration!  What happened? Did it not occur to her how it would make Edward feel when she did stuff like that with Jake? Her constant disregard for his feelings never ceased to amaze me. I wanted to scream and I wanted to slap Bella, and therefore, Stephenie. Jake is hugging her, so Edward comes back and Jake's stink is all over her Wedding Dress. Funny, it occurred to me but it didn't occur to Bella. She's always so worried about hurting Jake but she doesn't seem to worry about hurting Edward.    The only time she did seem to consider his feelings was when she was trying to hide her own pain, with the pregnancy and the transformation. The only time. She could hang onto Jake all she wanted with never a backward glance in Edward's direction. Did Stephenie do that on purpose or did she just think that was acceptable behavior? Yeah, that's a great ending; what a let down.    And a love shield? Yeah, I like Lily Potter too, but I would try to come up with something original for my fourthnovel, not something that's already been done by JK Rowling. And since when was Bella's love her strongest human trait? Her closed mind, yes, love shield, no.

Stephanie Meyer, you have a true gift and please never stop writing.  I can't believe the negaitve reviews. This book is a fantasy book, since when do vampires exist and when do they go to college.  If I wanted real life I'd watch the news.  This book is true fantasy and makes you believe in happily ever after.  I will read it again and enjoy it again just as much.  This series was just amazing and I hope Stephanie continues to write more about the Cullens.
031606792X|5.0|Now that the saga is over, and I've had some time to digest, I can unequivocally say that I did not expect the story to play out exactly as it did... but who would, really? However, I can't deny that I definitely saw some of it (a lot of it) coming. Some of the issues people seem to have with the plot twists seem blatantly obvious to me, so I wanted to post some of my own theories on why SM resolved things the way she did in Breaking Dawn. Given, these are simply my interpretations of why I didn't find every twist out of place, and I could be completely wrong.    1) How come Bella is suddenly okay with being a wife and mother, when she was so abhorred to the idea before?    I think, for Bella, like a lot of people, you can't imagine yourself in these roles until you are. And what's more, for Bella, she especially can't because of her mother's warnings about marriage and because she thinks it's impossible to have children with Edward anyway. Not to mention she's only 18. But that doesn't mean that she is incapable of fulfilling these roles, she just has to mature into them.    The marriage issue was already discussed, in Eclipse, when Bella explained it as nearly a formality in her mind-a way to make Edward happy. But, in the end, it was fitting for her to want to become Edward's wife because it meant she was prepared to dedicate her human life to him, literally. It was a necessary step in the novel to show that she was ready to abandon her human ways (worrying about what other humans would think about her early marriage, for example). She gave herself to Edward as a human, through the typical human method-marriage, before giving herself to him as a vampire.    Her reaction to being pregnant did not seem far-fetched, either. If anything, it went along with the stories of how most women feel when they realize they are carrying another human life inside of them. And how even more miraculous for Bella when she thought it was impossible! Is it really a surprise that sheimmediately wants to protect it? I think it's unfair to assume that Bella would immediately be terrified and beside-herself. Yes, she's young, but not THAT young. I find it funny that people think it's okay for Bella to decide to become a vampire for all eternity, but then she's clearly way too young to handle maternity. Bella at 18 isn't your typical 18 year-old, and readers should know that.    2) Why and how does Bella get pregnant?    The why part of the question seems obvious. After what Rosalie told her in Eclipse, this seemed a natural plot development. Bella has everything that Rose does not, a big part being the ability to conceive. If Bella were robbed of this chance, I think many, including Stephenie (who is a mother) would see it as a tragedy that she missed such a monumental human experience. It might not be what many readers wanted for Bella, but it's no surprise that SM took it there.    The how part is a little less clearly defined, but let's thank SM for not getting into all the gory details of vampiric male anatomy, shall we? Although, to me, the provided explanation is pretty clear. Edward is frozen, as he was when he was first created into a vampire. Therefore, like all men, at any adult age, he has the ability to reproduce, because for men fertility is constant, unlike women. And though Edward's body is technically dead (his heart doesn't beat, he doesn't have normal human processes, etc.) it still functions in its frozen state. And interestingly, so do sperm, as science has found ways to preserve human sperm to be used at a later time by \\"freezing\\" them. So is it so unbelievable that Edward is physically able to impregnate Bella? Maybe it's a stretch, but I think since this is fiction, why not?    3) Why does Renesmee grow at an accelerated pace?    This question also jumped out to me on the message boards as having a clear answer. Renesmee is linked to Jacob in BD, perhaps having a similar genetic make-up because she is a \\"half-breed,\\" as Alice puts it. She's hot to the touch, she is unable to be forseen in Alice's visions, and she might even have 24 chromosomes. Interestingly, like Jacob, she grows at an accelerated rate and then plateaus at a mature state. Think of Jacob's transformation into a werewolf in New Moon. It seemed that by the day he was getting bigger, and every time Bella saw him, he had grown several inches. This is exactly like Renesmee, throughout Bella's pregnancy and in her childhood.    4) Why does Jacob imprint on Renesmee?    So, it might seem a little creepy, but as soon as you knew there was a potential for Bella's offspring, of course Jacob would imprint! He wasn't meant to be with Bella, or he would have imprinted on her originally. But he loves Bella, maybe innately because he saw in her so many qualities that his eventual soul mate would have. Plus, since Renesmee is genetically more like Jacob, we can presume that she is a better candidate for reproduction of werewolves. And SM couldn't leave heartbroken Jacob for all eternity. He had to find his match, and if it weren't Bella, who else would readers have settled for? (I mean, not that they seem to be settled with Renesmee either, it's just the lesser of two evils)    5) How come Bella doesn't go through the normal \\"newborn\\" phase?    This was an unpredicted plot twist, but I don't think SM just did it because it was convenient for Bella not to always be thinking about drinking blood. She could have accelerated through that part of Bella's story and ended up with the same essential plot. But, isn't it interesting how Renee always told Bella how she came out of the womb a fully mature adult? She had wisdom beyond her years as a human, and so it was the same with her vampire birth. Bella is mature by nature, and that maturity, whether it be a superpower or not, meant that she was able to better handle the temptations of \\"childhood,\\" if you will.    6) Why is Bella's special power a shield?    Okay, people who have complained about this have me baffled! What did you expect? We already knew Bella could shield herself from Edward, the Volturi, etc, and Aro even speculated in Breaking Dawn how interesting it would be to see the power manifest itself when she became immortal. Duh. The ability to project her powers on others was unpredicted, but if she simply could just do the same thing she could do as a human, what fun would that be? For all of Bella's insecurities about her human existence-her awkwardness and accident-prone ways-it makes sense that her power as a vampire should be something rewarding and powerful. And, Bella, being the martyr she is, even in human-form, would of course devise a way to protect the ones she loved, and that is exactly why her shield developed as it did.    Like I said, the plot is not hole-proof, but it's not swiss cheese either. I think there are a lot of obvious answers to many questions that SM might not have put down on paper, but that doesn't mean she didn't think through them. I'm curious to hear others speculations about these and other issues they had with the book!
B0006L0LOS|3.0|This is a totally watchable movie, I love the origin of catwoman and some of the cgi effects, cat movements etc... Specially the fight in the jewelry store. B0000AQS0F|5.0|I'm often surprised at the poor reviews this series gets from 'Sci-Fi addicts'.  I more often find that people complain about the setting, or specifically call out Joss Whedon rather than focusing on the show itself.  So, before anyone goes too far off the mark, let's call a few things to light.    First, it's Joss Whedon.  The show is meant to be campy to a degree, and the show is meant to be enjoyable and generally light with a present but contained darker side.  Look at his other work in TV - much of it fits this bill, with only a bit of variation.    Second, it's a western... in space.  Period.  It's not supposed to be the evolution of man, the pioneering of new worlds, or societal fall-backs to an older time.  It's treated like a standard western moved into a space setting.  It's also Sci-Fi, so don't expect anything less and enjoy the combined oddities space and westerns add together.    Third, the characters develop over time. They're not transparent, and those that have reviewed and talked about poor character development certainly haven't watched the show enough.  I've gone through the series once, and have quite a bit of detail about each character involved (save one, who is purposefully left in a hazy background).    Fourth, the plot lines may not be the most original, but they each have their own twists.  With the amount of western material out there, I don't expect much new on that front, so transferring it to space only present limited options to expand.  However, each plot line was delivered well, and has enough personal flavor to stand alone.    If people have a problem with the plot or the acting, it's all based on personal preference at that point.  I personally thought the plot was fine, and the actors did a respectable job.  My main reason for such high marks was the enjoyment factor - the series was Whedon staple, enjoyable content with humor and camp appropriately inserted.  I enjoy a good laugh, and as long as I'm laughing with the series andnot at it, I call that successful.  And while I don't know that this show would be winning any particular awards for the series, it certainly fits my bill for a repeatable enjoyment factor - something I'll definitely watch again in the future when I need a light-hearted laugh.

031606792X|2.0|LONG SO BEWARE!<br /><br />I really need to vent since some of my friends haven't finished it yet..<br /><br />I'm 17 years old and I got hooked on the 'Twilight' series my sophomore year, 2006. I can not even begin to describe how the first book, 'Twilight,' made me feel. Stephenie Meyer gave me everything I could ever want in a book: romance, comedy, sarcasm, drama, action.. all wrapped up into one! Since then, I couldn't get enough of the book. I've probably read it 5-7 times; it's even made my top 3 items to take to a deserted island!<br /><br />I guess you can say I'm a big fan. I wouldn't say I'm a die-hard fan.. I was absolutely amazed and captivated by the book.<br /><br />With 'New Moon,' it left me with mixed emotions. I understand that Meyer wanted to show readers how Bella and Edward would cope without being together 24/7. I felt her pain but Bella started to annoy me.<br /><br />In 'Eclipse,' I think this was when the series started to pick up some more. There was definitely more action later towards the end and I really did feel once again, the struggle Bella faced in choosing Edward or Jacob. However, I believed she was being so selfish in this book and that part of Bella made me like the character less and less. STILL LOVED EDWARD, HATED JACOB.<br /><br />Ah, the series comes to an end with 'Breaking Dawn!' I have been waiting ever since I finished the third book. I even attended the midnight release party at Barnes and Noble. I woke up early in the morning to get my wristband as well.. Dedicated much? YES. Went home, started to read it and I will admit, the first two books were fine with me. I did, however, feel that the story was getting rushed, not everything was being thoroughly explained, a trait of Meyer's writing I admired so much. I knew Bella and Edward would have 'done it' already but like others, I was  amazed how crazy sex had made the two! Not a good message to be sending out to tweens and teens...<br /><br />As I have mentioned earlier, I said that I hated Jacob. Reading Jacob's perspective totally refreshed the book for me because I seriously need to get away from Bella's stupid antics and melodramatic talk. Jacob is seriously not as dumb as he looks or makes himself out to be. He has complete and somewhat complicated thoughts. He is outrageously hilarious; the titles of his chapters were TO DIE FOR! Jacob stayed the most sane to me out of all the characters and I could still feel the same Jacob we were all introduced to three books earlier. I also found it difficult to read some parts because I felt his agony and how hard it must have been to see the love of his life suffer for a baby she never intially wanted and to turn into a vampire! For once, I felt horrible that Bella put Jacob through this. I really wanted to dive more into Jacob's character but sadly.. it ends and goes back to Bella's POV.<br /><br />Wow, the rest of the book just goes downhill for me. Once the vampires find out about the Volturi and their plan, everything begins to build to the climax but when it finally comes.. NOTHING HAPPENED! I was waiting for a freaken epic battle scene to end the series but instead, I got a bunch of scared legendary vampires who run away because they see living proof of vampire hybrids. Can I say crappy ending?!<br /><br />The last chapter I was reminded of why I loved and stayed with the series for all these years. I replayed all the romantic scenes between Bella and Edward that made readers ALIKE grow to love and care for... I was happy to see that Edward could finally see into Bella's mind. That, I was able to handle. Everything else in the book just made me dislike it even more.<br /><br />Overall, the message and themes of the book addresses many issues that today teenagers and young adults deal with: finding and keeping love, having sex, getting pregnant, possibility of abortion, getting an education.. I could go on but they're all pretty negative to me.<br /><br />I read some of the other reviews and I agree with most of the negative reviews. There was no reality in this book. Everything was too neat and 'sweet.' I have a sweet tooth and all but this was just too much! After reading it, I probably got cavitites.. It was that bad.<br /><br />The thing I loved the most about Meyer was the way she characterized the people she wrote about in her book. Everyone could find someone they could relate to. Everyone could feel how they felt. BUT.. 'Breaking Dawn' failed to shine Meyer's characterization. The characters, ALL OF THEM, were so boring and I felt as if they weren't the same ones from the previous books. Bella made me cringe and I was still annoyed.. my favorite character, Edward, was barely mentioned! When he was, he was either refusing than wanting sex or constantly worrying about his newborn wife. I missed him so much. There was no romance in this book and I bet I can speak for everyone that this is why so many people have fell in love with the book.<br /><br />I will applaud Meyer for putting in Jacob's POV because I started to like him because I was able to understand him better. But the imprinting thing 'THE UNMENTIONABLE' was just plain creepy and disgusting to me. Jacob got the short end of the stick and that was totally unfair.<br /><br />THE WHOLE BABY PLOT WAS LAME. LAME LAME LAME. I couldn't believe Meyer chose to head into this direction with the most anticipated novel of this year so far. The name, RENEESME CARLIE, was the most ludicrous and bloodcurdling name I have ever heard in my entire life. I had no idea how to pronounce it and the nickname made it even worse... 'Nessie.' *shivers* I wanted there to be something with the immortal children! When that chapter came when Bella had a nightmare about a immortal child and a pile of drained bodies, I actually thought this would be the plot. Bella and Edward make a mutated baby spawn and it would become evil and kill everything! But instead, I got a beautiful and extraordinary intelligent baby girl who dazzled everyone. WOW. WOW IS ALL I CAN SAY.<br /><br />I can't say anything else now.. I think I got it all out of my system.<br /><br />I agree, I should have stopped at 'Eclipse' and made up my own ending for the series. It sure would have been much better than what Meyer came up with. But hey, read it and decide for yourself.<br /><br />'Breaking Dawn' ruined probably my favorite series (next to Harry Potter) of all time.<br /><br />I will never get over this...this book. Everything was too neat and 'sweet.' I have a sweet tooth and all but this was just too much! After reading it, I probably got cavitites.. It was that bad.     The thing I loved the most about Meyer was the way she characterized the people she wrote about in her book. Everyone could find someone they could relate to. Everyone could feel how they felt. BUT.. 'Breaking Dawn' failed to shine Meyer's characterization. The characters, ALL OF THEM, were so boring and I felt as if they weren't the same ones from the previous books. I missed him so much. There was no romance in this book and I bet I can speak for everyone that this is why so many people have fell in love with the book. But the imprinting thing 'THE UNMENTIONABLE' was just plain creepy and disgusting to me. Jacob got the short end of the stick and that was totally unfair.     THE WHOLE BABY PLOT WAS LAME. 031606792X|2.0|(spoilers below)<br /><br />I have always taken these books for what they are: not particularly groundbreaking literature, but a nonetheless enjoyable, poofy read. A peaceful resolution thanks to Alice's deus ex machina where everyone talked it out rationally and calmly and the Volturi retreated to their creepy towers in Italy.<br /><br />Yes, it sends a good message: violence doesn't have to be the answer. But does it make for an interesting read? Absolutely not. I wanted a huge battle sequence to put Eclipse's newborn fight to shame. 0312427999|5.0|This book is a great starting point for those interested in the alternative, behind-the-scenes version of history over the past 35 years.  It tells about U.S. involvement in South America, particularly Argentina and Chile and how our government supported totalitarian regimes to further the Chicago School economic agenda; the ANC and apartheid Africa and why it failed; disaster capitalism's impact on Sri Lanka and Thailand after the tsunami; disaster capitalism's impact on New Orleans; and where disaster capitalists went wrong in their dealings in Iraq.<br /><br />Naomi Klein truly went above and beyond in creating a concise, accurate portrayal of what's been going on in the sidelines over the last few decades.  I'd be very interested to read her other book \\"No Logo\\" in the future.
031606792X|1.0|I guess the danger of writing the final book in such a popular series is that if by chance the author ruins that one book, the rest of an otherwise intriguing and inventive series is destroyed along with it. In Breaking Dawn, Stephenie Meyer truly rises to the challenge of tearing apart her entire series with that one final book. There will be no spoilers in this review so you need not read with caution. It is enough to say that in her final volume, Meyer bends and distorts the rules of her universe to such a degree to render that universe ridiculous. With its unbelievably absurd plot twists this book read like extremely poor fanfiction. It is slow throughout most of the book but picks up when the conflict finally presents itself almost 600 pages in. However, even the poorly constructed and anti-climactic conflict is not enough to save this warped fairytale book. The main characters fail to retain many of the characteristics that defined them in previous books which makes them seem very alien to the reader at times. The plot twists are few and far between in this overlong book and one in particular is downright creepy (not in a good way). When the reader does finally cross the finish line at the end of this reading marathon, the result is bitter disappointment that such a highly anticipated conclusion was ruined to such a degree. The reader can only hope that next time Meyer decides to write the ending of a hugely popular series, she will have better editors

031606792X|4.0|Yikes. There was so much negativity in the above reviews that I felt the need to defend this book--and its worldview--in a review of my own.    As a young woman, and a femalist (not a feminist), I found this book refreshing in its portrayal of the wife/mother Bella, and I was glad that Stephenie Meyer didn't give up her more traditionalist beliefs to appease a postmodern crowd.     Looking around at the broken marriages and the children neglected by their mothers for the sake of careerism and materialism in our world, perhaps it's time for our culture's heroines to re-embrace the traditional domestic roles of wife and mother, without neglecting to embrace their own unique strengths at the same time. This is something that Bella manages to do in Book 4.      Although some may complain that Bella is too young to make a good mother(though not young by our grandparents' reckoning, I must add), I'd like to point out the fact that motherhood ennobles and matures her character.  She has to think selflessly for once. She lays down her life for her child and her new family, while using her own unique gifts to help to save them. And in getting married in the first place, she gives up all of her human dreams for the companionship of a husband who adores her and will support her, no matter what, and with whom she now shares an equal relationship--a better life for her than she could have ever imagined.     It's also important to point out that being a wife and mother doesn't actually *define* Bella; rather, these roles strengthen her, test her, and challenge her.  She gains more positive qualities as these roles become a part of her life--qualities that add to the definition of who she is, rather than detract from it.  In fact, I'd hazard to say that, had Bella continued to simply date Edward and skipped the whole marriage/baby gig, she may have gotten perpetually 'stuck' in a selfish adolescent state when she became a vampire, limiting her own potential by going down a self-pleasing path.  Moreover, she might have deprived the world of the presence of a very unique individual born of her selfless choice, a miraculous little infant girl who very well might continue the series.    Bravo, Stephenie, for writing such a pro-family, pro-life, pro-marriage, and pro-selflessness novel at a time in which our culture embraces individualism at the expense of others.
031606792X|2.0|Last summer I walked into a book store and plucked a book off the shelf with an interesting looking cover. I read the summary out of curiosity and decided to give it a try. That book was Twilight. I devoured it. Edward Cullen gave me butterflies! I needed New Moon two days later when I had polished off the first book in the series. I was not disappointed. I loved the way Bella and Jacob's relationship grew and I loved that the reader fell in love with him the way she did. Slow and unexpectedly. I came to care about these characters and was sincerely interested in their happiness and futures. A month later Eclipse was released and again I became even more deeply involved with the story. I loved these characters and the relationships between them. I felt as though I knew them. The story line developed so naturally and everyone played their part. Although Bella was my least favorite character, I understood where she was coming from. She was weak, self-conscious, misunderstood. She was human. The only thing, in my eyes, that made her even slightly relatable were her insecurities. I like that she found confidence and strength in her relationship with Edward and her friendship with Jacob.     In waiting for Breaking Dawn, I read The Host (Also written by Stephenie Meyer) and was pleasantly surprised. I wound up LOVING the book. I figured then that Stephenie truly was talented and wasn't just a one-trick pony. This made the anticipation for Breaking Dawn unbearable. I knew she wouldn't let me down....    ...But boy oh boy was I wrong. The first few chapters of this book followed the same feel of the last three books in the series. I felt like we picked up right where we left off and was pleased to see that the book was developing at the same natural pace as the others. Then things went terribly wrong. I felt like mid way through the book I had stumbled upon  an atrocious version of Bella's Breaking Dawn story. A fan fic written by someone who didn't fully understand the depth and maturity of the characters and their relationships. Like Stephenie Meyer's had left her computer unprotected and some hacker swept in to ruin what took her three long books to create. The characters started acting OUT OF CHARACTER. There were inappropriate moments of \\"chuckling\\" and some seriously creepy images going on. Stephenie what happened!? I'm devastated at the outcome of this book. I almost wish I could UN-read it and come up with my own conclusion. At one point while reading, I closed this book, threw it (with force) across the room and started to cry. I missed and longed for the original personality traits of the main characters. I didn't understand them anymore. It felt like I was starting the story over with strangers. I feel as though this book was written to satiate the hormonal needs of all those rabid fans girls. Maybe they tied Stephenie to the bed and threatened to pull a \\"Misery\\" move on her but it seems they got there way. The storyline spun wildly out of control and into this CHEESY fantasy world. Everyone winds up relatively happy at the end but at the cost of losing who these characters truly are. Some parts of this book were rushed and incomplete while others dragged on and became tedious to read. All in all, I would say to those people who are looking forward to breaking dawn, keep your mind WIDDDDDDDDE open. Expect the unexpected and try not to compare it to the other three books in the series. In fact try to steer clear of any kind of expectations. Be prepared for an unfamiliar atmosphere and maybe you can feel more satisfaction in the ending of this originally great series.
