006097625X|5.0|Okay, this is seriously one of the most brilliant books I have ever read, and I have Henry (who is also brilliant) to thank for introducing this to me. (Thank you, Henry.) Although this book has been around since '93, I suspect it's nowhere near as recognized as it deserves to be, but with time that will change, I hope.<br /><br />The full title is \\"Understanding Comics: The Invisible Art,\\" and what Scott McCloud does is explain what we take almost completely for granted, not just about comics, which he convincingly raises to a fine art, but also about the way we 'see,' and think we see, the world around us, especially as it is represented in words and images.<br /><br />It's an important book because he talks in deceptively simple terms about how we perceive reality. McCloud shows the reader, through the seemingly \\"childish\\" mechanism of comics, how we think about what we perceive. Therefore, it's an epistemological text, and those are always of tremendous interest to me. It's also a book about how creativity works, and that's a central theme to my research. I've spent most of my adult life dealing with 90% of what he encapsulates in 215 densely packed (and highly entertaining) pages. Did I mention that the entire work is written in the form of a comic book? No? Well, it is.<br /><br />It purports to be about comics, but that is only the tip of the philosophical iceberg. It's a study of how to think about words and images, and how we have come to use them, not just in Western society, but also in the East. He calls this the \\"invisible art,\\" the effect of the combination of words and pictures, and if you read this, you'll get a much better understanding of the term \\"closure,\\" which is the phenomenon of what the brain does when interpreting the gaps between words and pictures (in comics, this gap is represented visually by the space between each frame of words and images). We make up a story in our minds to close this gap, and it's a crucial piece of the story-telling process, this 'silence' that leads the reader to decide what really happens.<br /><br />Scott McCloud combines semiotics (the discussion of the meaning of signs and signifiers), art history, rhetorical analysis (why it's so brilliant), cognitive and neurological research (another reason it's so brilliant), with an analysis of art and literature's influence on human social dynamics. The synthesis he reaches makes the invisible, visible, and will help the reader understand how comics evolved and where they come from. Hopefully, it will give the reader a new appreciation for the comics art form.<br /><br />I have studied the theory behind virtually every aspect of what he's talking about, except comics, and so I know the sources he's relying on to get to the information he's condensed for the reader, and I also know you won't like those sources, but you will like this book because it's accessible in a way semiotics, rhetorical analysis, and the finer points of art history, are not. But if you read this book, that's part of what you'll be reading, and you'll be glad you did.e' that leads the reader to decide what really happens.     Scott McCloud combines semiotics (the discussion of the meaning of signs and signifiers), art history, rhetorical analysis (why it's so brilliant), cognitive and neurological research (another reason it's so brilliant), with an analysis of art and literature's influence on human social dynamics. The synthesis he reaches makes the invisible, visible, and will help the reader understand how comics evolved and where they come from. Hopefully, it will give the reader a new appreciation for the comics art form.    I have studied the theory behind virtually every aspect of what he's talking about, except comics, and so I know the sources he's relying on to get to the information he's condensed for the reader, and I also know you won't like those sources, but you will like this book because it's accessible in a way semiotics, rhetorical analysis, and the finer points of art history, are not. But if you read this book, that's part of what you'll be reading, and you'll be glad you did.

She finds the place where she fits and finds herself.  It was lovely to see.  Sure, I hate the baby's name but I'm really pleased with everything else.  I feared fights, battles and beloved characters lost and luckily we were given a happy ending where strength of character, truth, and above all LOVE triumph.  I can't have any complaints with that.

031606792X|1.0|I've never been a fan of the Twilight Saga. Never. I think the books are horribly contrived, horribly written and horribly famous for no tangible reason whatsoever. But I read Breaking Dawn expecting it to be like Eclipse or the other two books that precede it: boring and unoriginal.    However, Breaking Dawn is anything but. And not in good ways.    ***This review DOES contain spoilers.***    I've seen on various interviews with Stephanie Meyer where'd say something like...  \\"Twilight is about finding love, New Moon is about losing love and Eclipse is about choosing love.\\"  Choice. That was a theme SMeyer constantly bombarded us with in Eclipse and how Bella had to give up a lot to be with Edward.    In Breaking Dawn, every single one of these so-called \\"sacrifices\\" were negated.    Bella wanted to become a vampire so she can be with Edward forever and ever and she says in Eclipse that her body isn't going to be the same once she's turned. Basically, she gives up sex. However, we find that magically (perhaps through divine intervention?) she can still WANT Edward the same way after she's a vampire.    Bella gave up a \\"normal\\" future aka having kids. Through some logic-defying twist, she gets pregnant and delivers a beautiful baby girl. This doesn't make sense. SMeyer has said before in interviews that vampires have no sperm. How can Edward get Bella pregnant if he has no sperm? SMeyer breaks the rules to her own land to derive this terrifically amateurish plot twist.    Bella gave up her family. In reality, Charlie finds out the Cullens are \\"different\\" and--through some convenient plot development--doesn't want to know more. (If he DOES find out about vampires, of course, the Volturi would either want him turned or dead.)  Of course, Renee continues to be the absentee parent and it seems that Meyer completely seems to have forgotten about her.    I know SMeyer wanted a fairy tale ending. What I don't know is WHY. The previous three books--while still bad--were dark(in a very boring way but this review isn't about them) with almost a brooding tone. A fairy tale ending isn't realistic or suitable.    I'm not even going to get into the bad grammar/writing or major character flaws. I could write pages and pages on what's wrong with the Twilight Saga but what I've written here will suffice.    P.S. NESSIE/RENESMEE CARLIE. Really? And I thought JKR was bad with the naming.

I think if readers are old enough to handle a half vampire half human baby violently ripping itself out of its mother while the father tears open the uterus, they should be able to handle a scene of the physical act of true love that we all knew Edward and Bella had.      It makes me even more sad that there are ppl that loved this book.  I wish, so hard, that i loved this book.  I want to love it, and honestly regaurdless of what happened in the story i probably would have, if i felt the connection to all the characters like i had in the first 3.    I still recommend that anyone interested in the series read this book only because this is how the author intened it to end.  Just be warned, you will NOT be dazzeled by this one like you have been by the others.    This is so depressing....

This is a plus.  In fact, Heath Ledger's Joker is far removed from the high camp earlier versions of Jack Nicholson and Caesar Romero.  This time the character has some depth and fear.  The Joker is a psychopath rather than a pure comic strip side show.<br /><br />As to the rest of the film, \\"The Dark Knight\\" is grossly over-rated.  Yes, I know that we need to take the plot with a grain of salt.  But, really, the plot ventures into the absurd.  I'm sure it appeals to a teenage audience.  However, as an adult, I found my credulity being strained to snapping point.  To be frank, I was glad when the film ended and the lights in the cinema came on.<br /><br />So, if you're a Batman aficionado, you'll probably find this film in the top of its class.  If you're a more disinterested viewer, I suspect you may be less than impressed.

B000002A3T|3.0|But after that, not much else to say. The second album under the Pink Floyd name without Roger Waters seriously misses his presence, especially in the lyrics division. The album is, conceptually, about relationships splitting apart (\\"Division Bell,\\" get it?), and minus the subtext of Gilmour's acrimony towards Waters, you'd think this was a divorce album.<br /><br />The bluesy \\"What Do You Want From Me\\" is the hardest song here. With a biting lyric and Gilmour's standard fluid guitar leads, it is probably the most obvious FU to the former band member. However, the concept strains itself and becomes too obvious by the time you hit songs like \\"Wearing The Inside Out\\" or \\"Lost for Words.\\" If it weren't for Hawkings' voice on \\"Keep Talking,\\" it would be a wholly forgettable song.<br /><br />The best of the rest are \\"A Great Day For Freedom\\" and \\"High Hopes.\\" \\"Great Day\\" finds our unhappy protagonist marveling at the fall of The Berlin Wall, yet forlornly wondering why inner peace is so far from his grasp. \\"High Hopes\\" looks back to the days of \\"magnets and miracles,' and then stares in the face of dashed hopes and disillusionment. The rest of \\"The Division Bell,\\" however, doesn't measure up to previous full-band classics like [[ASIN:B000024D4S Wish You Were Here]] or [[ASIN:B000006TRV The Wall]]. Completists may need this, but others can proceed with caution.

0761944524|5.0|This book was an enormous help to me in writing my doctoral dissertation. Now, I am a Communications scholar and I did a content analysis, so I didn't need to master a lot of highly advanced techniques. But nor had I taken courses that taught statistics in any depth. I was feeling quite at sea on some things. And for a dissertation, you really have to understand things, so you can defend it at the end. Although I had other statistics books and they certainly were helpful, this one that walked me through the tests I had been doing and -- quite simply, with patience and good humor -- helped me to understand why they were necessary and basically how they worked. I liked the fact I could read much or as little detail as I could absorb at the time -- there are quick summaries, clearly marked, or longer, quite simple explanations for those in a hurry, as well as in-depth explanations for things you really need to know thoroughly. It was having those choices that made this book incredibly helpful.

031606792X|4.0|There may be spoilers but it's necessary to give justfication to my review.    I cannot decide whether to give this a three star or a four star.  But I am sure that this is NOT a one-star book.    Each one who will read this book will have a different experience with it.  I do suggest you read it for yourself before you decide to believe those who says this is crappy.    It is NOT bad.  It could have done better with more fight scenes towards the end.  The anticipation of the coming danger has more chapters than the actual danger itself or the resolution of the whole problem.      Okay so SM is a fan of happily-ever-afters.  Is that bad?  I don't think so.  This could well be a fairy tale instead of an epic.  Ordinary girl gets a hot boyfriend and he loves her more than anything in the world.  He isn't human.  He turns her into his kind, but not before knocking her up and giving her the best human experience any woman deserved.  I love Edward and Bella so much when I read Twilight.  And I think they deserved that much.  They deserve eternity and I love them enough to want them to have a baby.      I read Breaking Dawn with the same mindset I had when I was reading New Moon and Eclipse.  I read as if I was reading an extended version of Twilight.  I wanted to take a peek at what Edward's and Bella's life were going to be after Twilight.  The conflicts, the pains and the final happily-ever-after.    If there had not been any sequel to Twilight, Jacob may not be as important as he is now.  This saga is ABOUT Edward's and Bella's lovestory.  Twilight IS a lovestory, more than it is a vampire story.  So we already know they will end up together.  Because if they don't, then what was the whole point?  What's the point of me falling in love with the lovestory of Edward Cullen and Bella Swan if she ended up being Bella Black in the end?  I would not even watch the movie if that had been the case!    This book may not have been as exciting as we wanted it to be.  Eclipsehad been more mysterious and more exciting, I think.  But that book irritated me because Bella's character irritated me there.  She was fickle, obsessive, selfish and whiny.  You will be happy to know that she is not like that anymore in Breaking Dawn.  Not even so much when she was still human during the earlier part of the book.    Why are people complaining about Bella all of a sudden protective of her baby?  Well guys, if you get married, things change!  Your perspective in life changes!  It seems that Bella matured more in days than in the years--in the previous books.  She's making up for it, guys!  She was too immature in Eclipse.  If she neglected her baby, we would have hated her more!  So I think this is better.      Edward...  Well, he is being Edward.  Always torn between saving Bella's life, and giving her everything she asks for.  The perfect, flawless Romeo.  That's what made us fall in love with him.  He suffered in this book... for Bella's pain and suffering.  He was willing to sacrifice everything... his love, his happiness, for Bella.  He's done this before in the other books and he will do it again here.  But here, we get to see how he would connect with Bella as a vampire too.  No more holding back too much.  No more holding hER as if She was breakable.  And in this book, Edward gets to be a husband... and a father.  It is also in this book that he gets to bond more with the wolves.    The bond between the vamps and wolves is more displayed here.  Co-existence.  For the same cause.  Fighting again on the same side.  Accepting each other's differences.  Enduring each other's scents.  Here, Jacob and Seth comes and goes the Cullen mansion as if they live there themselves.  I totally enjoyed this part.    Jacob... well, he's still Jacob.  Funny.  Rash.  Reckless.  Normal teenage boy.  The second part of the book was written in his perspective.  Of course.  Can Bella describe EXACTLY how the imprinting went?  At first, I wasn't happy when I startedreading the Jacob part.  But after this part, I must admit that this is the funniest part of the book.  I laughed more in Jacob's part than in any other parts of the book.  And I did like Jacob better in this book.  He wasn't too stubborn to fight and get in between Edward and Bella.  He loved Bella more than that.  He understood self-sacrifice.  And in the end, when the baby was born, he understood everything.  He finally understood the concept of imprinting.  And he understood why Bella was not meant for him from the beginning.  He would only hurt her.  And she would hurt Edward had she chosen Jacob.    Rose gets her piece too.  And she's made her peace with Bella.  It was fun to see them working together and Rosalie and Jacob getting on each other's nerves.    This book is about every character you have met in the previous books and then some new additions.  Not just Bella and Edward.  Like I said, a peek of their lives after Twilight.  And since they are surrounded by relationships and so much love, other their own, this book has been a lot about the other characters too.      Reneesme... Okay so I'm also not a fan of the name.  But I've heard creepier names.  (I had once seriously considered naming my future son Count Drake!  It's my baby!)  Reneesme is Stephanie Meyer's brainchild.  She can name her anything she wants.  I loved how she has Bella's eyes, and so much of Edward in her.    And don't get the wrong idea from the bad reviews that Jacob on Reneesme is phedophilia.  I think they stopped reading there!  Otherwise, they would have seen that Jacob has become her ultimate protector.  He doesn't even see Reneesme in an improper way!  And Edward confirmed that in the end.  He will wait for her.  Not for long.  Six or seven years, she will be a full-grown adult.  It would be nice to see that one.  A wolf and a halfling.  But in BD, there is nothing there but the ultimate sense to protect her.  Babysit her.  Give her everything she wants.  And he doesn't evensee the potential in the relationship even after it was revealed that she will be an adult in six or seven years.  Edward said that much and he was in Jacob's head.    Maybe some people expected a more grander drama, someone dying because it is only much more realistic that they do.  But then again, this is a fantasy.  None of these are supposed to be real.  So who are we to judge what is realistic and what is not?  So nobody died.  It was a happy ending.  Not realistic?  You're reading a vampire love story for crying out loud!    If you loved Edward Cullen and Bella Swan that much, then I think you will be satisfied at the way Breaking Dawn turned out.  For both of them.  Everybody worked out just fine.  They have been under so much strain, they deserve the happy ending.  And they deserve Reneesme.  A product of their timeless love.  Jacob deserved Reneesme too.  A gift for all his sacrifices.    I would have wanted a longer fight scene towards the end and probably a bit more twist, more challenge.  Maybe Aro refusing to leave until he acquires Edward and Bella.  Thus, I can't give this five stars.    But since Bella emerged as great vampire here, making up for all her fragility and uselessness in the past books, I would give this a four stars.  Yes, folks, Bella was super in her vampiric life.  Bella was able to render the most powerful members of the Vulturri helpless.  for once, she was the heroine!  For once, she felt she deserved Edward!

006135323X|4.0|Dan Ariely has written a very engaging look into experiments he has conducted over his tenure at MIT. He starts with his medical history of his third degree burns over his body. Ariely does this to make the reader aware of his inspiration to \\"discover what people really like\\" in the world. His first example is removing the cloth from his wounds in a fast or slow motion. The nurses are sure the fast rip with a quick flash of pain is the best way; however, this makes Ariely begin to wonder the truth behind this common assumption.<br /><br />The book flows in and out of his history and there did not seem to be in chronological order. The reader could skip around the chapters to their own delight. Ariely has made the book approachable for anyone with an affinity for experiments and the \\"why\\" behind the decisions. This approach has been made popular by \\"Freakonomics\\", \\"What Sticks\\", \\"Economic Naturalist\\", and many other books along the same line. I enjoyed Ariely's book the most of the new economist book series.<br /><br />Chapter Six, Nine, Eleven, and Twelve were my favorite chapters out of the thirteen in the book. Procrastination, Expectations, and Honesty are all prominently featured in these chapters. I did not feel I could better understand all the subjects he discussed in the other chapters any more than before for various reasons like I have read it, heard it, or not interested were the main reasons.<br /><br />I believe people should give Ariely's book a look just to see where some of his antics and experiments are different from the aforementioned books. It is approachable and a joyful read that is over before it begins. Ariely has done something to set himself apart from the economist books before him and also borrows some of their insights for his book. If anything check the book out from the library to see his experiments in action and know why human beings are predictably irrational.

031606792X|4.0|I read the first three books only two weeks ago and devoured them in little under 3 days.  I anxiously awaited Breaking Dawn...and was only slightly disappointed.  Some predictable turns and things ended too neatly (could it have killed her to just let Jacob suffer?  to let Bella suffer a little knowing what her selfish actions in refusing to give him up did to Jacob's heart?)  That does not make the book bad, nor do the final choices of the characters mean that Stephanie Meyer believes all teenagers should marry young and have babies, with no higher education.  She herself is educated and is a role model IN THE REAL WORLD for teenagers and adults alike (whereas Bella is an almost fully rounded character in a fictional NOVEL).  Meyer's books reinforce the idea that, no matter the struggle or situation, a close network of family and friends can help you through it.<br /><br />It is sad though, because the best part of books 1-3 was the tension between Bella's humanity and Edward's immortality, as expressed in various ways.  Now that the final book is here, everything is wrapped up nice and tight, no more tension or suspense.  Well, at least until I start rereading Twilight. ;)
031606792X|4.0|I went to a midnight release party for this book, and all I kept hearing was how everyone couldn't wait for Bella to become a vampire and they hoped she chose Edward... \\"...If she hasn't been turned before the book is half over I'm going to freak.\\" -- \\"If she doesn't pick Edward I'll just die.\\"  Well, of course she chose Edward and did become a vampire, so how could the dynamic between the characters not change.  Bella is no longer the clumsy, accident prone girl.  She is now a young, strong vampire.    I did, however, feel that this book was trying to cram a lot into one last story.  It could easily have been broken into two separate books.  Then maybe the transition from mortal to immortal, and the change in dynamic between characters wouldn't have been such a shock to everyone. 031606792X|4.0|***SPOILERS!!!***SPOILERS!!!***SPOILERS!!!***         I have to admit that at first I was disappointed in this book.  I felt, like so many others, that everything turned out a little too conveniently for Bella.  I also felt that it was quite predictable. I put the story together well before anything was revealed. As I have allowed myself time to absorb the story more fully, however, I find myself really liking it.  I felt that the character changes that people have talked about were necessary.  Bella couldn't continue to be that same clumsy, often irritating, teenage girl that she had been and expect to survive as a vampire for long.  Also, Edward had to change and allow Bella to develop her new Vampire self instead of being so overbearing and unreasonable.      As for her ability to seem to skip over all of the newborn problems I didn't find that as hard to swallow as some did.  I think that she had prepared her mind and that she did have an extremely strong will (which was shown in the other books). I, myself, have known people with the same kind of determination and single mindedness that she shows and they are much more capable of self control and overcoming their urges than those who don't have those characteristics. I think that the message here is that with enough preparation and determination, you can accomplish anything that is important to you.     I have read some of the reviews of those that are upset about the fact that Bella was a teenager when she became pregnant.  I agree that teenage pregnancy is not something to be taken lightly, but COME ON.  These people are the same people who thought that she was emotionally mature enough to give up her humanity and become a vampire for the rest of eternity.  It seems to me that if she can handle that decision she can certainly handle a baby, especially one that will be fully grown in approximately seven years.  As for her never particularly wanting to have children, when she found out that she was pregnant herfeelings on that changed completely.  Anyone who has had a baby can attest to the bond that is created between a mother and her child while in the womb.  The measures that she took to ensure the babies safety were consistent with what most mothers would do.  Even if it meant giving up her life she wanted to protect her child.      The argument that marrying and having a child at so young an age would interfere with her ability to experience the growth and fulfillment that comes of going to college and having interests outside the home are completely irrelevant in this scenario.  I mean, really, she is immortal now; her daughter will be fully grown in about seven years and she has all of eternity to accomplish anything she wants to.  The experience of being a parent enriches her life, as well as Edward's, rather than detracting from it.  It was something that neither of them ever expected to happen and Renesmee can only be considered a blessing.  This is a fantasy set in a world of vampires and werewolves...the issues that plague our normal human teens just don't apply in the world that Stephenie Meyer has created.  Bella is a vampire who cannot sleep she will have to fill her time with something, and I'm guessing that she will be more educated and fulfilled than any doctor, lawyer, teacher, writer, or any human woman ever could be.     Now to the part where Jacob imprints on Renesmee (I do still have a gripe with that name! I think Carlie Renesmee would have been preferable if she absolutely had to combine her parents names).  I really didn't have a problem with this, mainly because when Quil imprinted on Claire I thought a lot about the whole imprinting thing.  I have come to understand that it is not the same thing as falling in love or having romantic feelings about the person you have imprinted on.  It is more of a guardian or protector position that you assume and it can lead to love because of the bonds that you create while being around each other.  The factthat people are calling Jacob a pedophile is ridiculous.  As I said before, the same rules do not apply in their world as in ours.  He is not already in love with her and his only desire is for her to be happy and safe.  If Jacob is a pedophile then Edward is one as well.  Bella was, after all, only seventeen when he fell in love with her and he was over a hundred.    The only thing I find myself still yearning for with this book is a more satisfying ending with the Volturi.  I was really looking forward to getting to see all of the vampires get to use their respective abilities fighting against the greedy and power hungry aristocracy.  I felt that the fact that they didn't have more of a conflict with the Volturi was a bit anticlimactic.  Not that I was wanting someone to die, like so many of the reviews I have read thus far, just that I didn't want the Volturi to give in so easily.  When Alice returned, I was certain that there would have been more effort in obtaining her for themselves.  This way, however, leaves an opening if the author ever wants to add to the story.    All in all, I feel more satisfied after reflecting for a day or two than I did after initially finishing the book.  Though it didn't go the way I had envisioned it going and it's not my favorite of her books, I feel that Stephenie Meyer did a good job telling the story she wanted to tell and giving the characters the ending they deserved.
031606792X|1.0|Breaking Dawn was a disappointment. The series started out so strong with the beloved bestseller, Twilight, but as the series progressed, the quality digressed. By Eclipse, her ideas were becoming poor and ill developed. I hoped it was the weak book that every series seems to have and that she would redeem herself in Breaking Dawn and conclude the series with a novel just as loved as Twilight.<br /><br />No such luck. Breaking Dawn was more disappointing than Eclipse.<br /><br />Breaking Dawn started out with a thread of hope. The first hundred pages read like the other novels and I enjoyed the wedding and the start of the honeymoon. It looked like Stephenie Meyer might be going somewhere with it.<br /><br />But then Stephenie Meyer had to go make Bella pregnant, going against all her rules. She made it very clear that vampires can't have children or impregnate (because all bodily fluid other than venom and the blood they acquire through their prey is absent. Which would make it quite difficult to have children). So she goes against he carefully thought out vampire mythology and says heck with that, I'm gonna make Bella preggers anyway!<br /><br />The change in narration also bothered me. Stephenie Meyer stated in an interview that this would be the last novel for Bella's story. Hence the word Bella. This was supposed to be her story. A change in point of view was truly unnecessary. I think Jacob's POV made the vampires feel shallow and unreal (though we did get nice insight to the pack). I think if Stephenie Meyer really wanted to have her reader accept Bella's pregnancy, she should've told it in Bella POV.<br /><br />I was beginning to accept that fact that Bella and Edward were going to have a child. But then the unthinkable occurred.  Jacob imprints. I didn't want Jacob to imprint, period (even if it was on a NORMAL girl, but the fact that he imprinted on Bella's child was just absurd.) Imprinting was the easy way out of the love triangle and I think there should have been more pain and sacrifice in the book. By choosing Edward, Bella was giving up some things, most importantly Jacob and the chance at a normal life (which included children) Stephenie Meyer decides to make everything happy and perfect and Jake and Bella's feelings for each other suddenly disappear. The whole story would've felt a bit more real, a bit more human if there had been more sacrifices to make.<br /><br />At least the rest of the novel wasn't complete happiness and fluff. (Though I was quite annoyed at Bella's perfection. Her self-control was just too good) The appearance of the Volturi was a good idea, but poorly developed. It ended too smoothly, with perfect Bella saving the day. I think there should've been a fight with some casualties (other than Irina) Again, Stephenie Meyer was trying to hard for the happy ending. A few deaths, especially from the Cullen family, would've made the story much more believable.<br /><br />The series concluded with a happy ending. (Even the last chapter was called The Happily Ever After) It was all too good to be believable.<br /><br />The only redeeming quality about the book was the fact the Stephenie Meyer can write. Even though she came up with absurd ideas, she managed to make them work because she is a good writer. The fact that I enjoy her writing style was the only thing that allowed me to finish the novel.<br /><br />All in all, Breaking Dawn was a disappointing end to a series (and an author) that I believed had much more potential.in the book. By choosing Edward, Bella was giving up some things, most importantly Jacob and the chance at a normal life (which included children) Stephenie Meyer decides to make everything happy and perfect and Jake and Bella's feelings for each other suddenly disappear. The whole story would've felt a bit more real, a bit more human if there had been more sacrifices to make.     At least the rest of the novel wasn't complete happiness and fluff. (Though I was quite annoyed at Bella's perfection. Her self-control was just too good) The appearance of the Volturi was a good idea, but poorly developed. It ended too smoothly, with perfect Bella saving the day. I think there should've been a fight with some casualties (other than Irina) Again, Stephenie Meyer was trying to hard for the happy ending. A few deaths, especially from the Cullen family, would've made the story much more believable.    The series concluded with a happy ending. (Even the last chapter was called The Happily Ever After) It was all too good to be believable.     The only redeeming quality about the book was the fact the Stephenie Meyer can write. Even though she came up with absurd ideas, she managed to make them work because she is a good writer. The fact that I enjoy her writing style was the only thing that allowed me to finish the novel.     All in all, Breaking Dawn was a disappointing end to a series (and an author) that I believed had much more potential.

B0015DYIH2|5.0|I was thrilled from beginning to end reading BREAKING DAWN, grateful to Stephenie Meyer for writing such a wonderful saga, and saddened to read the bad reviews from petulant readers.<br /><br />Ms. Meyer has created complete, rounded, fully-faceted characters, and let us go along as they each matured -- even the adults.  I was hoping for a book that brought the saga to a happy ending, because that was the point all along:  Bella and Edward had a once-in-an-existence love that could meet and defeat any and all challenges.<br /><br />For those who carp on small details, I ask this question:  When did you decide that vampires, werewolves, Volturi, mind-reading and all the other staples of THE TWILIGHT SAGA were permissible, but a baby and a happy ending was not?  Either you hand yourself up to be entertained, or don't bother reading.<br /><br />One other thought:  These are Stephenie Meyers' characters, not yours, no matter how you might identify with them.  She fleshed out her dream and shared it with the world.  To have any response other than gratitude for being taken on a wild romantic ride is sheer selfishness.  For those who would rather be right than be happy, pick at details.  For those who want to be satisfied over and over by a fine author, grab BREAKING DAWN and the first three in the TWILIGHT SAGA and have the time of your life.

What I noticed was that it is not perfect, there are numerous scenes [mostly in the closing titles and stills] with visible dirt/debris and scratches which could have been removed.  There are also quality differences from scene to scene which some viewers may find distracting [me among them]- one scene is crystal-clear, while the next scene may be comparatively fuzzy, with visible film grain and multigenerational losses visible].  Another curiosity is why they had to drown-out William Shatner's opening narration [\\"Space...the final frontier...\\"] with so much reverberation.  Other than those quibbles, I found the colors to be as garishly oversaturated [with almost a day-glow flourescent quality] as I remember from watching it on its original run [circa 1966] on an old-fashioned Setchell-Carson 25\\" color console TV, but with vastly improved fine detail - the make-up was VERY apparent, also I could see ear hair/peachfuzz on some actors! Every shaft of hair was clearly visible, along with acne scars and the border of Captain Kirk's hairpiece.  The motion-animated digital insertions were seamless and greatly enabled the enhanced \\"versimilitude\\" the producers were after.  BTW, this review applied only to the standard definition side, I have not been able to watch the HD side, as I have no HD player - this said, I am amazed they were able to make the standard-def picture so sharp and finely detailed.<br />I remember watching the digitally reworked \\"Star Trek - The Motion Picture\\" and [at the time] wondering if anybody would ever do the same thing with TOS, and now they have.  This edition is a clear improvement over the previous remasterings.  Bravo!

B000E1ZBGS|5.0|Those reviewers who criticize the imperfect portrayal of the characters, fancying themselves to be pro Jane Austen, need to go back and read the book again to get it right. The costumes are different styles, because certain people would be able to have the lastest fashions, and others not. 031606792X|5.0|I'm a little surprised at the negative reactions to this book.  That major issue seems to lie with Jacob imprinting Renesmee, citing it as sexual or perhaps even incestuous...     Imprinting on a child was, as anyone knows, a subject previously touched upon in the issue of (I think) Quil and Claire.  The imprinting is certainly not voluntary.  What sane grown man would ever wish to be tied toa child in any way that could be misconstrued as sexual? Despite what some would believe, I truly believe that imprinting is a testament to love in its purest form.  Jacob and Quil were not seeking physical or even romantic gratification from the subjects of their imprinting at any point in the near future.  Rather, they were willing to sacrifice relationships that could fulfill them in those ways to fully protect and be with their \\"mates\\" (for lack of a better word).  Perhaps they were aware that it would someday be a possibility.  Imprinting happens for a reason. Is it repulsive to see a 60 year old man with a 40 something woman, not even taking into account that the wolves (shape-shifters...sorry) do not age in the same way?  If not, would such a scenario still be acceptable if that same sixty year old man knew 40 or 50 years sooner who his future mate would be, but as she was much younger, simply had to wait for her?  It's not that Jacob saw Renesmee and was physically attracted to her or simply wanted her to belong to him.  He KNEW that she was his intended, the perfect mate for him, despite what he might have liked.  Let's face it, he initially would have hoped to have imprinted on Bella.  Perhaps Bellas was simply a picture of his future mate and that was partially why he was so fond of her and why he felt so compelled to stick around.    Finally, something I was absolutely incredulous about was someone claiming that Jacob's imprinting on Renesmee was \\"unrealistic\\".  I, for one, can find a a lot more in the book to call \\"unrealistic\\".  How about the freakin vampires?  It's a fantasy novel, buddy.  It's not supposed to be realistic.  What it did offer, though was a very practical resolution to the Bella and Jacob issue, one that I feel was perfect and as realistic as possible.  They were meant to be in each other's lives in some significant way.  Neither of them were ever able to make sense of their odd connection.  Perhaps, as previously stated, it was not  simply a way to keep them together so that everyone could live happily ever after.  Perhaps Jacob and Bella were so close and so insistent upon being in the other's life because of some greater good, i.e. the birth and imprinting of Renesmee.

031606792X|2.0|Okay... So I loved the first three books in the Twilight Saga, but breaking dawn? No!!  *Spoilers*  A BABY?! What? Bella doesn't WANT a kid. The real Edward would feel remorse for killing their child.\\"     And then part two came on and it was from JACOB'S point of view. I was pissed. He never looked or acted like he was freaking out over her after she turned into a vampire. He just... let it go. That was it. That's what was so un-Edward.    It was like Edward freaked out (the \\"burning man\\") when Bella was pregnant but then when he was changing her he was just determined and then she was changed and he just loved her. As in he didn't fear for her.    Back to the story. So Bella isn't really thirsty and she only really freaks out once at anyone (Jacob) and it isn't really all that big of a deal. And then Charlie goes along with Bella's new life perfectly. And their slight worry is the kid and how fast she's growing (which ends up not being a problem) and Bella visiting the Volturi, who can't pick her mind to find out about the baby. No worries.     I don't even want to talk about the rest of the book except to say that the ending was predictable. Of course Alice and Jasper would come back. Of course the ending would be perfect with no one dying and Bella's gift being the thing that saves the day. Of course. Like we couldn't predict that.    I think that Stephenie Meyer was projecting her love of being a mother onto her writing. And I don't like it because this is Bella's story, not Stephenie Meyer's autobiography.
031606792X|4.0|Before I even read the book, I got on Amazon and read all the reviews to see how the plot went. I was surprised to see all these negative reactions to the book, and frankly when I started actually reading, I had those in mind. However, the book surprised me and I enjoyed it very much. Yes, it's different, but it's all very interesting. The imprinting thing with Jacob and Renesmee even made sense, and though the Bella-Edward dynamic was different than it has been, their romance is still obviously there. I think many people were expecting certain things, and that's why they're disappointed. Also, I don't think Stephanie Myer is trying to send any messages with the story; about marrying and having children young, not going to college, etc. Bella is a vampire, after all, and we all knew her life wasn't going to take the \\"normal path\\"...highschool, college, then married, etc, etc. People also complained about the lack of action, but even without fighting scenes like Eclipse, the tension was still there when Bella was struggling for her life and the baby's, and when Alice disappeared and they gathered to meet the Volturi. I think people should stop trying to find fault with the book because it's not what they personally wanted it to be, and accept and enjoy the story for what it is, which is very good.

031606792X|3.0|The series was most certainly at its best with \\"Twilight\\" and flowed smoothly through the next two installments with the story changing and surprising the reader rather than becoming disjointed. However, this easy flow is interrupted and turned on its head with the fourth installment. I give Meyer props for writing the unexpected (surely there was not one reader who was not shocked by certain twists), but I was also slightly uncomfortable with how much the style and tone deviated from that of the original trilogy. The innocence and humor of the characters that I have come to love flounders here, and personalities change with little explanation. I found myself pausing and trying to re-paint the portraits of the main characters as some actions conflicted with what I had been told about them in previous books. Like other reviewers here, some parts of the novel left me feeling like I was reading a fanfiction as opposed to the work of Meyer, who previously impressed me with her knack for storytelling in not only the Twilight Saga, but in \\"The Host\\" (which is worth a read). I think most of the harsher reviews for this novel are stemming from reactions to the surprise plot twists in the story, and most of the extreme contempt portrayed in those reviews is undeserved. While this is not Meyer's best work, and it is clearly not what many fans wanted after suffering through the anticipation, it is exciting, unexpected, and will definitely keep you guessing.

081541028X|4.0|Collins writes a richly detailed and intelligent account, laced with smart-alecky humor, of what it was like to join the astronaut corps, the training and planning that go into a mission, and what it's like to go into space. His description of his anxiety during the period that Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the moon really puts you in the moment and makes you realize that making it back was no foregone conclusion.<br /><br />It makes me sad to see how this book has become dated. We as a nation gave up on manned space exploration 35 years ago, and the shuttle has been a dead end. While I reading the book, I felt a sense of futility that Collins, who wrote the book in the '70s, could never have anticipated.<br /><br />Carrying the Fire is an excellent astronaut memoir; maybe one day there'll be a reason for somebody to write some new ones.<br /><br />Reviewer: Liz Clare, co-author of the historical novel \\"To the Ends of the Earth: The Last Journey of Lewis and Clark\\"

031606792X|1.0|Before I actually purchased the book, I went here, to Amazon, to read some reviews about Breaking Dawn to make sure it had lived up to its hype.    To my surprise, it hadn't.    I accidentally came across a few spoilers, and I read them, mouth agape. Bella pregnant? Jacob's convenient imprinting? It all sounded like a immature fifteen year old's fanfiction. However, I was determined to give the book a fighting chance, and bought it at a bookstore right near my house.    The next day, I returned it, fully read and smothered in my hatred.    Where do I even start? The first few chapters of the initial Bella story were written in a tasefully familiar fashion. Bella was still somewhat relatable, and I was able to fully tolerate any writing blips that Meyer had made.    After the honeymoon had started, however, I quickly began to lose patience with the story.    Edward became an emotionally detatched nitwit with only his lust to drive his love for Bella. Bella, in turn, was equally sex-crazed, and slowly became a one-dimensional character. Her stubborn love for her mutant spawn only made her infuriatingly untolerable, and I began to wish she would be mercilessly killed by the Volturi at the end.    Carlisle was written horribly as well, and came off as just plain idiotic when he had to have another person, a werewolf/shape-shifter whatever, tell him that a vampire might like to drink blood. At that point, I knew something horribly wrong was going to happen to the rest of the characters -- and the plot.    My remedy: Bella should not have been both pregnant and turned into a  vampire in the same book. In fact, the pregnancy should have been eradicated altogether. I'd like to shake Meyer's editor by the shoulders and make him or her see the monstrosity that they allowed published. The pregnancy did nothing for the plot, the characters, or the health of the series altogether. It added unnecessary fluff, and a convenient way to end Jacob's reign as a deep and satisfyingly affectionate character.     I also believe that Bella's transformation hurt the book as well. What had made Bella special as a character was the fact that she was HUMAN. A human who could not trust that everything around her wasn't magical in some way. It is what turned her fans onto her in the first place; the belief that even ordinary people such as ourselves could play a part in a beautiful world that previously only existed in our dreams.     After Bella had made the change, she turned the book into something common -- the typical garbage about being drafted into a vampire clan, and then NOTHING EVER BEING THE SAME AGAIN. It's OK, Meyer. We've seen that written before; no need to give us your own little spin off.    Finally, in my opinion, the Volturi SHOULD have eradicated the Cullen clan, leaving only Bella, Jacob, and Renesmee alive. Would have at least provided a slight cliffhanger into Midnight Sun. Yes, people, there is going to be another one. If her editor allows it.    RECAP: Bella and Edward's love turns to lust, pregnancy had nothing to offer the story, Jacob is conveniently disposed of, all other characters fall flat, and the climax is any but.     Borrow it first, get your own opinion, then buy. If your stomach can handle it.
031606792X|3.0|I am not a teenager, in fact I am the mother of a 16-year-old. I first heard about the Twilight saga in Entertainment Weekly. As a writer, an English teacher and an avid reader, I was fascinated. I devoured the first 3 books--absolutely in love with the story and while I found Bella's behavior in New Moon a bit annoying and immature, I took into consideration the fact that the books were written for young adults and at that age they do feel love and heartbreak in an all-consuming way. Yes, Bella is immature, yes, she is fairly one-dimensional. I often thought along the way that Edward couldn't read her mind because there wasn't much going on there to begin with. I was often puzzled as to what he found so intensely attractive about her beyond her unique scent. But I was willing to go along with it because I so enjoyed Edward and Jacob. I had a few ideas as to how Breaking Dawn would play out, but I never imagined Meyer would go in this direction. Bella's pregnancy was ridiculous enough, but Jacob imprinting on the baby went too far. I found Quil and Claire disturbing enough without having to deal with Jacob and Nessie. And can we talk about that name? I think the middle name of Carlie would have been so much better and Charlie and Carlisle were so much more central to Bell'as story than dippy Renee and poorly defined Esme. I wanted Bella to have to choose--but Meyer neatly took that choice away by making it imperative to turn Bella to save her. As for the Volturi--I was really looking forward go a good fight with the Volturi being destroyed. Instead--everyone made nice and only Irinia is killed. As another reviewer wrote, this story ends for me with Eclipse. Breaking Dawn read like it belonged to another story and was written by another writer, An opportunity to write a truly classic and heartbreaking love story was lost and instead everyone lived happily ever after. In the best books, just as in real life, there is no happily ever after. There is choice, there is consequence, there is heartbreak and loss, but if you are truly lucky, there is love.

031606792X|4.0|I'm a 28 year old man who started this series a couple weeks ago not  really knowing that its fanship is almost exclusively made up of  teenage girls.  Well, I like it regardless; it's not outstanding  writing, but the characters are addictive and it makes a decent  fantasy.  I was eagerly anticipating the fourth installment, but with  several fears in mind.    My greatest fear for this book was that it would spend too long  wearing the too worn paths the series had walked before.  Love  triangle.  Angst.  Some reason would appear for Bella to not become a  vampire, or not until the end of the book.  Bella would continue to do  little to distinguish herself but suffer and complain about innocuous  things (parties).  The most interesting cards in Meyer's hands, placed  there when the story was set up in Twilight (such as Bella's  conversion), would be held longer than they should or not be played at  all.    (Spoilers below)    So I, for one, am very happily surprised.  None of my fears came true  in the least.  I much prefer radical changes (Bella having a baby), to  more of the same.  Meyer's played the cards I wanted her to, and let  us enjoy them -- the wedding and honeymoon took up the first part of  the book, and then Bella's experience as a new vampire got ample  space.  In between those pieces, were 200 pages of Jacob's  perspective, which, in spite of previously disliking the Jacob  character, I enjoyed and felt characterized him well.    The radical changes seem to upset many.  But I'm afraid I agree with  the typical negative review of the previous books more than with those  of Breaking Dawn.  I think the changes, though radical, were all  clearly foreshadowed in the previous installments (Rosalie's character  was set up for her part in BD, Quil's imprinting got us ready for  Jacob's, etc).  So I'd like to think that Meyer didn't pull any of  this out of her hat at the last moment.  I personally don't mind the  pieces fitting together too neatly.  That'spart of the fun of  storytelling.    The weakest part, I would say, was the last 200 pages -- the Volturi  conflict.  Well, it's never been a series about violent conflict.  The  violent conflicts seem to pop up towards the end of the books out of  obligation.  Maybe it would have seemed more meaningful to some  readers if major characters died.  Yet I don't think that's exactly  right for this series.  It's not *epic*.
031606792X|5.0|Having read the whole series now, it is obvious that the author has come a long way (for the better) in her writing, not that she was bad to start with. 031606792X|1.0|So much of what I would like to say about Breaking Dawn has already been written in far more succinct words then I have - but I still feel inclined to offer my own review. BAD IDEA. Now they really can be one big, happy family, just like those folks on that ranch in Texas. He used to fantasize about Bella naked and pregnant with his babies, now just see what he's got to look forward to with Nessie after he finishes fathering a couple of her half-siblings! He won't even have to wait that long, because she'll reach maturity by age 7. This just doesn't work on any level, except maybe for incestuous polygamists.\\"    Jacob should have killed himself in shame when his imprinting occurred. At least he would have his dignity. Admittedly, I find the concept of imprinting to be very distasteful under the best of circumstances but this is an abomination.  The very epitome of awful.     Why not Leah or Tanya or anyone, literally ANYONE other then the child of the woman he wanted to spend the rest of his life with just weeks before.  Nothing more convenient then to help raise your future wife.  It makes me literally green with disgust. I can think of countless ways to include Jacob as a permanent member of Bella's family - this is just completely unacceptable and the major part of what ruined this book for me    As a mother - I am sickened. As a reader, I am greatly disillusioned.    Any chance that the real Breaking Dawn comes out next Friday and we were just Group Punked?  I wish I could get a magic clock and stop myself from reading Breaking Dawn. I want to pretend that the series ends at Eclipse

0553589059|2.0|Undertow: by Elizabeth Bear  There are many things I like about the book including the depiction of the city on floats which reminded me of Sausalito back in the 60s. I liked how they would change the city to deal with storms, that seemed like a nifty idea, particularly in places like New Orleans where storms will devastate the low country. And most of all I liked the aliens, except where they are written as the racist \\"noble savage\\".     This brings me to my several struggles with this book. The characters in the book are a sociopathic murderer, a dissociated hacker, a narcissistic conjure man, and several corporate leader types and other indistinguishably similar unpleasant human types. In some cases there are duplicates of these as well. Then we have the noble savage aliens who actually have legitimate issues based on the story. The problem that I had was that the apparent protagonist is the sociopath and I don't invest well with murderers no matter how pretty you shine them up. The secondary characters are equally off-putting with the exception of the aliens.     As a reader it is incredibly difficult to invest in these violent, oppressive persons' issues. These are the people I dislike intensely in real life, the ones who think they can simply violate the rights of everyone else. Determined to finish this book (the first Bear book I've managed to finish) I decided to slough through these issues for the gems that must exist to explain these choices.     I appreciated that she gave a go at Shrodingers Cat and quantum theory even if I didn't quite believe her conclusions about how things work. I didn't appreciate so much the long expository sections where she explained her theories either. However, I determined and muddled through these sections too.     I was feeling good, however, there were only a few pages of book left and...and...well, she contrived to put the alien in a position to discover the bad corporate guys were going to commit genocide and oh no...thenoble savage must save se whole species by killing everyone on board the ship. This was a complete reversal of the alien policy of non-war presented thickly throughout the book. This was the \\"go to\\" human answer of violence, murder, death is the \\"good\\" answer. And in one fell swoop the aliens became humans in froggy costumes doing evil and suddenly I had no one left to root for turning the book into an airborne object of rejection.    SUMMARY: I don't consider a book well written if it pops me out a lot and I had this problem with this book. I noted the overuse of the word \\"oily\\" and it popped me out four times early in the book. I also didn't like the head-hopping quality that kept me from really liking the characters. The selection of unlikable characters coupled to the \\"special gizmo\\" one had stashed on the planet and the \\"special circumstances\\" where one alien must kill a lot of people to save the world - these are trope fantasy and even though this is positioned as SF - it is, in my opinion, really a dressed up fantasy novel and the slide is magic.

031606792X|5.0|I'm shocked by all the negativity directed at this book.  Who did people think they were reading, Margaret Atwood?  Of course everything was going to come out roses and sunshine.  The reason that this is a good novel in its genre is that while you are reading it, you're not always so sure that everything will work out.   Is it a monster baby?  Will the wolves and vampires destroy one another?  Did Alice and Jasper run away from their family because Alice saw no hope?  Will Edward and Bella turn out to be another Romeo and Juliet, i.e. dead?  These questions keep the reader turning the page even though the rational mind already knows the ending.    In this book the key ingredient was the love for a child.  We already knew that Bella and Edward loved one another beyond the norm.  It was a smart decision on the author's part to shift the focus to another kind of love.  It is this love that allows Bella to come into her own.  Meyer seems to be playing with the theme of a mother's love and fear for her children bringing her great strength (e.g. mothers lifting cars to save their children,) as it was fear for Renesmee that allowed Bella the will to control her new power, not fear for Edward.  Bella was prepared time and again to sacrifice herself for her daughter; Renesmee's survival was the most important thing.  But perhaps this theme is either not appropriate or appreciated by younger readers (this is YA lit, after all.)    Many were made uncomfortable by the pairing of Bella's age along with marriage and motherhood.  I do not think that the author is saying, \\"Hey, high school grads, go find yourselves a hot man, pop out a kid, and forget about your own lives.\\"  This is fantasy fiction.  Bella had to be this young age for motherhood if the theme of parental love was to be introduced.  Besides if you want to complain about inappropriateness, let's be bothered by the fact that someone in his nineties (Edward) was hot for a teenager.  Now no one is bothered by that fact (or it they were, they probably didn't bother reading the series).  Why, because it's sci-fi where real world issues like age don't matter as much.  I found the \\"traditional\\" marriage a bit quaint, but certainly not enough to ruin the story.    All in all, I've enjoyed spending the last two days in this world.  The book was crack-lit (i.e. literature that you know is not the best, but it's just so addictive, you can't put it down,) just like the other three.  That's why, when I pulled my head out, that I was so shocked all negative reviews.

But I found myself really enjoying it most of the way through.  There were some parts I found silly (naming the baby Renesmee/Nessie - ouch!), but I didn't find the story nearly as bad as so many others apparently have.  And I loved kick-butt, sexy vampire Bella.  I was satisfied at the conclusion, and smiling when I closed the book.

031606792X|5.0|I thought this was the perfect end to Bella and Edward's story.  It was full of emotion and sacrifice (despite reviews to the contrary) and it really sucked me in.  It shocked me because the turn the story took caught me completely by surprise, and I like that Stephenie can create another turn when you'd think she'd pretty much exhausted the whole angst-filled relationship thread.  To be honest, i thought that this book was mainly going to focus on Bella coping with losing her humanity and then her new body/instincts. And it was so much different than I thought! There are so many different story lines and plot developments that I'm surprised she fit it all into one book and made it feel complete.  I think she did an absolutely amazing job.      In reply to the ranting reviews...  ****SPOILER ALERT****  Some people think the Jake/Nellie thing was a cop out because Stephenie just wanted Jake to find happiness away from Bella.  And that might partially be true, but I felt more like Bella was passing her humanity on and that's what Jake was truly connected to.  (Remember the whole soul mates in a normal world thing?  So her soul moved on to a body he was allowed to love...)    Someone said something about \\"lucky Bella getting it all, husband, happy friend, and a baby\\" and it took so much pain and sacrifice for that to come about that there was very little feeling of \\"luck\\" about it.  I felt like I was fighting for that happiness right along with her.    And then there was the whole \\"married at 18?!?!  how could this happen?\\"  And that was where the book was headed from day one so I don't see how thats a surprise, and I'm a little shocked at all the reviews railing against that.  I'm in no way a supporter of early marriage, but there are circumstances (such as the supernatural) that kind of put the relationship into a realm of its own.    There's so much more than that, but instead of trying to turn this book into some statement about female empowerment or lack thereof,I prefer to just enjoy the story for what it is: a love story.  Whether thats between lovers, friends, or family.  Because that's obviously what all these books are about.      It does a great job of conveying emotions and the tense scenes had me nearly screaming.  I've never been so sucked into a series before.  Ever.  And I feel like this is an ending I can live with, because anything else would have felt like she was straying from the message she's been trying to make throughout the entire series.  (That whole love conquers all thing...)    I highly recommend reading all these books!
031606792X|2.0|As a huge fan of Twilight, I found Breaking Dawn a messy attempt at wrapping up the series. The previous 3 books focused on the main characters. Readers developed a good understanding of each character, their personalities, relationships, etc. Breaking Dawn seems to have thrown all that knowledge away. While the book itself wasn't horrible, it was mediocre at best. I admit that I found many parts suspenseful, but it wasn't suspenseful in a positive way. There are many twists in the book that make you go \\"Did she REALLY just write that?\\" followed by \\"Oh God, she did.\\" The suspense was wondering how the story could possibly end without leaving readers completely baffled by what had just happened.    <Slight Spoilers Start> The first few chapters were in typical Twilight mood, but then Breaking Dawn quickly turns into something else that barely resembles the same mood or flow found in the other 3 books. I found it hard to believe that Meyer moved the story so far away from Bella and Edward's relationship to the relationship between the baby and everyone else. It was no longer a story about a girl in love with a vampire troubled with forbidden love - there was hardly any deep storyline about Edward and Bella's relationship in the entire book.     Characters were so out of place and it seemed like they were no longer acting like themselves, the only one showing some consistency was Jacob. But then with Jacob imprinting on the baby threw that out the window. It would have made more sense just to have Jacob admit to have imprinted on Bella (what I originally believed) and have him leave La Push/Forks for good. Edward as a father didn't seem to have any connection with his daughter, and who knows what Bella was thinking the entire book.     The final showdown was quite a letdown as well. I would have hoped that at least 1 major character died because of the Volturi vs. Cullens epic battle, but I guess not.    Overall I felt a little cheap after reading the book. There weretoo many twists that were incredibly cheesy that it was hard to try and forget about them. It's too bad...

B0002F6AH0|5.0|I mentioned to one of my friends when I ordered this series that I wanted to learn more about World War II. I had always known that World War II was terrible, but watching The World at War, I realised that I had not known the extent of how terrible it truly was. This experience has had a significant impact on me, and is not one that I will forget quickly.<br /><br />The scale of World War II was staggering. 50 million people lost their lives, including 20 million Russians. Although the total figure varies according to the methodology used, anywhere from 9 to 11 million Jews, Poles, Slavs, gypsies, gay men, political dissidents, people with disabilities and others were murdered by the SS and their supporters, most in the concentration and extermination camps of Auschwitz, Dachau and the like, names which have become synonymous with unspeakable horror and infamy. Whole cities (or large parts thereof), such as Warsaw, Dresden, Nagasaki and St Petersburg, to name just a few, were razed, acts that involved the indiscriminate slaughter of thousands of innocent civilians. The World at War covers the devastation waged on these, and other, cities.<br /><br />One thing I always remember from when I first watched this series, as a young boy in the 70s, is the opening music by Carl Davis, which is perfectly suited to the subject matter. Another thing I always remember about the opening is the very effective use of the various human faces fading into each other, and being engulfed by flames. I especially remember the face of the little boy.<br /><br />Some of the episodes I found the most gripping include the following: The Final Solution Parts 1 and 2; Warrior; Morning: June - August 1944 (about the Allied invasion of Normandy); Occupation: Holland 1940 - 1944; Nemesis: Germany February - May 1945; and Hitler's Germany: Total War 1939 - 1945. Of these, the episodes I found the most disturbing were The Final Solution Parts 1 and 2, about the Holocaust, and Warrior, an episode about soldiers and battle, which includes uncompromising and confronting archival footage, such as a scene showing a group of European soldiers unceremoniously tossing a comrade's corpse onto a stretcher and then into an open grave, and footage of the flame throwers the US soldiers used. I remember thinking when I watched the movie Saving Private Ryan, which also depicts the use of the flame throwers, that most people would be hesitant to use such cruel measures on a nest of cockroaches, let alone other human beings. I also found the images at the beginning of disc 5 particularly chilling, such as a young girl in The Netherlands standing under an anti-Semitic sign reading `Voor Joden verboden' - `Prohibited for Jews'.<br /><br />One of the most notable aspects of the series is the inclusion of many fascinating, and unbiased, interviews with people from both the Allied and Axis nations, including the following:<br /><br />- Interviews with Traudl Junge, Hitler's secretary<br /><br />- An interview with Richard Boch, an apparently reluctant SS officer, in which he recounts a conversation he had with a colleague whilst witnessing children who were hiding under piles of clothing being flung into the `showers' during a late-night gassing: `argh, I'm going to be sick, I can't stand this. Oh my', I said, `Karl, I've never seen anything like it in my life, it's absolutely terrible'. His friend later replied `you do get used to anything in time'.<br /><br />- An interview with Lord Avon, Foreign Minister of the British parliament at the time, in which he comments on the persecution of the Jews: `as the war progressed, some horrifying reports began to come out, and at first, it was very difficult naturally, to assess their accuracy, and they were indeed so horrible that it was hard to believe they could be true'.<br /><br />- An interview with a German translator, Hildegard Wortmann, in which she talks about hearing of Hitler's suicide: `I was so disappointed that he was such alousy, such a rotten coward, he had started the war, millions of dead people, everything was lost, in ruins, then he wanted to give up all responsibility and he just committed suicide, just like his mouthpiece Goebbels, I still hear Goebbels in my ears, do you want the total war, the yelling'.<br /><br />I have only a few minor criticisms of the series, for example, I was somewhat surprised that Josef Mengele, the despicable Nazi `doctor' responsible for performing monstrous experiments on sets of twins, was never specifically mentioned. However, the series overall is so brilliant that any minor criticisms cannot detract from the 5-star rating it so manifestly deserves. It is undoubtedly the definitive documentary of World War II, and you could most definitely not buy any other Word War II documentary and acquire a solid knowledge of the events that unfolded. It is the most expensive item I have purchased on Amazon to date, but it was worth every cent.<br /><br />The dark nightmare that was World War II embodied the most ghastly evil and blackest period that mankind has ever known, a reality accentuated by every episode of The World at War. The extremes of carnage, destruction and human suffering that the War entailed must never be forgotten, not in 50 years, not in 100 years, not in 500 years. The Holocaust, in particular, was utterly demonic, and although the ovens of Auschwitz, the most notorious death camp of all, are forever silenced, much of its physical entity remains as the Russians found it in January 1945, a reminder to the world of the depraved brutality that racism and bigotry can ultimately lead to. This can be summed up no better than by the powerful and indelible words which end The Final Solution - Part 2: `The ruins of Auschwitz are more than a memorial. As long as there is political intolerance, religious bigotry, racial prejudice, they are a warning. A warning that we all have a responsibility to see - that no-one builds another Auschwitz'.ons of dead people, everything was lost, in ruins, then he wanted to give up all responsibility and he just committed suicide, just like his mouthpiece Goebbels, I still hear Goebbels in my ears, do you want the total war, the yelling'.     I have only a few minor criticisms of the series, for example, I was somewhat surprised that Josef Mengele, the despicable Nazi `doctor' responsible for performing monstrous experiments on sets of twins, was never specifically mentioned. However, the series overall is so brilliant that any minor criticisms cannot detract from the 5-star rating it so manifestly deserves. It is undoubtedly the definitive documentary of World War II, and you could most definitely not buy any other Word War II documentary and acquire a solid knowledge of the events that unfolded. It is the most expensive item I have purchased on Amazon to date, but it was worth every cent.     The dark nightmare that was World War II embodied the most ghastly evil and blackest period that mankind has ever known, a reality accentuated by every episode of The World at War. The extremes of carnage, destruction and human suffering that the War entailed must never be forgotten, not in 50 years, not in 100 years, not in 500 years. The Holocaust, in particular, was utterly demonic, and although the ovens of Auschwitz, the most notorious death camp of all, are forever silenced, much of its physical entity remains as the Russians found it in January 1945, a reminder to the world of the depraved brutality that racism and bigotry can ultimately lead to. This can be summed up no better than by the powerful and indelible words which end The Final Solution - Part 2: `The ruins of Auschwitz are more than a memorial. As long as there is political intolerance, religious bigotry, racial prejudice, they are a warning. A warning that we all have a responsibility to see - that no-one builds another Auschwitz'.

031606792X|1.0|(MAJOR SPOILER ALERT!) I was so excited when I started reading this. And up until the end of Bella's first part, I was mostly alright with it. And then Bella ends up pregnant! Twilight was amazing, as was New Moon and Eclipse, but this one left me feeling more than just disappointed, but disturbed. I didn't see it in the way that most people did--- Stephanie Meyer's supporting teenage pregnancy. I saw it as a disturbing view on life.   What I thought Stephanie was saying was that if you marry a super-hot guy and move into a cottage with him and have a baby with him, nothing will go wrong. Your best friend disapproves of your choices? Big deal, he'll get over it, because everything's perfect. That same best friend \\"imprints\\" on your newborn daughter? You'll get over it after awhile, and see how good it is, because everything's perfect. The pregnancy itself almost kills you? Big deal, I'll live, because everything's perfect. There can never be any problems with your life, because, hey, everything's perfect. You don't tell teenagers that whenever something like that happens to you (dismissing the sci-fi fantasy stuff), it will all turn out all right because everything's perfect. Sure, you want them to have a positive outlook, but if I wanted to read a book about how nothing bad ever happens \\"because everything's perfect\\", I would've read a dollar-store romance novel.

031606792X|5.0|This book was tastefully written and completely in line with the rest of the fantasy stories that Stephenie Meyer has produced. I think that people who are criticizing the death out of this book have played up the other novels too much, had too much time to fantasize about their own ending to Ms. Meyer's story.  Yes, HER story.  So Bella gets her husband and her baby and her best friend and her family, and it all has a neat little bow and she even gets to keep her human family.  Somehow, she gets to keep and have everything and it's not good enough.  Somehow, SM wove a story in such a way that was creative and imaginative and thought out enough to tie up all loose ends, answer all questions and make everything turn out happily ever after.  That seems like it would be a very difficult thing to do, but she did it.  Cinderella and Sleeping Beauty ended the same way, and they are classics.  It may not be YOUR idea of a perfect ending, but it's not a reason the bash the hell out of the book.  It was written in the same descriptive, warm way that her other books were written and it puts you right there with the characters.  No one loves her books because of the \\"extremely thought out and complicated\\" storyline, they all love her books because they love the characters and the feeling of knowing them all personally and being right there with them.  This book follows the same rules, even though it may not have the ending that you were anticipating.

I felt like she poured more effort into writing those two.  After reading The Host, I was expecting so much more.  This book didn't read like a Meyer book for me and that disheartens me.

0321344758|5.0|I read this book when I was still an amateur programmer. I since earned a university degree in computer science and am a professional web developer, and I still use the advice given in this book. User friendliness and value to the customer (which go hand in hand) are the most important lessons any programmer can learn.    This book has a (seemingly) intuitive thesis: web sites should be designed with the user in mind. More particularly, the harder one has to work to figure out how to use something, the worse it's designed; web site use should be obvious (or at least self-explanatory). I say \\"seemingly\\" intuitive because it ought to be intuitive but a lot of programmers, especially inexperienced ones, forget that.    While this book is geared towards entry-level people, it will serve as an important reminder to seasoned professionals of the basics of good design and user-friendliness. With that said, I think that new designers (who are most prone to poor usability design) and people who feel they have not been designing with the user in mind will benefit the most from reading this book, and much of the advice in this book will be useful even years later.

031606792X|2.0|To properly review this book, I have to go back to the first three . . .    Twilight - the beauty of Twilight was the beauty of first love, especially love that has so many challenges to overcome.  In Twilight Bella was a strong character - leaving home, starting at a new school, and trying to make sense of a first love with a very complicated \\"boy.\\"  Stephenie Meyer actually had me believing in the possibility of vampires, even though this is not my genre at all.  I honestly feel she should have stopped with Twilight; it is always better to leave your readers wondering, \\"Will she spend eternity with Edward, or not?\\" rather than proceed with the next three installments, which got progressively worse.  New Moon - I can't adequately express how much I disliked this book.  I understand why Edward left, but for Bella to curl up into a pathetic ball was truly sad.  All of us experience loss- whether it is a first love, or family, or health, but the message sent was it is okay to wallow in self-despair and lose yourself.  I also objected to the fact that she used Jacob (similar to the scene in Twilight where she \\"flirts\\" with him to gain information).  I don't particularly care for Jacob as a character, but the manner in which she used him for her selfish purposes once again shows a character of weak moral and intellectual value.  She loses interest in her academic side to pursue trouble in order to hear Edward's voice - great plan.  The Volturi are beyond description in terms of ridiculousness - any belief engendered in the reality of vampires was completely blown apart by their existence in the book.  Eclipse - Bella has made her choice - right?  Wrong!  She spends the bulk of this terrible book alternately pining for Jacob or trying to get Edward to have sex with her.  She sneers at marriage, yet tries to get him to turn her into a vampire for all eternity.  Jacob is truly a reprehensible character in this book.  I personally do not find emotional manipulation sexy, and lost tons of respect for Bella and Jacob as she waffled between the two men, and he used any method he could to sway her.  Any strength or dignity she had in the first novel completely disappears.  Which leads us to . . .  Breaking Dawn - Bella goes through with marriage for the right reasons?  No, mostly to have sex with Edward.  I fear that most people (sadly myself included) read this book simply for the sex scenes that Meyer has been leading up to since Twilight.  Rather voyeuristic, and weird. The whole \\"Jacob's perspective\\" is ridiculous, and quite frankly confusing.
