031606792X|4.0|To start off with, this book was not what I was expecting but I'm not about to be overly critical to the close-minded who are bashing this book from every angle. This book was well written in many ways, there some spots with humor and from Chapter 24 on I couldn't put it down. If you are open-minded to take the awkward and surprising moments in stride and look at the context around them I'm sure you would agree it is a decent book. Yes, I will admit that some of the concepts are seen as horrible but you have to look at the things around it.     1st Point: Pregnancy and marriage at 18.   - Yes, this book makes the two seem like something every teenager should do. But the sad and honest truth is that pregnancy is common place among teenagers today so I don't know why it's so shocking to see it in a book. For me, I don't agree with it but I'm not about to freak out over it appearing in a book.     2nd Point: Renesmee \\"Nessie\\"      - Ok, alot of people of seething over this choice of name. If you read far enough you will see that Bella is not fond of the name Nessie either. You all are treating it like her full name is: Nessie. Her real name is Renesmee. People are attacking this as well. I think its creative that SM choose Renesmee for a first name and Carlie for the middle name. It works the same with fathers naming their sons: Frank Sr and Frank Jr. What is the big deal?     3rd Point: Jacob imprinting on a baby      - I can understand the freak outs over this but there is no need to be making comments that he is a pedophile, he's not and SM doesn't portray him that way. He even states, when Bella is pissed of at him when she finds out. He says I quote: \\"It was involuntary\\" He didn't choose it and you'll also note when Rosalie is holding Renesmee BEFORE the imprinting he wants to kill it. Later on in the chapter he also says \\"You know I don't think of her that way! Do you think Edward would have let me live this long if I did? All I want is for her to be safe and happy--is that so bad? So different from what you want?\\" This whole issue is just plain over-reaction.     4th Point: Edward asking Jacob to sleep with her      - At first glance this is shocking but think about it in context. Bella is dying. Edward ONLY says this out of desperation. She wants a baby, and you will all be surprised when it happens to you how even if you didn't want to have a baby how you become attached to it while you are carrying, like Bella. SM has 3 children she is more than qualified to know the bond between mother and child. Honestly, how many you can sit there and say that you when it came down to it that if someone you loved deeply were dying and there was any possible way, no matter how ridiculous and unfathomable it was that the loved one could be saved that you wouldn't try that one thing no matter what it was? When it comes to people we love deeply we would be willing to try anything to keep them safe and/or save their life. You would feel regret afterwards for not trying that one thing if it were possible. Edward was trying to save her. And as for the way he was acting throughout, put yourself in his shoes, wouldn't you react the same way if you had to watch your loved one die right in front of your eyes and being unable to save them?     5th Point: Bella becoming a vampire     - That has been what she has wanted since the very beginning. SM is giving her what she wants. In mythology in our own world vampires are portrayed as strong and unbeatable. If you think about it, iff SM would have kept Bella's clumsy side we would all be like, why? It wouldn't make sense in all SM's descriptions of vampires in Twilight, New Moon, and Eclipse to keep Bella clumsy. And again, BELLA WANTS TO BE A VAMPIRE. As for her choice to attend at least one semester of college, she's human. Our wants change alot, its not unheard of.    6th Point:      - If you think about it, many people out there like Science Fiction novels, movies, and tv shows. If Breaking Dawnwas never made into a book and it made into a movie instead, NOONE would be complaing.    Finally, everyone is making the book out to be a mockery and making jokes about its content. I think it was a well-written, extremely creative book altogether. From Chapter 24 to the end was honestly my favorite part because of the covens coming together and the whole Volturi issue. That's good writing. I challenge each and everyone out there criticizing this book, to sit down and try to be as creative as SM. I'm a writer myself, an amateur at best, but still a writer. Believe me I've tried to be as creative as SM but to no avail. The way she took concepts from her other books and expanded on them in Breaking Dawn and kepping the flow going fairly smooth and tying everything together was very well done.     I think everyone needs to calm down and just look at the book in a different light. Yes, I understand that every book as its critics and people who hate the book, its very obvious in this case, but an open mind will take the good with the bad and make an honest opinion. I think the whole issue mostly is just the SURPRISE that this book brought. I don't think any of us were expecting the content. As for the people saying she was just cramming everything into a final book, SM actually said that it is the final book, BUT it is the final book from Bella's POV, she said there might be more but written in someone elses POV. If that is what she was thinking she wouldn't be cramming all this into one book. If you think about it, she is pleasing what I think many of us were expecting or wanting in the end: Bella and Edward together, Bella becoming a vampire (which may I add that SM was leading up to in New Moon where Aros was curious what her ability would be once a vampire because she was able to block him), and Jacob ending up happy. Everything SM said came true, obviously not the way that many hoped but she still did it. I applaud her work on this piece and wait anxiously for other publications from her.

How this movie rated 3-stars is incomprehensible to me, it's no better than 1-star.

031606792X|1.0|I've been anticipating such a disaster since I heard the supposed spoilers, but not really believing it would happen. The other three books were so good, it would take a train wreck of titanic proportions to ruin it. Alas, the rumors were true. A smashingly awful end to an otherwise enjoyable series. And now to the important part: why Breaking Dawn was such a colossal mess.    DISCLAIMER: Extensively long and ranting review to follow.    *SPOILERS*    1. There was actually no plot. More so the illusion of a plot. I can summarize the book thusly and save you some money:    Book 1, Bella - Has a wedding. Looks hot as usual but fails to grasp the extent of her gorgeousness. Has a gooey honeymoon, complete with destroyed headboards and feathers. Fails to use protection for (obvious?) reasons and lo and behold becomes pregnant with beloved Edward's demon spawn. Becomes a maniacal mother off a Lifetime movie.    Book 2, Jacob - Sees Bella's wedding. Is jealous/miserable/annoyed/angry. Find her pregnant upon her return from her honeymoon. Is jealous/miserable/annoyed/angry. Howls a lot. Eventually gets the hots for the newborn little beast instead. Is suddenly all buddy buddy with beloved Edward.    Book 3, Bella - Is a crazy mother. Becomes a vampire. Marvels at how damn awesome she is, now that her true mediocrity is hidden by her \\"rocking bod\\". Has a lot of sex. Worries over the hybrid a lot. Prepares to fight, but finds that no fighting is necessary. Has a lot of sex. The End.    2. Edward and Bella have a child. Besides the fact that the ENTIRE book revolves around this fact, besides the fact that the entire atmosphere created by the previous three books is shattered with it, besides the fact that Bella loses any shred of personality she once had after \\"motherhood\\", and besides the fact that she seems possessed by the honor of carrying beloved Edward's mini-me and nothing else, it simply makes no sense. I've toyed with every possible explanation suggested, and none ofthem are satisfying. Frankly, I feel a tad insulted that readers are just supposed to swallow whatever an author puts out there, simply because it is \\"fantasy\\". We deserve a world where things fit together, and Bella's pregnancy fits in nowhere.     3. Renesmee Carlie is a dreadful name. There, I said it.    4. Rosalie is little too \\"Hand that Rocks the Cradle\\" for my taste. What ever happened to the compassion she suddenly revealed in Eclipse? She's gone psycho. As opposed to the other members of the Cullen family, who are mere shadows and bad impressions of the characters they used to be. (Jazz?? really?)    5. Leah apparently has a big role to play in this book. Oh wait, never mind, she doesn't.    6. Hey guys, look, a big climactic fight scene! Oh wait, never mind, just more poorly written vampire lovin' that is completely contradictory to the way things were initially portrayed.    7. Bella is even more of a jerk as a vampire than she was as a human. Now she finally knows she's hot, wants to crush things all the time, and is a bit of a show off. But at least she's as dull as she always was.    8. The whole \\"What Do I Tell My Parent's Problem\\" is nonexistent. Renee seems content with a phone call from her daughter every couple of years or so. And Charlie seems pretty cool with his daughter becoming a bloodsucking monster so long as he has a new fishing set to play around with.    9. Come to think of it, NONE of the potential issues that were mentioned in previous books seem to become real problems. Is Bella a crazed bloodthirsty wild newborn? Nope, she breezes through it. Are her parents devastated by the loss of their daughter? Nope, they barely care. Does Edward find her any less attractive? Hahahahahaha *chuckles*. Is any human sensation or desire lost after becoming a vampire? Figures that they would be even better. There were literally NO sacrifices Bella had to make to be with her soul mate. Everything just miraculously fell into place, flawlessly, and with no effort whatsoever. Talk about luck.    10. Jacob imprinting on Nessie is too convenient and goes against how Jacob was represented. He fell in love with Bella the human way and is against imprinting as it takes away yet another of his choices. Wouldn't it make sense for him to be the only one who gets to CHOOSE who he loves? I'm sorry, but this plot twist was one of the most unappreciated of all for me.    11. Jacob is not immortal. He can slow his aging to let his imprint catch up, but he will grow old and die eventually. But will Nessie? And at what age will she stop growing? When she is Jacob's age? What will happen then? Will they both stay frozen, so that Jacob can watch the rest of his family age and have children and die off?    I like happy endings. I don't mind that Jacob imprinted on a baby. I was glad Bella finally became a vampire. I didn't find the birth scene unbearably gruesome. The only problem I had was the lack of intensity and passion, personality in the characters, and the total absence of substantial and logical (yes even fantasy books have to have rules) plot. As a stand alone book, it's so-so, but it is simply ridiculously out of place amongst its predecessors. I hardly even cared what happened to anyone. I will not bash SM, I will merely mourn the feeling I had when getting lost in the previous books, because it was crushed with the coming of Breaking Dawn.    Finally, for those of you who think I am taking this way too seriously for a YA vampire novel, I forked over $16 for 768 pages of unnecessary tree death, and when this is the outcome, I think I have the right to be chagrined.    Ah well. If you are a disgruntled ex-fan like me, you can still console yourself with this truth - no matter how bad your life gets, Bella's will always be better.

031606792X|2.0|To avoid writing what I have been reading over and over again I will just say it's a disappointment. I sat there after reading the book wondering what had just happened. It was not only out of place, but just plain bad.
031606792X|3.0|Well...I must say this is one of the strangest finales I have ever read. I am a die-hard Twilight fan; I waited in line at my local bookstore at midnight to get my book then raced home to read it. All the while I was reading, I was not only utterly confused but I was wondering what had happened while she wrote the book. Stephenie Meyer told us readers that this was the ending she had pictured for Edward and Bella since she began the series, but I ,on the other hand, most definitely did not expect this. They have their wonderful little wedding and they are happy and blissful on \\"Isle Esme\\" and that was no surprise, but then Ms. Meyer ripped away all the passion and love out of their wedding night for us. That was something I was most looking forward to: a short intimate scene about their first time. Edward and Bella's relationship was always defined by those little moments that made our hearts race, and made us wish we were in Bella's shoes but there was a heartbreaking absence of these scenes in Breaking Dawn. Instead, all we see is right before and right after.   I can't even begin to talk about Bella's pregnancy. We see WAY before Bella does that she is pregnant, but while I was reading I was thinking \\"No way, this can't happen. There is no way that a vampire can get anyone pregnant.\\" But, apparently there is. This was just weird, and it was inconsistent with the author's own words(she said that vampires had no bodily fluids so therefore there would be no sperm). I suffered through reading Jacob's point of view, watching Bella be killed by the thing inside her and I was utterly disgusted by the delivery. I also thought that that was a very strange place to switch points of view again. Then she names the baby girl \\"Renesmee\\".I read the name three times and still thought that I hadn't gotten it right, I thought \\"there's no way she would ever name a child something like Renesmee.\\"I was yet again wrong. So the pregnancy thing just really threw me and ticked me off. Ireally thought it was unnecessary and a stupid thing to add to the story.    Now, Bella as a newborn was probably the best thing because it gave most readers what they wanted, Bella changed, and Meyer did a very nice job describing the process with excellent word choice and imagery. But when she woke to find that Jacob had imprinted on the baby, that just seemed wrong. How do you explain that to someone you are destined to be with? \\"Yeah, well, I was totally and utterly in love with your mom and often fantasized about her. We were going to kill you by ripping you out of your mother but instead you were born. So now I'm settling with you...\\"THAT would be one awkward conversation.   The conflict with the Volturi was what we were all expecting, but it was pretty pointless. NOTHING happened, they came, they talked, they left. End of story. Alice saw it coming but then she ditches the whole family with Jasper. It was very entertaining to read about all the vampires that are their friends but I was horribly disappointed to see that Meyer virtually removed Alice from the story from pages 200 to 650. She couldn't see the baby so she locked herself in a closet all the time. Alice was always one of my favorite characters and her disappearance from the story really made me sad.   All in all, I believe that Stephenie Meyer is a wonderful writer and story teller and I LOVED the first three installments of the series but I believe that she really let herself and all her fans down with this one. I understand that she wanted to leave no loose ends, and to tie everything up nicely, but she did not have to go about it in the fashion that she did. The \\"bow\\" that she tied around the story to bring it all together was totally unrealistic and broke the connection that most of us readers had with the story by tying every one of there stories into the same one. There were so many things she could have done to end the story for all of them and answer all of our questions but she did not doit in an entertaining way. I also thought that the character development that had taken place in the first three novels was absent in this one and made the story much less interesting. So, even if you LOVE Stephenie Meyer or the Twilight Saga, I honestly would not recommend this finale to you.

031606792X|4.0|The title is self explanatory but after just finishing the book and reading a few reviews I think there is a lot people are missing.   BD is VERY different from the other three books. Not that hard to figure out    Baby Nessie- What I saw was unsafe sex gave you babies.- Granted in this case no one has ever heard of vampires having children but the logic is actually sound if you think about human procreation.  The term \\"my biological clock is ticking\\" only applies to females.- Then to apply normal rules to the darker nature of BD, sex with a vampire produces a baby much worst than any other.  The name was terrible though Ill concede to that.     Jake and Nessie- This isnt pedophilia.  In imprinting you are whatever that person needs you to be. So Jacob isnt going around thinking inappropriate thoughts about the child all day. It comes up a lot in the book simply because Edward and Bella know that when the time comes he'll be her perfect man due too this relationship and that bothers them because, like most protective parents, they cant see their little girl with anyone. Till then he's just the babysitter, big brother, best friend, etc.. It is an odd plot twist though.      Point is that the book really isn't bad if you can stretch the edges of the fairytale and see the darkness of reality in your utopia.

031606792X|5.0|Breaking Dawn was very different from the first three in the series which is why I think this book has gotten such harsh reviews. some of the things about the book are...    a) The first and probably most obvious reason of why it's so different was because it dealt with much more mature issues then the first three books did, but I think this is only to be expected. The series grew as Bella grew mentally and emotionally so it was completely understandable for the series to change like this when Bella was also so drastically changing.     b) I was a little doubtful about the book towards the beginning once Bella had found out she was pregnant. I know many people did not like this because Meyer had established at the beginning of the series that vampires could not conceive, but I think the way she wrote it and handled it made it work.     c) Bella seemed to get everything at the end of the book which a lot of people found unrealistic and ridiculous but Bella has throughout the series gone through quite a lot of pain both mentally and physically. She did not know that everything would turn out ok and she had to make many hard decisions in the process. The happy ending was just Meyer's way of tying up loose ends on a happy note.      d) Renesmee was a very controversial character and Jacob imprinting on her made it even worse. I did have problems with that character but towards the end I did begin to like her. Jacob imprinting on her was not sick or wrong and in a way it had to happen. Jacob was in love with Bella but he never imprinted on her, so instead he imprinted on her daughter, her own flesh and blood, a part of her. It made sense at least to me. It would not have seemed right for Jacob to imprint suddenly on some stranger; he was too much in love with Bella for that to have seemed right. Instead he imprinted on a part of Bella. He was in love with Bella because of that small part (Renesmee) and once Renesmee was no longer a part of Bella Jacob was no longer in love with her. I don't know if that was the way Meyer intended it but that's how I saw it.    All in all I really thought Breaking Dawn was an amazing book, but it was very different. Many people were expecting a book on the lines of Twilight New Moon and Eclipse but that was impossible. There were too many different aspects in Breaking Dawn that hadn't existed in the first 3 books for Breaking Dawn to be similar to them. Meyer needed to give Breaking Dawn a twist so that the books didn't start to sound repetitive so she did. I refuse to compare this book to any of the first three because it is such a different book and there for I can't really compare it. I liked Breaking Dawn because it was Breaking Dawn and to me Meyer is still an amazing writer.

031606792X|5.0|I think this book only shows what happens after all that \\"happily ever after\\" thing, what usually doesnt happen. When people want to have sex without always having to be romantic, or misterious. Thats called desire.  Theres also the routine. You get used to the one youre married to.  And then, one day, suddenly you wake up and you want desperatly to have a baby. Because you realize that the one you have at your side is the one you love, and that it would be wonderful to have a kid with him/her, to create a new life that is a result of your love. This is just my opinion. I enjoyed the book very much. I dont think that this is about the same kind of love Twilight was. So, get over it and enjoy this new perspective.

031606792X|5.0|Like the endings of other fantasy sagas, I expected a happy ending.  We saw it to a greater or lesser degree in Harry Potter, Lord of the Rings, Star Wars, Dune, The Dark Materials and others.      I wondered often, while I watched the countdown to Breaking Dawn's release, what Stephenie would do with the characters and the story.  I foresaw the basics - Bella would become a vampire, she would choose Edward, they would marry, we would learn her gift as a vampire, and something would occur with Jacob that would make all the characters okay with each other.  Happily Ever After.    But I truly didn't expect the extent of twists and turns that took place in Breaking Dawn.  It was far more supernatural and far more emotional than I had expected.  What is most odd about this is that I should have learned from the previous two books because the events in them were completely unexpected for me as well.  It took me a bit to accept the events of New Moon especially.  But the wonderful ones - the trip to Italy and the ultimate return - kept my love for the story alive.  It was when, however, I really started to know and understand the characters of these books that I let go of what I wanted and needed and learned to really just enjoy their story.      This is why I loved Breaking Dawn.  The story went in a direction I did not expect.  And I loved Stephenie more for it.  It would be a bit silly, I think, to be upset by the supernatural and unbelievable aspects of it.  After all, her vampires sparkle.  I love that she had the guts to take this elsewhere and create new story lines and new things to contemplate.  I checked my logic at the door when I really got into Twilight, so why would it suddenly come back in for Breaking Dawn?    I have now read the story twice - I couldn't help it.  I found so many scenes unbelievably touching and I wanted to experience them again.  I completely understood Bella's instincts on motherhood as well as Edward's and Jacob's reaction to what was happening to her.  I hated leaving Bella's perspective for any period of time, but I found I really loved seeing Edward from new eyes.  And I knew, especially the second time through, that we needed that other viewpoint to really understand what happens to Bella and Jacob at that point in the story.  It was necessary.    I actually love the characters more now than I ever did before which is impressive as I was a huge fan from the beginning.  I reveled in Bella's excitement in the last part of the book.  It left me smiling and sighing along with her.      I am very happy with the end of this story.  I can tell that Stephenie has set up something more for Jacob and Ness.  And I love that.  I'm looking forward to more.
031606792X|5.0|I would like to thank Stephenie Meyer for creating a wonderful series and ending it with humor and emotion in Breaking Dawn. Bella was not out of character when you consider that she was two years older than when the series started and she was married. 031606792X|1.0|Some people can overlook the flaws because the work is a piece of fiction. Yes, fiction is about lying, but to be a good liar you have a sense of continuity. Anything that tosses the reader's out of the reality you create isn't good. If you have to strain to believe what the narrator is telling you, if you have to turn off your critical functions instead of having the work engage them, when you sit there wondering what the writer was thinking (imprinting on an infant?), then the book has failed.

031606792X|3.0|The Twilight series is sort of like a guilty pleasure for me. It took a great deal of effort for me to close my lit mind and read the first one without zeroing in on issues, but once I managed to, I read New Moon and Eclipse right after for the sake of the romance.<br /><br />-SPOILERS-<br /><br />I read a lot of the reviews for BD and my opinion relatively coincides. I think where we differ... I didn't find Jacob imprinting on Renesmee to be creepy. Meyer really drove home the fact that the wolves don't see younger versions of their imprinted loved ones sexually until the object of their imprinting grows to maturity. Like, he treats Nessie as if he were the world's best big brother, not like a pedophile.<br /><br />I was also not really thrown off by the pregnancy itself. Sure, it was a little out there, and it doesn't make sense that the vampire venom wouldn't have killed off Edward's sperm, but I set the inconsistency aside and continued to read the story for how it was, regardless of broken rules.<br /><br />What really got on my nerves, however, was the anti-climatic ending. There's nothing I hate more than that, and it's the same issue with the Host - there was so much build up about how the V were going to attack and cause a lot of damage, and that there would be a great deal of suffering - yet nothing happens at the end except for Irina being the unfortunate unlucky one (not that anyone except Tanya cares) and a lot of \\"I'm sorry :(\\".<br /><br />At the very LEAST I would have enjoyed seeing the V attack, and see some of our favorite characters die. To be honest I would have enjoyed seeing Edward and Bella die, dying to allow Jacob to run away with Nessie, needing to use the papers Alice went through so much trouble to insinuate were necessary. Melodramatic, maybe, but then again I was never much of an E/B fan.<br /><br />Another thing that got on my nerves - Jacob running away at the end of Eclipse had SO MUCH potential. I wish Meyer didn't simply bring him back to the wedding that easy - I would have rather seen Bella forced to go find Jacob if she cares for him that much. Maybe after she became a vampire, and seen Jacob react to her in a feral sense. Anything but \\"he randomly shows up at the wedding.\\"<br /><br />All in all, I wasn't unhappy until I got to the ending. Please, Meyer, work on fixing your anti-climatic tendencies. It is extremely disappointing to get to the end of the book and feel like nothing has actually happened.her seen Bella forced to go find Jacob if she cares for him that much. 031606792X|1.0|First I'd like to say that I greatly admire Stephenie Meyer as the author of the first three Twilight books.  However, I have lost a significant amount of respect after reading Breaking Dawn.  This will certainly impact my desire to read any of her future books.      I've never seen a series go so off the rails. Where was her publishing company?  What about her agent?  Her friends?  Why didn't anyone warn Stephenie?  I find it hard to believe they didn't have strong opinions.  Or did Stephenie believe as the author she knew best?  Either way, someone made a horrible error in judgement.    WARNING... Spoilers below!    I feel like Stephenie left her characters off the page, stranding them in Eclipse while shifting to some alternate fanfic universe. I love fanfic but SM's leaves a lot to be desired. To be honest, although well written (not crafted), I don't feel like this was a book/story Stephenie wanted to tell. It felt slapped together, like she'd prowled through endless fanfic to steal the best ideas and make them their own. Harsh -- I know but I just didn't feel that she was enjoying writing this book like she did the previous three in the Twilight series. In terms of characters -- she reduced the Cullens to bit parts. Almost parodies of their former selves. Even Edward became a minor character. He had no depth, no angst or true emotion after the first hundred pages. How do you have an epic romance with a one dimensional love interest? Even Bella fell flat. She turned into a thirty year old after she \\"changed.\\" All of her teen angst was gone. There's no panic over her even becoming a mother. She became some sexy bombshell super mom vamp. I'd have no problem with this if there was at least a strong journey of discovery for her. Instead it's: \\"I guess I skipped the whole newborn thing and gosh I look amazing in slinky dresses. I'm so beautiful now and oh - I must have sex all the time instead of meaningful conversations with my boytoy husband!\\"     I won't even delve into the pregnancy or Jacob and Nessie plot lines.     I'm extremely disappointed that SM decided to butcher her own series for the sake of selling more books. Personally, I would have sooner waited a few years for her to do this right.   I would even have preferred Eclipse as the final book.      I'll leave you with one final word -- Disappointing.

0792838068|5.0|I just want to say this right off the bat; I honestly think that 1995 has seriously got to be one of the greatest years of film in recent history.  There are just so many cinematic gems to be found within that particular year, and `Leaving Las Vegas' is truly one of them.  I will admit that I was skeptical at first.  I am not a fan of Nicholas Cage, not in the least.  He is a very mannered, `actorly' type of an actor; you know the type that always appears to be acting.  I prefer my actors to sink into the rawness of their roles.  Look at Crowe for instance, a chameleon type actor who never seems to be acting as much as he is simply `being'.  That, and it also seems very hard for Cage to emote any fluctuation in emotion; he just comes off one note.  I adored him in `Matchstick Men', a film that embellished his mannerisms and made them work to his advantage; and I loved him in `Adaptation', a performance that he openly attests to his going contrary to everything he's build his acting career on.  In other words, he played the character as if he was a different actor, and it worked beautifully.<br /><br />Those two stellar performances aside and Nicholas Cage is a mediocre at best actor in my eyes.  So you can understand why watching yet another Cage film was not really that appealing to me.<br /><br />Well, I'll just say that I am extremely glad that I decided to give it a go.<br /><br />`Leaving Las Vegas' is responsible, not only for Cage's finest performance, but is honestly his finest film; ever.  Yes, it is bleak and depressing and ultimately heartbreaking, but it is so emotionally connected without being overly sappy and or too heavy handed.<br /><br />As a quick side point, that is another wonderful thing about the films of 1995; they are truly effecting without being spoonfuls of sympathy.  Films like `Leaving Las Vegas' and the overwhelmingly fantastic `Dead Man Walking' are able to crawl inside the viewer and grab hold of their beating heart with a realness and rawness that reflects real life and not Hollywood's overly saccharine fabrication of it.<br /><br />Anyways; back to the film.  `Leaving Las Vegas' centers on a relationship that forms between as alcoholic mess of a man named Ben and a `hooker with a heart' named Sera.  Ben has lost everything to his drinking, or is it that he starting drinking because he lost everything...either way, he has nothing except the bottle and so he decides to cash out all his savings and put himself up in Vegas to drink himself to death.  The end looks gloomy and bitter for Ben, but he winds up meeting Sera and things start to change for him.  Sera is tired and lonely and just needs someone to talk to, and when Ben pays her to just sit and talk she realizes that she needs him as much as he needs her.  He tells her his plan and warns her not to try and ask him to change, that he will never stop drinking, and she allows herself to comply because she needs to be with him, but as they come closer with one another her love for Ben starts to tear away at her commitment to him.<br /><br />It feels weird for me to say this, but the strongest facet of this film is the acting.  Cage embodies Ben with such rawness and accuracy.  I remember when I watched Meg Ryan devour her character in `When a Man Loves a Woman'; how she really soaked up her characters addiction.  That is what Cage does here.  His shakes and stutters and tantrums are so real, so believable and ultimately so heart wrenching.  As good (or even great) as Cage is, Elizabeth Shue is a revelation.<br /><br />Another quick side point about 1995 in general; it was truly an astonishing year for leaving ladies.  The entire Oscar shortlist is beyond compare when stacked up against their usual picks for each and every performance nominated is worthy, even if I would replace one or two.  Shue, Sarandon, Streep, Thompson, Stone...all of them are flawless and deserving of an Oscar (especially Shue and Sarandon) but there was Kidman in `To DieFor' and even Silverstone in `Clueless' (such a fantastic comedic performance).  I mean really, 1995 is above and beyond stellar.<br /><br />Sorry bout that.  Back to the film, or more importantly, back to Shue.  Elizabeth Shue is not my favorite actress either.  She is decent, but hardly ever mind blowing.  I think that is what makes her performance all the more unbelievable good.  As Sera, Shue captures the fading light in her eyes that starts to shine brighter when she finds Ben.  In Ben she sees someone that needs her, and I mean really needs her.  She is used to having men `need' her in ways that degrade her, but Ben truly `needs' her and that truth fleshes out the real woman that is Sera.  Her performance is a true `tour-de-force' if I ever saw one and unbelievable moving and touching.<br /><br />In its final frames `Leaving Las Vegas' attacks the viewer and strips them so-to-speak of everything they have inside.  The film is a tragic yet beautifully accurate representation of the disease that is alcoholism and the effect it has on a human spirit.  Contrary to `When a Man Loves a Woman'; a film that sported a fabulous performance yet fell into the trap of Hollywood induced clich&eacute;s, `Leaving Las Vegas' allows the bleak realities of human tragedy to ring true, and the effect it a much further reaching and effecting film.  In the end, Ben finally leaves Las Vegas, but Las Vegas will never leave us.tastic comedic performance).  I mean really, 1995 is above and beyond stellar.    Sorry bout that.  Back to the film, or more importantly, back to Shue.  Elizabeth Shue is not my favorite actress either.  She is decent, but hardly ever mind blowing.  I think that is what makes her performance all the more unbelievable good.  As Sera, Shue captures the fading light in her eyes that starts to shine brighter when she finds Ben.  In Ben she sees someone that needs her, and I mean really needs her.  She is used to having men `need' her in ways that degrade her, but Ben truly `needs' her and that truth fleshes out the real woman that is Sera.  Her performance is a true `tour-de-force' if I ever saw one and unbelievable moving and touching.    In its final frames `Leaving Las Vegas' attacks the viewer and strips them so-to-speak of everything they have inside.  The film is a tragic yet beautifully accurate representation of the disease that is alcoholism and the effect it has on a human spirit.  Contrary to `When a Man Loves a Woman'; a film that sported a fabulous performance yet fell into the trap of Hollywood induced clichs, `Leaving Las Vegas' allows the bleak realities of human tragedy to ring true, and the effect it a much further reaching and effecting film.  In the end, Ben finally leaves Las Vegas, but Las Vegas will never leave us.

031606792X|1.0|i loved the first three books, i've read them dozens of times. literally. i dutifully picked up my copy of  breaking dawn first thing saturday morning, started reading it first thing, and finished sunday night. completely disappointed.     it's hard not to tell you what i don't like about this book without revealing some spoilers, and if you've read the book you might be able to pinpoint some of the already famous things, but in a nutshell, i just think this one was badly written. too much dialog, too much description. i understand this book has to be like a child to stephenie now, wanting to pour as much detail as she can into her dream, but it just gets boring. and the first three books were hardly ever boring. which is ironic, because i think at the heart of the first three books it was a simple love story while the last one feels more like someone trying to write a book that would make it to the silver screen.     knowing all this, would i have bought the book anyway? probably, because reviewers can't speak for everyone. it's nice to see how a series you've read over and over ends, even if it manages to disappoint you severely.

B00005214X|5.0|Do yourself a favor: buy this album. When it arrives, put everything else aside, get your headphones on, lie on your bed, close your eyes, and listen to it beginning to end. This is an album that deserves to be listened to in one sequence before you start listening to each song individually.    This album is a journey through George's soul, and if you're lucky, your own soul as well. Yes, it's long, but all meditations are long. Listen carefully to the lyrics as you lie there, try to get the imagery in your head.    This is the best album by any solo Beatle. Yes, better than Lennon's \\"Imagine\\" and \\"Plastic Ono Band\\", better than McCartney's \\"Band on the Run\\". Those are phenomenal albums with some great individual songs, but this one stands alone as an experience to be treasured.    The only flaw with this album is that some of the jams at the end are kind of filler. You'll probably only listen to them once. You'll probably be in a trance by then, so it'll be really cool, but once you snap out of it you'll realize that you're hungry and the album is running a bit long. But that's okay, because more is better when it comes to George Harrison. Bless you, George.

B001DDBCV4|5.0|I have been a fan of the series \\"Sex and the City\\" since 2000, when I watched HBO's recap of the first two seasons one late night on HBO2. From that moment on, even at the age of 13 I feel in love with these characters: Miranda (the cynic), Charlotte (the old-fashioned), Samantha (the slut), and Carrie (the social anthropologist). But those one-dimension descriptions do not do the series justice at all. For 6 beautiful seasons the HBO comedy turned dramedy focused upon the life and adventures of a group of friends who see their friendship mature and blossom into a family while they try to navigate down the crazy road of love.    Over a year ago when I heard news that a long-awaited feature-film was actually a possibility to say the least I was a little scared. I remember the how for the course of a year the anticipation kept building up and up for the films impending May 2008. And when cast interviews, trailers, and posters started to appear I got really excited. And then release day came and I was there at midnight with my best friend, dressed up and excited. And to say honest the movie didn't disappoint at all.    While the film had some flaws at the element of being a feature film (what is to be expected from a first-time director), it wasn't the special effects or camera angles that were important. No, it was the acting and the reunion of characters that fans have been missing for the past 5 years. The story serious didn't disappoint, even with its whooping 2  hour run-time. It was the story that everyone was hoping for: One of reunions, love, the testament of commitment, the butterflies that come with everything at stake, and the beautiful experiences of love. At the level of plot the producers kept almost everything rush until after the film's release - which was a very good idea. Giving away even the minorist of plot details would destroy the films experience, and lessen the effect of the girl's reunion. All I have to say is that there are moments you'll find your jaw on the group, your eyes tearing up, and your chest aching from laughter. It truly is an adventure in those 2  hours.    The film's $55 million release weekend take accompanied by the almost $400 total gross is a testament to the fans that love this show. HBO has already planned a sequel and even a third film later down the line. And while I believe those films will be amazing - they will not be able to capture the magic of this original film. It was the reunion people didn't think would happen, and it provide that beyond the dramas of life, friendship will truly survive.

I felt let down like Stephan and Vladimir.   All in all I am glad that Bella, Edward, and Jacob got their happy ending but it fell short of the grand finale closing that Harry Potter's seventh novel delivered.    Would I always be a Twilight saga fan? Yes. Would I read Breaking Dawn again? Only if I was bored and had nothing else to read!
0307237702|3.0|The Audacity of Hope is as good a title as any for this book by a young, rookie Senator.   And the hope at the heart of his writing and thoughts is well placed, for in this, Barack Obama's Second book, despair lurks in the margins.     He as much as admits to this at several places in the book.  He sees the country so completely divided on certain issues that finding a solution to the myriad social and economic problems connected to those issues seems almost like a dream.      Indeed, there is one constant subtext throughout the book: Barack's restlessness at the slow pace of governmental change.  The rules and the glacial pace of Senate procedures simultaneously fascinate and frustrate him.  He is in awe of just how good the framers of the constitution set up this great political experiment. However, the machine of the Senate, and the current business of politics, seem to him an almost torturous affair. Early in the book, Barack explains that what is debated day in and day out in the Senate is not (contrary to what most laymen perceive,) what the NEW laws should be.  Instead, most of the time is spent trying to figure out what the EXISTING laws actually mean. (This experience in the Senate seems to have opened his eyes to just how important the appointment of Judges are.)     He bristles at the tediousness of some of this, and he openly wonders at just how quickly he may find himself caught up in the machinery that has consumed so many before him. For instance he starts one chapter talking about just how nice it is to fly on private jets. He is very descriptive of the pleasures of this elite way of travel.  But he is also aware of just how much it separates him from the everyday American's experience.     More apparent though is Barack's ambitious nature seem too large for a long term career in the Senate,      He wants a larger stage on which to operate and to articulate his thoughts, and this book seems to be a prelude to that.    The Audacity of Hope is split upinto large chapters encompassing big topics, (Race, Faith, etc.,) and within those headings, Obama struggles with the conflicting and seemingly contradictory stances on many sides of the issues. If you follow politics in the news, many of Obama's analogies and examples will be familiar to you, but if you largely stay away from politics, this volume will give you a pretty good idea of what he honestly thinks regarding these issues.       The answer is simple: Like many in America, he struggles.    One of the most telling sequences of the book is when he talks about how the countdown for an approaching Roll Call vote.  He laments that when complicated issues, involving many complex factors, come down to the final vote, you almost always are wishing for more time.     The book is political, and more specifically campaign-oriented in nature, so it can often get a bit wonkish and, well, boring, but Barack has a way of bringing it back to simplicity with a humorous aside.      In light of his more recent popularity, (one hundred thousand people seeing him in Berlin,) it is interesting to read his account of traveling around Illinois alone as a virtually unknown candidate and sometimes speaking to 4 or 5 people.  My favorite anecdote involves his invitation to a Union gathering during a primary for one office he was seeking.  While he sat onstage waiting to speak, the man introducing him basically announced that the Union would be endorsing somebody else, but adds that \\"Mr. Obama is here to give us his thoughts.\\"    Once finished with the book, you can understand a little more about Barack Obama's political thinking. And a little about the gamble he seems to be taking in the upcoming election for President of the United States. Obama, if I read correctly, is gambling that MOST people in the United States feel as he does. That most people struggle with these issues in the same ways and would like to see an end to partisan politics.
031606792X|1.0|Spoiler Alert - Don't Read This If You Don't Want Spoilers      I am a die hard Twilight fan, the books were enjoyable escapism into the world of vampires and the humans who love them in Breaking Dawn we see that world turned upside down. I was okay with everything until Book 2, and not because I don't like Jacob, I like Jacob, especially when he is getting over Bella. But in this book, his story was the only thing worth reading about. Bella and Edward are so boring and unlike themselves it was painful to continue to read the book after Book 1.    Let's begin, Bella, our iconic hero who is baffled she is 18 and getting married suddenly is pregnant and guess what is thrilled. Rosalie, our blonde bombshell who hates Bella is there by her side, and if Bella dies wouldn't care in previous books and definitely in this one, basically gets to raise the kid. Hey wait, she pretty much does that anyway. Bella is in full-on martyrdom now. Was Bella ever a martyr, she was like us, normal, in every respect. She just happened to fall in love with Edward.    Edward is not our Edward anymore. No more are there loving touches and words, we get a wooden character with no attachment to his demon-spawn. In this matter I don't blame him, she was killing our Bella.     Renesme or Nessie. What a pointless plot device, how about we focus on Bella as a vampire, or Bella enjoying sex, Edward seeing he didn't kill her and maybe college? Nope, baby time it is.     Jacob was redeemable until imprinting on Nessie. Why, couldn't he normally fall in love, over time with Leah? It seemed that's where the plot was going, but no yet again, a pointless plot that leads no where.    Where were the Cullens? Dr Cullen, knowing Bella could literally pop at any moment, goes to get blood? Esme frets but says nothing, Alice and Jasper are gone, Emmett says sex jokes. Where is our beloved family?    Charlie is cool with babies, vampires and wearwolves? Right, great Police officer there.    I'm sorry I loved thebooks but this was inexcusable. I've read better, more involving fan fiction by 13 year olds.     Bella becomes a Mary Sue, and I hated her for it. Edward isn't our knight in shinning, sometimes coming to our window in dented armor, he's just boring, Jacob almost redeemed himself if he had actually moved on with someone, I'd have liked it to be Leah. but nope he's in Bella life for all time. The Cullens are useless and Nessie, all I can say is that I wanted her dead before she was born.

031606792X|1.0|I'm so disappointed in Breaking Dawn that I hardly know where to begin. Other reviewers have already accurately enumerated why this much-awaited novel lands with a splat; I won't belabor the point except to say that after struggling with virtually every page to convince myself to enjoy the book, I just couldn't.     Breaking Dawn was gratuitously violent, disturbing, rang false, and gave some very dubious messages that contradict everything Bella stood for prior to this. The overall effect once I read the last page was profound dismay. I wanted to hurl the book, and then bleach my brain.    Ms. Meyer: What On Earth Happened?! Burnout?! The chess piece on the book jacket is apt: this is one gambit that failed.     I feel it would have been okay with many, if not most, of her readers (of all ages) had she made some tougher, albeit more honest choices for Bella and particularly Jacob. It really does feel as though she was trying to tie everything up in a neat, happy bow, which ultimately had the exact opposite effect.    One more observation: as a parent, this book really, really isn't for under-16's. I'm not referring to sex, rather its aftermath, the results of which were prolonged and, at times, revolting.    I'm passing my copy of Breaking Dawn on to a friend and will try to forget it exists; from here on, I'll stick with the wonder of Twilight and let it simply stand alone in this pyrrhic series.

031606792X|2.0|**************************Spoilers Below**********************************      I have read the 3 other books from the saga, and I truly wanted to like Breaking Dawn.   I am not a fanatic fan but I enjoy this series as a guilty pleasure when I need something light and easy to read.  Unfortunately, I just could not like the novel.  To be honest this novel felt like it was from a completely different series.  The interaction and connection between Bella and Edward was nowhere near what it is the other three novels.  I truly believe it was because Meyer introduced such a curve ball into the plot, which was the surprise child Renesme/Nessie.  Meyer has stated over and over again, that this series was the epic love story of Edward and Bella.      However, Breaking Dawn did not offer the last chapter of the epic love story.      Sure they had the wedding, which was romantic to a point but is seemed, too rushed in my opinion.  I am still wondering what Meyer found so exciting about writing the wedding to seemed to fall dead to me.   There were no details on how much love was shown in Edward's face while she was walking down the aisle or Bella's reaction to how handsome Edward looked; Meyer always seems to mention his beauty.  There was not a lot of interaction between her parents, her human friends, nothing.  Also why didn't she have a bachelorette party?  Sure not every bride has one but why no last hooray with the girlfriends that she was close to like Alice or Angela.  Yes that might not be in Bella's character in the first 3 books but you would think that Meyer would write Alice forcing Bella into one because it is definitely in Alice's character.    The honeymoon could have offered so much more and shown the connection and love between the two.  Instead of telling us what they did, snorkel and fly through the jungle, why didn't she have any scenes where they interacted with each other, like in the meadow?  Sure they are soul mates and know each other so well, unlike their first time in the meadow, but Meyer still could have had more interaction that wasn't Bella begging for sex with Edward.    The fact that Bella begged for sex still gets me.  Sure she made the deal to marry Edward to get sex in the first place, but it was ridiculous how much she begged for it while on Isle Esme.  (I still have an issue with that deal)  Also the fact that Meyer wrote Bella to take advantage of Edward's wishes of her going to college as a way for her to have more human sex was very absurd.  I can see why Meyer didn't give the readers a detail account of the sex but she could have at least given the readers a reaction of how she felt after and how she feels so much closer to Edward, considering how cheesy she can get.      The whole Vamp/Human baby still is a complete shock to me.  Having heard the spoilers, I seriously thought that that they were a rumor, how wrong was I.  I think that if Meyer had not made the famous statement of how vampires can't have children, it might not have been so bad.  To state that fact (vampires can't have babies) and then find a loophole is just a cope out to me.  Very amateur writing if you ask me.  The whole baby story line is amateur.  I personally found it hilarious how she foreshadowed her being pregnant by having her eat eggs all the time and also the fact that she was snacking on raw chicken while it was cooking and having her disliked the taste of cooked chicken.  The fact that she was only a little suspicious about something moving inside of her was dense.  Also the fact that Edward has gone through med school twice and didn't see something fishy until the last possible moment, how convenient.  Sure he thought that having a baby with Bella could never happen but considering that Bella is his world, you would think that he would be more observant to her \\"supposed\\" signs of pregnancy.  This whole story line made the vampires look completely stupid, Carlisle an accomplished doctor did not see that the Vampbabyneeded blood until Edward hears it in Jacobs mind.  This could have been handled so much better if she had spent a little more time on details and thinking through how the characters would react.  They all seemed OOC.      Also isn't a vampire made through a bite, not created through intercourse?  That still doesn't make sense to me.      The name Reneseme is also an atrocious name and the nickname is even worse.  How is Nessie even close to Renesme?  I will give Meyer credit though; I thought that the child had cute characteristics if her situation wasn't so strange.  Growing at a rapid rate mentally and physically was such a convenient plot point for the Jacob imprinting.      I really don't have an issue with imprinting in general, just the fact that Jacob imprinted on Bella's kid.  I actually found the Quil/Claire story line very sweet.  The issue that I have with this imprinting is that Meyer states through Jacob's narrative that he had fantasized about Bella naked and most likely in sexual situations.   She then has him imprint on Nessie, her daughter, which is just creepy to me.  Why Bella's kid? Why not Leah? (I feel bad for that poor girl; she got shafted if you ask me.)    The whole birth scene was disgusting.  Having not given birth myself, but having seen my sister's, I know that I can't physically understand the pain that can occur.  However that scene was just gruesome, it read like something out of Aliens.  To have that in a YA novel was very surprising to me.  I had to put it down for awhile when I was reading that scene.  The writing style and the amount of information that was occurring in the scene were very hectic and hard to follow.      The \\"epic\\" battle that was supposed to occur was a major disappointment.  The Volturi stalled and talked way too much for my taste.  After Irina's death, I wanted to see her sister's attack just to get some action.  I was expecting action like in Eclipse, not talk.  Also why did she have Garrett, a character that was recently introduced at the end of the novel and some one who the audience has no emotional connection with, give such an impassioned speech against the Volturi.  It just didn't fit.  The whole love shield was ridiculously used.  It would have been better if the shield had been used sparingly, not the whole time they were waiting to fight.  It made it to convenient.  It would have been better if Bella could suddenly able to master it when those she loved were in danger at the last moment, not the whole time.        The whole book was very rushed.  I missed the interacting between Edward and Bella and the Cullen family, especially Alice.  She made it seem like she was trying to make everyone's dreams come true, the E/B marriage, the transformation, having Jacob in her life, living happily ever after, having Bella's parents in the loop, ect. ect.  It just didn't work because those things don't fit all together according to her other books.  She did not set the other books up to have all of these things.  That is why this book is all over the place.     And of course I realize this is fiction and not reality.  I am a fan of a happy ending so I have not issue with that I actually prefer it.  I just wish that she had stuck with what she set up in the other 3 books.  If she didn't want to have Bella have to choose and make sacrifices, she should have not set it up to make her fans see it as so.  I am still very shock about the content of this book.  I was really looking foreword to this book and was greatly disappointed.
031606792X|5.0|**Minimal spoilers, you've been warned**    I bought the book at Wal-Mart at around 3am Saturday morning on my way home from partying with my best friend (who lives ridiculously far away), and once home I promised myself I'd just go to bed. Bella is given everything she ever wanted without making any of the sacrifices that one is supposed to make when choosing a 'forbidden love'. Not to mention that the reader is constantly reminded how special Bella is by making her not have to go through the hardships that come with being a newborn Vampire, even though everyone else had to have them. She also basically is the one that protects and defeats the Volturi because the power that 'Special and Perfect Bella' develops is the only one able to save everyone.    She is also apparently stronger than Edward. She's immune to bloodlust, despite her having to supposed to go berserk when in contact with blood.    She set feminism back a hundred years when she began begging Edward for sex. Not to mention the author portrays her as a sex-crazed eighteen year old boy. She constantly wants to sex-it-up with Edward, and not just in this book. She, once again is frequently describing Edward's beautiful-adonis-God-like-etc, etc.    Moving on to her daughter, who turns out to be even more of a Mary Sue than her mother. The kid has super-mental-powers in the womb, she begins to grow at an exponential rate where she will conveniently stop aging at about 18, she can read, can talk and has the mental capacity of an adult, she can copy the moves of others perfectly, and is able to walk, run and even hunt. Also, since all the members of the Quiletes come to instantly like her, all is well between the Vampires and Werewolves.    She sounds like that girl from The4400. Nessie is also a Damphir, you know, like Blade, or BloodRayne, or Connor from Angel. Only, they are actually depthful characters that have flaws, Nessie does not. If no one can see what a Mary Sue this child is, I feel very sorry for you.    Moving on, Jacob imprints on Nessie...........I can not even begin to say how creepy and wrong that is. Also, how is it possible that the reason why Jacob fell in love with Bella was because he knew that she was going to give birth to Nessie? That's taking the 'love' concept ridiculously out of range. I liked Jacob, he deserved a better ending, considering him having to endure Bella's blatant rejection.    My last issue, aside from the poor writing and cliche'd situations and predictable plot devices, is the underlying message of the book, that a lot of fans don't or refuse to see, is that the book portrays happiness for a teenage girl whose straight out of high school as having a man in your life and having his child as soon as possible.    It's as if the author thought the only way to make it a true happy ending was to make sure that Bella had a child, probably because the author has kids of her own and felt if fitting for her character despite how young she is or what kind of message she might be sending to her young readers.    I think the only thing I agreed with, was the explaination that the Werewolves were not actually wolves, but Shapeshifters. This, makes sense, because a lot of indian myths are centered around not werewolves, but SkinWalkers, which are also called Shapeshifters.    Overall, I only enjoyed very little in this entire book, why her editor thought it should be published, I'll never know.
031606792X|4.0|Breaking Dawn is every bit as entrancing, cheesy, far fetched, lovely, intriguing, and delightful as any of the other 3 books in the Twilight Saga. 6304806434|3.0|This is a well-made, very watchable example of a classic Hollywood genre -- the action/adventure film. Nicholas Cage plays Cameron Poe, ex-army Ranger who gets in a bar fight and kills a redneck who was bugging his wife. Poe ends up with a plea-bargained eight-year sentence, does his time without annoying anyone, and is about to be released when he's put on a Federal Bureau of Prisons airplane (known as \\"Jailbird-1\\")as a convenient ride back to his hometown. The plane is otherwise filled with the worst of the worst convicts from around the country, who are being shipped to a new super-max prison -- and they have no intention of going. John Malkovich does a terrific job as Cyrus Grissom, ringleader of the escape plot, and John Cusack is also very good as U.S. Marshal Larkin, whose plane it is, and who has to try to prevent the escape, and who establishes a tenuous alliance with Poe -- because Poe is the heroic type and he just can't let things happen this way. Steve Buscemi plays a creepy, Hannibal Lector-ish serial killer whom even the other convicts are nervous about, but the screenwriter and the director missed the chance to do a lot more with him as a \\"wild card.\\" (Would he really have sided with the escaped cons in the Big Showdown?) The plot accelerates as it predictably progresses, with the plane finally crash-landing on the Las Vegas Strip (neat SFX, though not really believable). And while you know the Good Guys are going to win, it's interesting to see how they manage it. Actually, the only bad part of the film is Cage's dreadful attempt at an Alabama accent.

031606792X|5.0|First of all, I want to preface this by saying that I thoroughly enjoyed the book. I avoided the Internet like the plague until I finished reading last night and I formed my opinion before it could be tainted by some of the reviews here. I respect everyone else's opinion, but I have to say that I was surprised to see all the negative energy being directed at the book. Stephenie should be so proud of Breaking Dawn! Instead of the traditional review, I will include a list of likes and dislikes.    LIKES    1. I was perhaps one of the few people who did not want Bella to be changed into a vampire because I feared that she would be transformed into an entirely different person. But Stephenie did such a good job keeping Bella's character intact. This leads me to my second point.     2. I loved that Bella was able to avoid/control her lust for human blood. One of the things I had been worried about Bella being changed was that she would be like all the other newborns. It was definitely a good choice for her to be able to avoid it!    3. Stephenie couldn't have resolved the Edward, Bella, Jacob love triangle better than she did. I was so happy that Bella and Jacob were finally able to enjoy a mutual platonic love, while Jake found the person he was truly meant to be with. Renesmee and Jacob being together makes so much sense.     4. I enjoyed the consistency of all the characters. It is entirely plausible that Charlie would prefer to be on a \\"need to know basis\\" regarding the supernatural. All that would matter to him was that Bella was safe. Edward's desperation during Bella's pregnancy was also very in-character. Bella was DYING. Of course he would resort to any means of keeping her alive! I'm guessing he would not have wanted to murder the child under any other circumstance unless his love was dying.    5. I was so glad that Rosalie's high degree of dislike for Bella was resolved. Although it was clear that she had ulterior motives (the baby), in the end, she and Bellawere on good terms, which made me smile. Now the Cullens can truly be a happy family.     6. While I was reminded by J.K. Rowling's Albus Severus blunder, I thought the name \\"Renesmee\\" was beautiful and ingenious. It represented the love and devotion Bella had for both her biological and in-law mothers. The middle name of \\"Carlie\\" is the same. I'm glad the name Bella chose for her child wasn't meaningless like many names are.     7. Probably my favorite part of the entire book was the fact that there was no \\"epic battle.\\" Prior to the book's release, many Twilighters were abuzz about which characters might be killed off. I thought of Alice and Edward and Bella and Jake and Carlisle and all the characters I had grown to love, and dreaded Stephenie taking any of them away. Stephenie showed us that there doesn't need to be war; there can be peace. She showed us the power of words and how they helped divert a raging, devastating war. I felt that the book could not have had a truly \\"happy ending\\" unless all the family was intact, and it was.     8. I LOVED Jacob's book. Although I had become quite accustomed to Bella's POV, Jake's was refreshing and also humorous. I really enjoyed the easing up of tension in a very serious situation (Bella's pregnancy). The chapter names were also hilarious! So Jacob.    9. Garret. He was a minor character, but I thought he was funny and I liked the idea of he and Kate together. I also enjoyed Alistair's mumblings. :P    10. The fact that the werewolves and vampires were able to reach a truce and also gain a lot of friendship. I loved how Bella at first, and then Renesmee were able to bring the two opposing clans together. They learned tolerance.    11. Charlie and Sue having each other. Charlie and Sue had both lost their spouses (Charlie to Phil and Sue to death) and were lonely. I felt bad for Charlie in the past when Bella thought that he had never really gotten over Renee. Charlie deserved a companion, especially because his daughter and grandchild were not human.    12. This is general, but Stephenie's growth as a writer really showed up in the book. After reading The Host, I knew that Breaking Dawn was going to have phenomenal writing, and it did! I am really excited to read everything else she writes in the future.     DISLIKES    1. I found a few grammatical errors here and there (for example, putting neither/or instead of neither/nor), but nothing major. I also noticed that she alternated between saying \\"blonde\\" and \\"blond.\\" Again, not really that big of a deal.     2. The inclusion of the J. Jenks storyline. I completely understood its relevance (Bella would have to have a plan for Renesmee to escape, especially because she thought she and Edward would die). I suppose I felt that it was unnecessary because there didn't end up being a battle. On the other hand, we as readers would not have been able to believe in the danger of the battle unless Bella was completely prepared for the worst outcome.    3. It bothered me a little bit that Bella became so desperate for sex with Edward while she was still human that she was reduced to tears and even offered to postpone being changed. However, I can see the necessity of this, as well. Bella feared that she would not be able to express her love for Edward for years in her crazed newborn phase, so it makes sense that she would be upset about him only letting 'it' happening once when she was human.    4. I need to re-read the book again to get a clear idea of exactly how it was that Edward impregnated Bella. I am guessing that vampires and humans having sex is very rare because they are usually too overcome by bloodlust to \\"get the job done.\\" So, I suppose that isn't even a specific dislike; just a need for clarification.    Breaking Dawn was an excellent novel that left me smiling and hoping. The writing was superb and I thought the book was very fitting as the end to the amazing saga. Bravo, Stephenie!

031606792X|4.0|I'm fairly new to the Twilight series and have now ready all four books w/in a period of 2 months. B0013FSL3E|3.0|I couldn't wait to see Wall.e at the theater and I was very disappointed. I am sorry to say that, in my opinion, it was just not a very good movie.
