031606792X|1.0|Breaking Dawn is the much-anticipated conclusion to the Twilight series from Bella, the narrator of the other three published books, point of view. It suceeds bestsellers TWilight, New Moon, and Eclipse.    In Twilight we are introduced to Bella as her mother is dropping her off at an airport, where Bella is board a plane to the rainy town of Forks, Washington to live with her dad. Her motivation, it is later revealed, is to allow her mother greater opportunity to move around with her new husband, who is a minor league baseball player. It's not long before Bella is drawn to the sexy, reclusive Cullens - a coven of older teenagers described as seductively beautiful outsiders. Apparently, the attraction is mutual and she is soon approached by the chivalrous Edward. Their 'relationship' soon mounts in intensity, and Bella is unofficially integrated into the Cullen family. Twilight is followed by New Moon, where Edward leaves her \\"for her own good\\" after an accident involving a paper cut and broken bones, thus opening a window of opportunity into which Jacob, a Native American from a local reservation and Bella's childhood friend, quickly steps. Like every other fertile man in Forks, Jacob quickly falls for Bella - a fact which, in addition to the appearance of werewolves within the reservation, complicates the relationship between the two central characters in the third book, Eclipse. This, then, quickly builds to encompass territorial disputes between the two mythological creatures (coincidentally, vampires and werewolves are mortal enemies), as well as an approaching army, headed by the bitter vampire girlfriend of Twilight's villain. Eventually, all the conflicts are brought to a close - the evil vampires are bested by cooperation between the Cullens and the werewolves, Bella acknowledges but denies her love for Jacob, and Edward and Bella end up engaged.    And this is where Breaking Dawn picks up - the book opens on Bella in a new car, reflecting on her impendingwedding. Through the first few chapters, the reader is fully subject to alternating bouts of angst, low self-esteem, idolatry based on Edward's utter perfection, and uncertainty about the wedding. However, this 'conflict,' like all others in the Twilight universe, is quickly absolved as soon as Bella is fitted in her wedding dress and sees her gorgeous husband-to-be. From here, Meyer proceeds with the wedding and then a swift transition to the happy honeymoon, where, after two books of repressed lust, Bella and Edward finally consummate their relationship. Unfortunately, it turns out that Edward is still fertile, thus leading to an unexpected (and potentially unhealthy) pregnancy.    Directly after the tumultuous conclusion of the happy couple's not-so-happy honeymoon, Meyer switches point of view to Jacob - the bitter ex-almost-boyfriend who harbors an acute grudge against Edward which, somehow, extends to the rest of the Cullens. After a solid block of angst and forbidden lust, Bella goes into a very violent and bloody labor with her demon spawn, at the end of which, in conclusion to Jacob's turn at narration, he \\"imprints\\" (the creepy werewolf equivalent to \\"love at first sight\\") on Bella's barely-born mutant baby.    From here, Bella picks the narration back up and the reader is subjected to a clumsy definition of what it is to be turned into a vampire. Meyer, apparently, knows no other way to describe it than having fire (the magical venom that has replaced all of the normal bodily fluids in vampires) running through her veins - which is how she illustrates it for an entire chapter. Bella has been hastily turned after her painful delivery to save her life (in a sense, at least). The story quickly dissolves into poorly disguised wish-fulfillment, featuring a cottage in the woods, a beautiful baby, an effortless transition to life as a vampire, superhuman strength of will, and ridiculously awesome sex. At the end, Meyer, much like in Twilight, throws in some contrived conflict featuring evil Italian vampires - all culminating in a thoroughly unthrilling action sequence suceeded by an excruciatingly gooey epilogue.    In Breaking Dawn Meyer continues in her proud tradition of poor storytelling, fully outfitted in amateurish prose, holey plot, and spotty conflict. As in the three prior books in this proclaimed \\"saga,\\" she builds a shaky structure, which she then proceeds to slather with an excess of sweet, and unrealistic, nothings between her two lovers. The universe is built around her characters (a typical trait in poorly written fanfiction) - the world reacts to them, instead of them reacting to the universe. The plot is built around the whims of her characters, all of whom are startlingly one-dimensional, and furthered by a series of unexplained and illogical coincidences. At times, Meyer even sees fit to directly contradict both the laws she's set up for her universe as well as the rules of science and logic. Bella is impregnated by Edward, but this should be impossible both because all of Edward's sperm should have died and, according to the laws of Meyerpires, all of his remaining sperm should have been turned into vampire venom.    Furthermore, the same misogyny is on full display throughout the narrative. Although Bella, through her transformation to a vampire, has become less physically helpless, she displays the same weakness of mind and character that was her single defining characteristic throughout her story. Similarly, the surrounding female characters, such as Esme, Alice, Rosalie, Leah, and Renee, have been weakened even more to compensate for the minimal improvement on Bella's part. Alice, once a promising and interesting character, is reduced to a shallow, superficial, weak character with the mindset and attention span of a slightly below average teenager, despite her century-long lifespan. Esme, similarly, is depicted as a stereotypical housewife, her mind entirely absorbed with decoration and housekeeping. Rosalie, the only character not actively depicted as evil to express dislike for Bella, is shown as a bitter, hard-hearted, jealous bitch who cares only for the opportunity to care for a baby that she was robbed of with her transformation to a vampire - similarly, Leah, the only female werewolf, is depicted as a lovelorn and physically inferior harpy who only expresses care for her brother and her violent, cheating ex-boyfriend Sam, the head werewolf. Renee, Bella's flighty, inconsistent mother, is given little attention but is shown as negatively as ever.    Stephenie Meyer has repeatedly proven herself to be a technically inept amateur writer who, intentionally or not, pumps her cheap stories with dubious moral and intellectual messages. In that respect, this book does not disappoint. The action is frighteningly tame, her characters are sexist, her romance is clumsy and forced, and her writing is as novice as ever. Breaking Dawn is a complete failure of a book, not even good for a few cheap laughs because of the seemingly endless stream of insipid narration the reader is subjected to for over seven hundred pages.
031606792X|5.0|When I first started reading the book, I had read some of the spoilers so I knew what to expect.  I thought I would hate it.  The whole idea seemed quite ridiculous to me, and I did dislike it to a point...then it changed.  It was around book 3 that I realized just how phenomenal an author Stephenie Meyer is.  Yes, she didn't write it so all her fans would be happy (how boring would it have been if it was written like I expected) and she took risks yet it worked.  I loved it.  She took a character (Bella) who hadn't changed over three books and had her come into her own by experiencing something that no one can truly understand until they are one-maternal love.  She broke her characters into pieces, then put them back together again in a way that actually fit with her previous books.    Anyone who has read any of the other books would have seen some of the things coming-Nessie anyone?  There were so many hints about Bella giving up motherhood that it shouldn't have come as a surprise that she does get to be a mother.  Yes, she does become a mother, but she certainly has to suffer for it.  The Jacob/Bella relationship is also fully explained.    I will admit Renesmee is a stupid name, yet who are we to tell the author what the names are going to be.  Maybe she likes it?  I would say that plenty of people name their children stupidly every day.    I won't go off anymore, but to anyone reading the reviews and deciding whether to read it or not, I'd say go for it.  Its not typically what you'd expect after reading the other books, but it is brilliant.  REad it and form your own opinions-that's what I did even knowing the spoilers beforehand.  You won't be disappointed.
B000XZTGB6|3.0|When I checked the BelAir website I discovered that the Hector Berlioz item on this DVD `Harold in Italy' was not just the Finale (as noted on the DVD cover) but the entire work, I had to purchase the disk. For many years, the CD version by Colin Davis and the London Symphony Orchestra with Tabea Zimmermann (viola soloist) has been a favorite of mine, and I have been looking for a DVD version for some time.<br /><br />I went straight to this particular title and immediately found that while Yuri Bashmet is a good musician, his performance in this concert was not in the same class as Ms. Zimmermann. I was also amazed that, for a filmed concert, there was audience applause after the second movement. This was not just by a handful of concertgoers who did not know the work, but a significant portion of the audience. Mr. Bashmet's performance was certainly not one that warranted applause at that point. He tackled the next movement with more confidence and once again, to my utter amazement, the audience applauded. I think that some of the responsibility for this might have been that Valery Gergiev's pauses between movements were slightly longer than necessary. This is a work that needs to be listened to without significant interruption with each movement flowing on from the one before. Although the overall performance was not too bad, in terms of listening pleasure it was certainly a disappointment.<br /><br />Moving on to other works on the program, the Overture to Ruslan and Ludmilla was played as precisely and briskly as on the complete opera DVD by the same orchestra and conductor; which is to say somewhat faster than we are used to hearing it on the concert stage. I particularly enjoyed Liszt's Piano Concerto #2 (with Yefim Bronfman soloist), Verdi's Overture to La forza del destino and the Strauss Polka; but was disappointed with some of the other selections, as I prefer not to listen to short snippets of works that are more familiar in their entirety.<br /><br />The booklet notes that the acoustic consultant for the new Mariinsky Theatre Concert Hall was the same person responsible for the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles. This certainly contributes to the very good audio quality of this DVD.<br /><br />A word needs to be said of the video direction by Chlo&eacute; Perlemuter who seems to have very little talent or experience in directing concerts of this type. I thought Herbert von Karajan was bad with his hogging of the camera but at least when the Berlin Philharmonic played you were shown groups of instrumentalists in addition to the conductor. Ms. Perlemuter tried to get Valery Gergiev in almost every shot that is on the screen. If he doesn't fill the screen completely, he is almost always to be found in the center of the picture - somewhere. Camera vantage points were not chosen with regard to showing the musicians, most of whom are shown from the rear and too often arms, heads and instruments interfere or block the picture. It is perhaps unfortunate, considering how much camera time is spent on Mr. Gergiev, that his appearance seemed very untidy. Designer stubble is questionable on any person, but once that person is no longer young and the hair is gray, it just looks very unkempt. He reminded me of a `down-at-the-heels' street performer who had been given someone's discarded dress suit.<br /><br />If it wasn't for the misplaced applause in the Berlioz I would be able to recommend this as an excellent disk to LISTEN to, however, I will continue to wait for other versions of the works I really wanted to see performed well, becoming available.e acoustic consultant for the new Mariinsky Theatre Concert Hall was the same person responsible for the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles. This certainly contributes to the very good audio quality of this DVD.    A word needs to be said of the video direction by Chlo Perlemuter who seems to have very little talent or experience in directing concerts of this type. I thought Herbert von Karajan was bad with his hogging of the camera but at least when the Berlin Philharmonic played you were shown groups of instrumentalists in addition to the conductor. Ms. Perlemuter tried to get Valery Gergiev in almost every shot that is on the screen. If he doesn't fill the screen completely, he is almost always to be found in the center of the picture - somewhere. Camera vantage points were not chosen with regard to showing the musicians, most of whom are shown from the rear and too often arms, heads and instruments interfere or block the picture. It is perhaps unfortunate, considering how much camera time is spent on Mr. Gergiev, that his appearance seemed very untidy. Designer stubble is questionable on any person, but once that person is no longer young and the hair is gray, it just looks very unkempt. He reminded me of a `down-at-the-heels' street performer who had been given someone's discarded dress suit. 031606792X|3.0|Firstly, I love the series and The Author. Despite my feelings about breaking Dawn I still think Meyer is going to write plenty of good books in the future.     However, She fumbled this one immensely.      I would compare this to Stephen kings dark Tower series (if) All of the sudden Stephen had decided to end the series in 4 books instead of 7. Only right up until he went to write the 4th book, he was under the assumption he was going to be writing 3 more books after the 4th one. He thought he had way more time to explain things, to allow characters to develop at a rate which was believable not one which disconnects you from them.      Convulsive? Apologies.      Same comparison works with The harry potter books, If Rowling had stuffed 3 books worth of storyline into a single book of 700 pages and decided her supporting cast of characters didn't matter anymore and suddenly had nothing to say, you would have had the same mess.     Meyer stuffs way way way too much down your throat. Generally so far in the series the main point of the story is the relationships, the characters, they are very crucial to the first 3 books of the series.     Yet in BD, the characters are overrun with plot, The first Story Arch would have been enough for a full length novel, and it should have been. That would have left room for us to spend time with these characters. Instead everything was thrown into overdrive and we reached an imagined ending way before we should have.        Another major problem is the Climax, which is all tricks and illusion. Nothing really happens, Everyone get's their happy ending, no harm befalls anyone we care about. It's all fluffy and amazingly unrealistic.      Of course her series isn't exactly based on fact, of course not. But she has always managed to make it feel as if what's happening, if it really did happen, could happen this way.     Not any more.      She has said she writes for herself, Which is good. An author must please themselves before anyone else. You cannot try and please your audience, you can never make everyone happy.     But Authors also can't just tie everything up like it's all a Disney movie. The story needs to be served. Yes it's hard to let go of characters that you care about. But this turned into a big long piece of fan fiction. I felt like I was reading something from a grade 10 creative writing English assignment.      It's as if she's terrified of continuity.      Alas it could have been amazing, it should have been more then a single book, or one plot should have been cut. We should have heard At least Alice say more then 4 words throughout the entire novel... one of her best characters get's muzzled... Gah.. It's hard to know that this was Bella's last one, at least from her perspective... She deserved better.
031606792X|3.0|If you're picking up Breaking Dawn expecting the same breathless romance of the first three books in the Twilight saga I'm warning you now:  this one is different.  Approach with some caution.  Be prepared to have the fantasy you love very much touched by \\"normal life\\" in such a way that it changes the story completely.  The same cast of characters is back, but they are different:  not as present almost and very nearly stretched out of proportion when they are.  As it is in real life, marriage changes Bella and Edward's romance utterly (as I heard one fan say it, \\"Where's all the 'fluffy' romance?\\"), as do other things.  I've had a day to let Breaking Dawn sink in, and while there are parts I love (Stephenie's  humor is very much in evidence and there are some interesting plot twists), there are also parts I really don't like.  Stephenie almost seems a little off the mark with her characters and there are chunks of the book where, although there are obviously very imporant things going on, the reader is mostly left to their own devices to figure out what those things are.      So be cautioned, dear reader, that while Breaking Dawn neatly ties up many loose threads and brings a conclusion to Bella's story as promised (plus leaves us many other things to consider), it may very well leave you discomfited as well.
031606792X|5.0|I hate that everyone is freaking out about the 'message' behind these books. It was a great work of fiction, as was the rest of the series, well written and intriguing, fantastical, sucking you completely in. We are all entitled to our opinions, I understand that, this is mine. Don't read this book looking for a moral or a lesson, read it to enjoy it, to live for 700-something pages in a world full or werewolves, vampires and happily ever afters.

031606792X|2.0|If you want a book that rekindles the magic of the first three Twilight Saga installments, then BD is not for you.  The characters, especially the most beloved (Bella, Edward and Alice), become stoic and boringly mature overnight.  The youthful vigor and passion is replaced with a less romantic, and much less playful, demeanor.  Loose ends are tied up, but with the knowledge comes disappointment because the forever after is not nearly as wonderful as a Twilight-Eclipse reader would most likely picture it. The story is also depressingly anticlimactic.  After such a long read you hope for a little action, which builds, but is ultimately doused before any real trouble starts.  I suggest reading the first three installments and drawing you own conclusions because this conclusion will not be nearly as satisfying.

031606792X|3.0|After I read through this book the first time, I gave it an automatic 5 stars. But after reading it again, I must say that I've changed my mind on a few things, even though I still did enjoy it.    *SPOILERS*    The first part, from Bella's perspective, I absolutely loved. B0006IIKS0|5.0|A couple years back a film friend of mine put this film on his must-see agenda. He's a documentarian, so I didn't understand how a pop doc could stoke his interest. I said, Yeah, I thought about it, but there were a couple of other movies at the festival that seemed more my style. I liked Metallica, but a doc? I asked him what I thought was the obvious, \\"So you're a Metallica fan?\\"<br />\\"No,\\" he laughed self-consciously. He's not really into metal. He's more into worldbeat, Celtic music, and other esoterica. Some jazz, but not U.S. based. Very much into the international scene.<br />When he gave his feedback after the show, I expected him to give the hardline critical response and tell me at best it was pretty good, maybe overhyped. But his face lit up and burst into enthusiasm, envy, pride. It was so well done, it was just \\"amazing\\" he said. As a doc Director who'd been nominated for an Emmy, that was quite a compliment. He did mention \\"This is Spinal Tap\\" and for me, that kind of killed my interest. I'd seen that movie many many years ago, but it didn't stick in my mind as something that I could still remember years later as something unforgettable in some way.<br /><br />I heard buzz about \\"Some Kind of Monster\\" by a variety of critics, etc., after its initial screening at film festivals nationwide. That it was progressive, like nothing people had seen before, blah blah.<br /><br />I watched \\"Some Kind of Monster\\" when the DVD arrived. I was surprised to see 2 discs, and insert of material.<br /><br />I held my breath for the overhype that was likely fanning the film. Ever the skeptic. A film about a band going thru therapy?<br /><br />But it wasn't really about that. Hour after hour, I was riveted. In the film Lars mentioned it was really about relationships. It was that, and more. My impression of the film up til I sat down, and even listening to my friend's effusions was that it was a documentary about a band. I can't recall the \\"This is Spinal Tap\\" movie, but my recollection is that this is the case of apples and oranges. If the film had been buzzed less about some people going thru therapy than a story about a band family, then I probably would've seen the movie sooner not later. I can relate to that.<br /><br />I watched the film and the bonus CD of outtakes in one whole day. We're talking hours upon hours. It was that riveting, compelling, candid. I bought another CD for a friend who is a long time Metallica fan and occasional guitar player/drums player but he, for some reason, hadn't seen the film. Maybe it was the mention of the band going thru therapy that turned him off.<br /><br />It's an inspiring tale of a family getting their act together and pushing beyond their limits of current excellence and accomplishments. Being vulnerable and open to growing pains. When you're at the top, you don't have to go down. You can expand your horizons. Sometimes the music or your art or whatever you're possessed about possesses you and becomes bigger than the creators. A la Frankenstein or some other non-human machine. You risk being overcome if you don't take control and get grounded. Recover your humanity. For artists, sometimes they can get caught up in the craft, consumed even, even glorified for having been consumed.<br /><br />This was an up-close look into the lives of a family of musicians and how they got their house in order. Healed the parts. Got the humanity back. I don't think I've ever seen such candid, raw exposure like that from giants among us to whom others look up to as larger than life, bigger and better than human. Goliath. Fighting the monsters within them and between them.<br /><br />It was touching and horrible to see the struggles. Viewers could see their own humanity. You hope and pray that the musicians find their way back home. To realize why they came together, the joy in their craft, even in the hard work. Labor of love.<br /><br />It was almost like watching a married couple go thru counseling. We all know or have met people married for years, and are dumbstruck with near horror when we hear that divorce is looming on the horizon as a possible final solution to whatever ails their union. Counseling is no longer the last resort for marriage, it's sometimes a healthy maintenance requirement. As with anything, if you wait til it's nearly too late to make things better, it probably is too late. So for that, it's inspiring to see a family of musicians doing whatever they can to stay together, whether times or good or bad, practice does make perfect, and good habits  like bad ones become hard to break.<br /><br />In the movie, you see the band getting into healthy living. Making peace with some demons. The singer James, you find relief in his having a father figure in his life who's positive after years of being without something he needed. Lars has his father, apparently comes from money, and is very business oriented, practical, so you don't feel a whole lot of sympathy when he's complaining about people not going all out for him on his birthday. He's got the wife, the house, megamil sideline art deals, he had a fully intact family, he was revered and a big fish in a small town, him and his whole family. But James used music to escape and channel emotions. Like so many in the states, music, sports, etc., other creative or athletic activities were something positive avail to even those who had very little. It's almost like a source of hope and faith.<br /><br />Both Lars and James have families-wife and kids. I've heard it said that when men have their own kids, they begin to make peace with their own childhood. They rise to the challenge. If their childhood was less than what they'd like, there's the need to do better by their own kids, for some. And for some who had good childhoods, a need to keep up the legacy.<br />I've heard that in growing up and into their own families, some men will 'put away childish things' and concentrate on their home life. It was incredible to see married men trying to navigate a home life with a lifestyle that's not necessarily home-life friendly. It was touching to see the men include aspects of their home life, their wives, their kids.<br />Being the heroes in their home.<br /><br />With every challenge comes the opportunity to rise above and have a rebirth. Or not. Growing pains. If it takes a long time to develop bad habits, it surely takes some time to undo them. With people all over the world showing support and hope, the Metallica family remains intact, and gives back yet again to its legions of fans, old and new. We're all in this together. United a house stands, divided it falls. The world itself can be some kind of monster. We have to maintain our shared humanity, keep our eyes on the prize.<br /><br />A decades long relationship that has weathered many tests, trials and tribulations, how can you grow there? take note.ar horror when we hear that divorce is looming on the horizon as a possible final solution to whatever ails their union. Counseling is no longer the last resort for marriage, it's sometimes a healthy maintenance requirement. As with anything, if you wait til it's nearly too late to make things better, it probably is too late. So for that, it's inspiring to see a family of musicians doing whatever they can to stay together, whether times or good or bad, practice does make perfect, and good habits  like bad ones become hard to break.     In the movie, you see the band getting into healthy living. Making peace with some demons. The singer James, you find relief in his having a father figure in his life who's positive after years of being without something he needed. Lars has his father, apparently comes from money, and is very business oriented, practical, so you don't feel a whole lot of sympathy when he's complaining about people not going all out for him on his birthday. He's got the wife, the house, megamil sideline art deals, he had a fully intact family, he was revered and a big fish in a small town, him and his whole family. But James used music to escape and channel emotions. Like so many in the states, music, sports, etc., other creative or athletic activities were something positive avail to even those who had very little. It's almost like a source of hope and faith.    Both Lars and James have families-wife and kids. I've heard it said that when men have their own kids, they begin to make peace with their own childhood. They rise to the challenge. If their childhood was less than what they'd like, there's the need to do better by their own kids, for some. And for some who had good childhoods, a need to keep up the legacy.  I've heard that in growing up and into their own families, some men will 'put away childish things' and concentrate on their home life. It was incredible to see married men trying to navigate a home life with a lifestyle that's not necessarily home-life friendly. It was touching to see the men include aspects of their home life, their wives, their kids.  Being the heroes in their home.    With every challenge comes the opportunity to rise above and have a rebirth. Or not. Growing pains. If it takes a long time to develop bad habits, it surely takes some time to undo them. With people all over the world showing support and hope, the Metallica family remains intact, and gives back yet again to its legions of fans, old and new. We're all in this together. United a house stands, divided it falls. The world itself can be some kind of monster. We have to maintain our shared humanity, keep our eyes on the prize.    A decades long relationship that has weathered many tests, trials and tribulations, how can you grow there? take note.

I honestly felt like I was reading bad fan fiction.  If I had not been a fan of the earlier books and picked this one up, I would have stopped reading after Book I.  Bella pregnant with Edward's child?  (What about the fact that all bodily fluids become venom after you become a vampire?)  I felt like Stephenie Meyer created rules for her world and then broke them.  Another HUGE problem I had was Jacob's imprinting on Bella's child.  What the heck?!  Also, the Volturi just changing their minds and walking away from the brewing battle?  Too clean, too easy.      These books were about true love, sacrifice.  The emotions that I felt in the first three books were intense.  I was able to feel what these beloved characters felt.  During this book, I felt nothing.  I actually didn't even care if Bella or Edward lived!      I love this series, but am sad to think that my memories of the first three books will be tainted by the fourth.

031606792X|5.0|I am OBESSESED with this saga!! I literally devoured this book in a day and found it delectable and satiating.  I am concerned, however, with the copious amount of negative reviews on the book and I do understand many of their reserves although I do object.   First, many have complained about the lack of reality in the story, how certain things seem impossible such as tumultuous \\"wild ride\\" readers were taken on in a completely unrealistic book to begin with!! it seems contradictory to complain about realism in a fantastical world filled with vampires and werewolves!   Second, many saw the book to have lost the concept of sacrifice on the part of Bella and were deterred by her bearing a child at 18, getting hitched and being sex driven... I can understand their discretion considering the age group targeted by the saga and the influence it may have, however, having a 15 year old sister myself and being a 15 year old once, REALITY holds that these are evident concerns and concepts such an age group is plagued with at this day in age as much as we would rather not grasp the fact. I dont think it is a detrimental influence to their hold on morality or that it is telling them it is okay, but rather an eye opener to the responsibilities that arise from such decisions such as Bella's need to protect Nessie and be the best mother she can be.  It is a huge 180 from my initial impression of her being completely immature.  It shows the growth that comes with responsibility.  Through my own observations of pre-teens who have become pregnant, they fail to understand the responsibilities in order to adapt to our innate maternal nature as women and thus do not exhibit that love and devotion all mothers should feel, as Bella did. Such is evident in young girls that are not pregnant as well as they contemplate doing adult things without an adult conception.  Also, although I do not condone sex among such an audience, we must remember that despite Bella and Edward's urges to be sexually active (Which is involuntary and inevitable at any age) they decided to wait until MARRIAGE before they were active.  Not only did they wait until marriage, but they also chose to marry the person they irrevocably loved and pledged to be together forever in her commitment that was displayed by her willingness to become immortal with him. In this case, I find such to target the actual concerns of those reading the story and be a positive influence rather than a negative one.  Back to her SACRIFICE...even though in the end she hadnt sacrificed anything at all for the sake of a happy ending, I was satisfied with her INTENTION and decision to sacrifice herself if need be because I WOULD NOT be content with an unhappy ending.  Were people rooting for her to die in efforts to preserve the concept of sacrifice in the story??  She still had choices to make as well, but they were resolved by her decision to solely protect her child!  Onto the flattened image of the rest of the characters... I can see what people are complaining about, however, such didnt even occur until the middle of the story when things began to get chaotic.  I actually found this void of the original characters essences to truly feed the tumultuous image of the incidents in my head.  Consider our own responses in the event of a disaster and how we are almost not ourselves.  In this case, the whole family was in danger...each and every one of them had the notion that everyone they loved may perish.  Of course they didnt seem like themselves! they had more important things to concern themselves with than to act \\"normal.\\"  This \\"wild ride\\" had to have been expected considering we are dealing with vampires and werewolves.  One musnt expect things to remain normal in such an aberrant story.  Like I said, I personally LOVED the book and laid my book down with a complacent smirk upon my face at its conclusion.  I thought I would be left disappointed at its end and hungry for more, but I was only left with the thirst to relive the saga again and again.  It felt complete!  I was satisfied with how stephenie maintained \\"edge of the seat\\" content, and even with Jacobs imprinting (although many thought it was disturbing even though he did not have sexual feelings for her...yet, he just wanted to make her happy--> its not like it hasnt happened before with a member of his own pack).  I also enjoyed the fact that Bella had the chance to experience the ultimate human experience of having a child created from love that was his and her flesh and blood! I wont say any more so I that I dont spoil it any more than I have already for readers but I applaud stephenie for satisfying me in every way with the events that transpired even though I know we all have our own \\"taste\\" preferences. Ultimately, the story still held a strong message inherent in Bella's self growth and maturity as we watched it progress through the books, in her responsibilities as a wife, mother, sister, and daughter and in her strength and courage in the face of danger.  P.S. I guess the only thing I hated was the NAME! I wish Nessies name wasnt so damn complicated and long.

B0000024YL|3.0|There are three reasons why you may want to buy this album and one why you may not:<br /><br />1.) If you're a first generation S&G fans who copped the vinyl when it first came out and is feeling a touch nostalgic, this is definitely the disc for you.<br /><br />2.) If you're not a Boomer, but a Gen X or Y-er who is doing their best to recreate Mom & Pop's listening experience for yourself, and you are big on hearing what previous generations actually heard when they rushed home from the record store with this disc in hand back in the summer of '72, then this is also the disc for you.<br /><br />3.) Finally, if you're an S&G completist who just has to have everything they've ever released, then once again, you're looking at your disc.<br /><br />However, if you're simply searching for a comprehensive S&G collection, then buyer beware.  There are several reasons why this disc doesn't fit the bill in that regard.  First of all, the obvious: it was released in 1972, and although all of their studio releases had wrapped up two years earlier, any post-72 work you may be looking for does not appear here (think Concert in Central Park, etc.).<br /><br />Secondly, much of their pre-1972 work is also ignored.  At 14 tracks and just over 44 minutes, this CD simply comes up a little short. Perhaps most importantly, if you're unfamiliar with this album then you need to know that the familiar studio versions of several songs (including 'For Emily, Whenever I May Find Her,' 'The 59th Street Bridge Song (Feelin' Groovy)' and 'Homeward Bound') are eschewed in favor of live versions. If any of this is of any importance to you, then be aware that there are more comprehensive S&G collections out there at reasonable prices, including 'The Best of Simon & Garfunkel' and the 2 disc 'The Essential Simon & Garfunkel'.<br /><br />Peace and Happy Listening!

031606792X|1.0|This novel disappoints on several levels. I found the plot to be tedious and forced, the characters to have changed radically from the previous three books in the series, a heavy dose of misogyny in the text, and ultimately, major reversals from the previous trajectory of the series.    (Spoilers below)    First, the story's plot failed to satisfy me. The most interesting element of the plot to me was the impending appearance of the Volturi and the question about their motivations as the guardians/royalty of the vampire world. This question fizzled out both because Meyer introduced at least twenty new vampires too late in the novel and because once the Volturi appeared, she missed the chance to give the Cullens and their allies the chance to fight for their beliefs (thereby showing their commitment to these beliefs).    I also found the characters massively disappointing. Although Bella spends much of the third part thinking about how her personality has remained the same since her change into a vampire, she has lost her two primary characteristics (her clumsiness and cooking for Charlie). I found the scenes between her and her daughter awkward and unconvincing. Edward became very wooden and flat, as did Alice, and Bella's human friends, her parents, and a lot of the Quileute pack disappeared almost entirely.     Bella's changes also reinforce the books' inherent misogyny. From the very first book, Bella's only interest is Edward. Even putting aside his paternalistic attitude of \\"I know what you need and what is best for you better than you do,\\" reflected in both his dialog and his actions (like buying her the armored car), I find it disturbing that she is so centered on him. In the fourth book, as Bella accepts his many gifts (the car, the house, the jewelry) she becomes less interesting as a character. Other disturbing elements of the plot include Rosalie's and Leah's depression about being infertile and Renee's willingness to ignore her own life experiences to encourage her daughter to take the same actions that she later found to be irresponsible and mistakes. While neither choosing to raise a family instead of going to college or having a career nor wanting children are inherently anti-feminist, I thought that the way all these elements worked together in this book created the expectation for the female characters that they only need succeed in the home, rather than fully explore all the options available to them.     Finally, this book reverses the messages of the first three books. In Twilight, New Moon, and Eclipse, it becomes very clear that Bella cannot have it all--she must choose between two types of lives, which comes down to a decision between happiness and security (Jacob) and all-consuming love (Edward). In a series of barely-believable plot twists (which incidentally violate the internal consistency of the world Ms. Meyer has created) Ms. Meyer not only gives Bella everything she wanted (contact with her family, Edward, and Jacob as a platonic best friend) but the thing she didn't even know to request (a daughter). In this sense, Breaking Dawn betrays the story of Eclipse and makes Bella's struggles and difficult choice almost meaningless--she doesn't have to sacrifice anything after all.    I would not recommend this book to anyone; it failed to develop the potentially interesting points of conflict and refused to allow any of its characters to face the consequences of their actions (and thus to grow).
B0000683DH|5.0|The Good Things<br />*Excellent action and some gorgeous special effects (including a very early example of CGI effects).<br />*Filming style is great and very original.<br />*Production design is a vast improvement over the first \\"Star Trek\\" film.<br />*Sound design is splendid too.<br />*The storyline is great. 031606792X|5.0|I will admit that when I first realized that Bella was pregnant, I was shocked.  I honestly never saw that coming.  BUT...to be completely fair, I didn't know what to expect from BD at all.  I knew I wanted three things to happen...  1) Edward and Bella get married  2) Bella become a vampire  3) Find a way for Jake to be okay with Bella's choice and change.  And, they all happened.  Given, not in ways that I expected, but in ways that I was okay with...after some thought...lol.  I'm probably the biggest vampire nerd ever and I've never understood why.  But, from the age of 11 I've devoured any and all vampire books.  (Most that an eleven year old probably shouldn't have read.)  And believe me when I say that I've come across way more disturbing situations than what most of you are complaining about.    So...Bella got married at 18. All of you are freaking out over this instead of her choosing to become immortal at 18?  Hmmm...priorities...  And yes, its way off the wall that she became pregnant, but I've read many other vampire novels that have dealt with that.  IT'S SUPERNATURAL!!!  Therefore, vampires, werewolves, etc...they don't have to conform to our biological rules.  Just because YOU don't understand it, doesn't mean that its not possible.  The mere fact that they ARE vampires should attest to that.  It's biologically impossible...yet you're reading a vampire novel and griping about biology?  You're reading about a fictional/fantastical world and wanting to add our human limitations to it?  How is that any fun at all?  Of course you didn't enjoy the book!!!  Use your imaginataion.  All in all, after I got over the shock of the pregnancy, I enjoyed the book immensely!  I laughed histarically when I realized that Jacob was going to imprint on Renesmee.  Oh come on...it's funny!!  It did bother me at first, sure...but again...it's FICTION!  And, yes, it was an easy fix for the Bella/Jacob thing, but why couldn't it be?  Why does everything have to be so hard.  And so what if everything was \\"wrapped up in a nice bow\\" at the end.  Why for the love of God would anyone want to read something that ends realistically?  Don't you get enough of that out of your life?  Personally, I read books to escape reality...maybe that's why I'm drawn to vampires (who knows?).  If I wanted reality, I wouldn't read fantasy/fiction...and ESPECIALLY not vampire fantasy/fiction.  Good grief!  And on my last note...how dare any of you attack Stephenie's parenting?  Do you honestly think that she would persuade her children to take her books literally?  If you want to attack a writer over her book, that's fine.  It's your opinion...but you should never call into question a writer's parenting abilities because you don't agree with her book.  It's low and childish.

031606792X|1.0|I've enjoyed each installment of the \\"Twilight\\" saga more than its predecessor so, I was all set to love \\"Breaking Dawn\\". All Bella's worries about being a newborn vampire with a ravenous thirst for blood? Didn't happen. Why? Who knows, who cares because she looks like a supermodel now. It just goes on and on and the whole confrontation with the tired, old Volturi at the end was so boring. It's like Ms.Meyer wanted so badly to give Bella and by extension her fans, everything we could possibly want, a perfect husband, a perfect child, a perfect face, a designer wardrobe.. She forgot to tell us a good story.     I'mso sad to series end this way.

031606792X|1.0|Breaking Dawn exemplified for me exactly why Stephenie is a novice writer.      In her previous books she set us up to expect two major conflicts: Bella/Edward/Jacob, and the Venturi.  In Breaking Dawn Stephenie completely wimps out, give us predictable and just downright awful solutions.  The entire time I was reading I kept saying, \\"This is ridiculous.  She's cheating us!\\"      In Eclipse, she has made it clear that Bella is IN LOVE with both Jacob and Edward.  Yet in Breaking Dawn she clears that up.. poof!.. by having Jacob impress on Bella's daughter.  I'm sorry, but what happened to Bella being in love with him?  It's not enough to add a few lines about Bella beaming when Jacob walks in the room, then after baby is born attribute it to the baby knowing Jacob from the womb.  What a cheat! Stephenie.. this is cheating!    In New Moon, she sets up the Venturi as powerful, scary and awe-inspiring. Their leaders are fascinated by Alice and Edward, and covet them. Then she gives us Breaking Dawn, with a drawn out rambling discussion at the end between the Venturi and the Cullens.  Where the Venturi are stoppped because of a bunch of witnesses?  Oh, and a whole bunch of powerful vampires most of whom we've never heard of before.  Oh, and the sudden appearance of a new race.  How convenient!  And the sad thing is.. that by taking this tact Stephenie makes all her main characters (the ones we know and love) take a back seat to the story.  We get very little dialogue, and very very few scenes between characters that we know.      Which brings me to my biggest issue here.  From the beginning of the series, this has been BELLA's story.  Bella is the voice of the series.  It's Bella and Edward that made us love the story.  And ultimately it's Bella and Edward's story that we want to hear.  In Breaking Dawn, we get a few chapters of the old Bella we know and love... then poof! we get a third of the book told from Jacob's perspective.  Jacob is telling us what is happening to Bella... while she is dying!  Stephenie literally makes Bella a secondary character.  Then once Bella has her baby and becomes a vampire, well, you don't get any time to get to know her with her new life.  It's rush rush rush, and baby, baby, baby until the end.  Move over Bella, this is Nessie's story now (setting us up for a sequel?), and forget Edward.. he gets a scene or two, but really becomes a tertiary character.    I was looking forward to Breaking Dawn because I wanted to hear Bella's story. I wanted to really get to know her as a vampire.  And I wanted Bella and Edward's story.  Instead I got a baby story, and my final image of Bella is of baby on her hip, in some sleek new outfit, and with a new defensive (passive) power that protects her family.  I didn't know her anymore, and Stephenie illustrated to me that she completely lacks the skills a writer needs to transform a character through a life change.    Never mind the whole implication of teenage love to marriage to instant baby.  With today's news about teenage pregancy pacts you'd think Meyer would have a bit more of a clue... but that's a whole other review I could write!      This author tried her best, but at this time in her life just lacks the skills to deliver.  Needs more practice, and a editor and publishing house that's a bit more honest with her.
031606792X|5.0|As I read the reviews of people writing of this novel as \\"unbelievable....impossible...) I am reminded that, well...Vampires and werewolves fall into that category. And although Bella  became pregnant with Edward's child may seem an \\"impossibility\\" to those readers who are envisioning their own preconceived happy ending, this is not out of the grasp of the concept of what we are reading, people!     Bella's character.  Stays true. Stays self sacrificing and bold to a point. Stays STRONG as she always was.  Edward. Pretty much remans the same.  Even as Bella as a vampire, the love is still just as strong and meaningful as ever. Still everything.  Nessie. What else could you ask for?  Jacob.  Saw that one coming a mile away.  Saw that one coming with the first kind word between vampire and werewolf in the other books.    This is an epic novel. It is not (in my view) intended for the younger reader due to such graphic description Meyer so dramatically hands over. It is an amazing roller-coaster ride of twists and turns that none of us expects, yet in some parts we are so thankful for it.    This IS the ultimate happy ending. This is what EVERYONE wants. Kudos to Meyer for giving that to her readers as well as herself. It is so apparant that she loves these characters. She can't part with them and feels an urgent sense of self preservation. It is her own. This is her story. It is so evident that she wrote it for herself. But in that regard, she was mindful of her reader and their expectations.    This is the end. Thanks Stephenie for an overwhelmingly emotional piece of literature. Just look at the way you are affecting people! Good or bad...a truly great writer affects people...and you have...(for the 4th time in this series...)  :-)

031606792X|4.0|Pros:  Bella is a more likeable character and her romance with Edward is less cloying, more action and unexpected twists, less angst time.    Cons:  As with the other books, I don't think that Meyer thinks enough about message and theme.    This review contains spoilers!      I don't care what anyone says, this is the best book in the Twilight series.  To begin with, there is so much more going on.  With the other books, I always felt that too much space was wasted with Bella angsting because Edward didn't love her or Jacob DID love her or she wasn't good enough for Edward and the actual plot was just tacked on.  In Breaking Dawn, these internal conflicts and internal commentary on how awesome Edward is fade to the background a bit, though they are certainly still there.  This book has a wedding, a honeymoon, a difficult pregnancy and birth, Bella becoming a vampire and dealing with her powers, Jacob's conflict with splitting from his pack and then imprinting on Nessie, a half-vampire toddler who grows at an amazing rate, and a very significant conflict with the Volturi.  The only part where I felt that there wasn't enough action was during the honeymoon when it went on about Edward and Bella's sex life.      I also think that Bella comes off as a much more likeable character in this book.  She is less whiny throughout and it is nice to see her focused on something other than Edward.  Even if it is just shifting some of her focus to Nessie, it seems much more mature and healthy that she isn't so wrapped up in ONE person.  The dynamics of Edward and Bella's relationship as vampires make me wish that he had bitten her books ago.  It is nice to see them interact as equals.  Before Bella was a vampire, Edward always seemed kind of controlling and semi-abusive and Bella seemed needy and clingy.      At first I was disappointed to have to read so many chapters from Jacob's point of view.  Even though I like him, the book was just getting good at the point that the switchoccurred.  I believe that I may have liked Jacob's point of view even better than the rest of the book, though.  The imprinting with Nessie was also less creepy than I would have expected.    I did not mind the happy ending in general, but I do think that it may have been stronger and more realistic if some of the \\"good\\" characters died.  It wouldn't have to be the main ones -- just someone to add some pain and reflection to Bella's perfect fairytale ending.      I was not completely satisfied with the underlying messages in this book.  The honeymoon scenes, in particular, made me cringe.  \\"Hey girls, he doesn't really MEAN to hurt you even if you wake up with bruises and there is talk of forced abortions.  He just can't control himself.\\"  I was expecting that I would have to cringe at some point, though.  I found these types of disturbing messages in all the books and at least they seem to be mostly gone by the end of Breaking Dawn.      I do wonder if we would be so worried about what type of message the book sends if it wasn't Young Adult.  It is possible to enjoy a good story even if you don't feel comfortable with all the themes, and that is exactly what I did with Breaking Dawn.  I enjoyed it very, very much as a great story with engaging characters.

B000YABIQ6|5.0|In terms of writing (story, dialogue, character development) acting, direction, and the great, smoothly polished look of every frame, this fine show is as good as TV gets.  And it needs to be said that the best of TV in recent years -- Friday Night Lights, Damages, Battlestar Galactica, The Shield, and going back a few seasons, Everwood, Veronica Mars, Jack & Bobby -- outshines all but the absolute cream of movies.    Alas, the great bulk of television programming is still the \\"wasteland\\" it was long ago dubbed, but back in the 60s, 70s and 80s when there was almost nothing worth watching on the tube, I can recall that it was every TV actor's aspiration to graduate to \\"features\\" where the best work was being done (and where the big salaries were).    Today, however, for those actors fortunate enough to be working on shows like MadMen, or others of that caliber, they are already working at the pinnacle of their craft.  They are collaborating daily with the most talented people in their industry -- writers, directors, producers, set designers and fellow actors -- all of whom share an artistic commitment to do great work.  And it shows . . . in every aspect of every episode.      Viewed from the perspective of that kind of fulfilling work experience, the only remaining lure of most movies roles could only be the money.    MadMen is not just TV at its best, it is dramatic art at its best.  Check it out -- preferably on DVD!
0743290119|3.0|Chasing Harry Winston is the story of three college girlfriends in New York on the eve of a big event: their thirtieth birthdays. Emmy has recently been dumped by her long-time boyfriend and takes her friends up on a dare to be more risqu&eacute;. Leigh works her dream job as a senior book editor and is engaged to the perfect man, yet she is searching for true happiness. Adriana is the spoiled daughter of a famous supermodel whose life appears ideal but who knows that her looks won't win her the world forever and seeks a purpose to her existence. They all decide that within one year, each will drastically change their life. Weisberger intertwines each woman's quest for love, life, and happiness into an emotional novel that speaks to the heart and allows us into the world of young, hip New Yorkers.<br /><br />I had very high expectations when I began this novel because I adored Weisberger's book, The Devil Wears Prada, but I honestly was rather disappointed. While this novel does have all the glitz and glamour, not all the characters are well developed. Emmy and Leigh are very believable women. I could relate to them, enjoy discovering their personalities and joining them on their adventures. Adrianna, on the other hand, seems to be one-dimensional. Her looks are written about in excess. The novel was also a little cruder than I anticipated.<br /><br />Even though it won't be standard reading for a literary class, Chasing Harry Winston makes for a pleasant beach read. The prose is engaging, the characters amusing, and the plot interesting. It allows the reader to become lost for a few blissful hours in a world far different from the one most of us live in. This novel is good for a lighthearted read.<br /><br />by Jennifer Melville<br />for Story Circle Book Reviews<br />reviewing books by, for, and about women
031606792X|3.0|This review will contain spoilers.    Unlike most people here, I did not hate this book. Of course, I have minor complaints, the perfect Bella as a vampire, the child with the horrible name (and worse nickname), the surprising lack of Edward and Alice. But those are insignificant compared to the gist of the problem, which is simply, the lack of emotional depth.    We had such a huge sense of the emotions running through the first three books in this series, it was easy to get caught up in. The story was addicting. We were drawn to the characters. In Breaking Dawn, there is so much happening and so much information, that the emotions became easily clouded. In my honest opinion, it should have been broken into 2 separate books, sold 6 months apart from one another. The first book ending with less of description of Jacob imprinting so that could have been revealed in the 2nd and ending simply with the reader knowing that Bella did survive. That would've been enough of a pull for the readers to want to buy the fifth book. Vampire!Bella has always been a draw. And, with the book split in two pieces like that, there would've been more room to examine some of the things that the author seemed to skip or skim over this time.    The previous books not only were emotional drawing (and draining), but the author speckled quite a bit of her own wry sense of humor throughout and the finer details that many people enjoyed. Some of that was still present, but we missed some things that we, as an audience, would've liked to have seen. In the essence of time and space, I'm sure, Meyer was forced to 'tell us what happened' in several situations, versus 'showing us'. Showing is far more effective and the story would've benefited from more showing and less telling. Something as minor as us being able to see Bella run into Rosalie's arms at the airport and forcing herself to turn her head so that she couldn't see the look of betrayal on her husband's face... and then the ensuing arguments, of course. Or as insignificant as Bella getting her 'after' car. Of course she's not thrilled with it, but goodness, Meyer never even said what color it was. Not that it's a big deal, but cars are such a big deal in this series... you'd think that there would've been a bit more information there.     It's those things, no matter how small, that add to the dynamics of a story, and those things which were lacking. And, I have to say, that it likely wasn't Stephenie Meyer's fault that these things weren't present... it was probably the editors. It is their job after all. But, they also should've suggested 2 books to allow her to tell her story with as much detail as she wanted to.    For those that are still bashing the books, my advice is to let it sit, try to eliminate the expectations that you'd had for this book from your head, and then pick it up and reread. It is truly a much better book the second time around. It's easier to see the tiny little sentences that have been tossed in there to try to keep the reader on that same emotional level as the author is. The things that she wanted the readers to understand so that the story doesn't completely fail. Her intent is there, even if there were problems with getting her vision into the readers' minds.
031606792X|1.0|I am not a Twilight hater. In contrast, I like the first three books quite a bit: they're fun, light, romantic and fluffy. Stephanie Meyer was never a great YA writing talent like Philip Pullman or Tamora Pierce, but I liked the world and characters she had created. I picked up Breaking Dawn the day after it came out.  2 hours later, I chucked it across the room in a fit of fury, and only the guilt of spending $15 made me finish it.   THIS IS SEXIST TRASH  As a nineteen-year-old girl, I'd say I should be able to relate what goes on in Bella's head. Although multiple reviewers have outlined the problems with Breaking Dawn, I'd like to throw in a few of my own. (spoilers)  -I related with Bella in the first couple books because she was learning how to be independent and fall in love at the same time. And she didn't want children. But SUDDENLY Stephanie Meyer decides to throw in some abortion controversy and have Bella (a seemingly sane eighteen-year-old) throw her life away for a child all the while exclaiming \\"Oh, who needs education? I married my rich boyfriend in a pretty wedding! And I can have a house and a baby! Woopee!\\" Religious conservatism/mormonism abounds, and while I normally wouldn't have an issue, it's the sudden reversal of character in order to preach these values that made me want to throw up. The author has absolutely NO IDEA WHAT TEENAGERS ARE LIKE. None. Bella is like some bizarre creature from a horny thirteen-year-old's fan fiction. Additionally, I found it extremely disturbing that Edward pretty much owns Bella's sexuality. And the sex scenes were just...blah. Boring. Poorly written. Stupid.   -The writing was laughably bad. And there were zillions of characters who lacked any sort of description, making it really confusing. As I am currently running through the agent process myself, I have absolutely no doubt that this would have been laughed out of the publishing house (if Stephanie Meyer hadn't been given free reign to do whatever she wanted).   -Jacob imprinted Bella's child????? Is this a sick joke??? \\"Here Mr. Lover, you can't have me, but I will force my daughter to love you and you can bang her instead. Gross.   -Edward tries to save Bella's life by getting Jacob to impregnate her? Um........... so, Bella can't be happy unless she has a child. Right.   -Graphic scenes of Bella drinking blood through a straw. Enough said.  -Racism!!! Why are all the characters from brazil described as wild and crazy with \\"cappuccino\\" skin? (One YA agent writes on her website that she throws out any manuscript with coffee-descriptions for skin.  -And for the ten bazillionth time, THAT HORRID NAME!!!!!! renesmee???? AHHHHH    In other words, Stephanie Meyer, please don't pollute the beautiful YA fantasy world with any more of your garbage. Seriously.

B0002IQMKM|5.0|The Best of Talking Heads is the latest in a (relatively short compared to other artists) line of \\"Greatest Hits\\" for the band.  However, if you are someone who is looking for a single-disc package of the best songs from each of the band's albums, this is the CD for you.  With an average of two songs from each album and a running time of over 75 minutes, it gives a very good overview of the band.  The songs are very well picked given the limitations of the medium, and I don't think you can do much better when trying to turn a casual listener into a full-fledged fan.  Sure, you can argue about the selections: \\"Houses in Motion\\" over \\"Born Under Punches\\"?  No \\"I Zimbra\\"?  But remember, this CD is for \\"new\\" listeners, and throwing songs like \\"Born Under Punches\\" in is like trying to teach calculus to a five-year-old.  As for \\"I Zimbra\\", it pales in comparison to the other three selections from Fear of Music.  Overall, this album is a great conversion tool to pop in while driving with a friend, which is exactly what it is for.

031606792X|5.0|I thoroughly enjoyed the final installment of the Twilight Series! It was everything I could ask for and more. The book has a wonderful balance of character development and plot and gives a satisfying ending to the story of Bella and Edward. There were a few surprises along the way, which I won't give away-but I truly loved the plot twists! This book is definitely not intended for young readers, as it has sexual scenes and a few \\"gory\\" scenes, but everything is done tastefully and provides parents an opportunity for good discussions with older teens. The story has excitement and romance, suspense and resolution-I finished it feeling so happy and content with the outcome!    In response to the unfortunately poor reviews, I suggest the idea that the best books provide cause for discussion-which this obviously has. I don't feel like Meyer set out to change the world with her story, or convince young people that vampire love exists as the only way to true happiness. Instead, she has provided readers with a chance to enter a world as magical as it is dangerous, and escape reality for a few hours. I enjoyed the growth Bella's character sees after the past years of mistakes and hardship. She does work for her \\"happily ever after\\" and sometimes life does work out-I believe in happy endings, and I am glad Ms. Meyer does, too!    All in all, this is a wonderful final installment that I will read over and over again!

1577314808|5.0|Eckhart Tolle's acclaimed book \\"The Power of Now\\" has many powerful lessons for living. It's a transformational tool to help us shift our consciousness and a signpost for awakening.<br />The life lessons that were the most helpful to me included:<br />The answer to the human dilemma cannot be found through the intellect but through consciousness (awareness) and our response to what happens.<br />Consciousness is the only lasting and meaningful aspect of who we are. It transcends our bodies, minds, emotions, possessions and events. Yet most of our energy and attention goes into doing, work, appointments, to-do lists, mind-clutter, possessions and commitments. The opposite of doing is being: stillness, spaciousness, awareness, silence and spontaneity. Doing is never enough if we neglect Being.<br />Recognizing that our ego, the unawakened self, is an imposter pretending to be us.<br />Making ourselves right or wrong is one to the principle mind egoic patterns. Nothing will satisfy us as long as the ego remains in place.<br />The power of allowing lies in noninterference, non-doing, in Presence, in the space between the clutter of thought and emotion. Wisdom, joy, love, creativity and aliveness are in the gap between the perception and the interpretation.<br />Being present is infinitely more powerful than anything we could say or do.<br />Surrender to pain it's not who we are. Pain is a doorway out of our ego prison. It's not the pain but the identification with the pain that forces us to relive the past again and again and keeps us in a state of unconsciousness.<br />To stop our egoistic body identification we should shift our attention from our external thought to the feeling of aliveness inside. The intensely alive energy field is our life energy, the bridge between the form and the formless.<br />What matters in not what we say and believe but how we act and react.<br />Whatever we think the world is withholding from us, we are withholding from the world. Just act as if we had it, and it will come. When we start giving we will receive.<br />The source of abundance is inside us. When we acknowledge the abundance around us it awakens to dormant abundance within.<br />Whatever we perceive, experience, do, think or feel is content. Content is what absorbs most people. Content is not essence. Essence is the formless inner space of consciousness. The universe is an indivisible whole in which all things are interconnected. The atoms that make up your body were once forged inside stars.<br />When we don't mind what happens we are aligned with what is. When we align with the present moment our actions become empowered by the intelligence of Life itself.<br />The ego can never be aligned with the present moment. The ego sees the present as a means to an end, an obstacle or an enemy. We become Present when we see our dysfunction and make friends with the Now. Presence is a state of inner spaciousness.<br />Life is always now. There is only this moment. The elimination of time from our consciousness is the elimination of ego.<br />When we say yes to the Now, the Now becomes a doorway into the formless and the separation between the world and God dissolves.<br />The joy of Being, which is our true happiness, cannot come to us through any form, possession, achievement, person, or event. It emanates from the formless dimension within us, from consciousness itself and thus is one with who we are. If we are content with being nobody in particular we align ourselves with the power of the universe.<br />Through us the universe is becoming aware of itself.<br />We are so consumed by time that we have forgotten eternity, which is our destiny. Eternity is the living reality of who we are.<br />Non-resistance, non-judgment and non-attachment give true freedom. Through acceptance, we become spacious inside.<br />Being aware of breathing for a year is more powerfully transformative than attending any courses. The more we are aware of the breath, themore its natural depth will reestablish itself.  Conscious breathing stops the mind. Three conscious breaths stops compulsions.  Discover inner space by creating gaps in our thinking. Awareness is Presence, consciousness without thought, and connection with universal intelligence. The mind of God is consciousness.<br />A belief in God is a poor substitute for the living reality of God manifesting every moment in our lives.<br />Give others full attention. The space of awareness is more important than what we are talking about.<br />Our entire life journey ultimately consists of the step we are taking at this moment.<br />Live with uncertainty, even enjoy it. There is ultimately no such thing as \\"my\\" life, since \\"my\\" and \\"life\\" are one.<br />All of the ancient religions point to two fundamental truths. The first is that humankind's \\"normal\\" state of mind is dysfunctional. Hinduism calls it maya the veil of delusion, Buddhism refers to it as dukka or suffering, Christianity calls it \\"original sin\\" meaning \\"to miss the point\\" to live unskillfully or blindly.<br />Although humankind is intelligent and our achievements are impressive in science, medicine, technology, architecture and the arts our intelligence is also tainted with insanity.<br />The second truth in all religions is that a radical transformation of human consciousness is possible. The Hindus called the transformation Enlightenment, the Buddhists Liberation, and the Christians Salvation.<br />Humanity's greatest achievement is not science and technology but the recognition of our individual and collective madness. The moment we recognize that \\"normal\\" human existence is a  collective nightmare we begin a process of healing and transcendence.<br />Many religious teachings have become distorted, divisive and part of a collective insanity. Yet in spite of all the insanity in the name of religion, the Truth to which they all point still shines through. There have been individuals throughout history who experienced a shift in consciousness and realized within themselves the Truth to which all religions point. They discovered that being \\"spiritual\\" has nothing to do with what we believe and everything to do with our state of consciousness.<br />Our purpose is to awaken from the ego-created earth-drama. This is the new earth (the tiltle of his next book).ous breathing stops the mind. Three conscious breaths stops compulsions.  Discover inner space by creating gaps in our thinking. The first is that humankind's \\"normal\\" state of mind is dysfunctional. Hinduism calls it maya the veil of delusion, Buddhism refers to it as dukka or suffering, Christianity calls it \\"original sin\\" meaning \\"to miss the point\\" to live unskillfully or blindly. 1416550518|1.0|THE HOUSE AT RIVERTON was a big disappointment to me, pretty much from its opening chapter.  In its beginning I saw a good deal of similarity, hopefully unintentional, to the opening of the 1997 film \\"Titanic\\".  In RIVERTON, we have Grace, the nearly 100-year-old heroine, having to relive a pivotal event in her life because of the curiosity of a filmmaker.  Shades of Rose, the nearly 100-year-old heroine of \\"Titanic\\", reliving the pivotal event in her life because of the curiosity of the undersea treasure-seeker.<br /><br />Later in the story it also became apparent that Grace of RIVERTON would share with Rose of \\"Titanic\\" the experience of a woman breaking free from the mould they were expected to occupy and living their lives in dramatically different ways than expected of women of their time.<br /><br />But actually the author's usurping that particular theme didn't bother me as much as other unconscious (I hope), \\"borrowings\\".  As I continued to read RIVERTON I kept thinking:  \\"haven't I read/seen this somewhere before?\\"  And indeed, I had.<br /><br />In the Author's Note at the back of the novel, Ms. Morton references \\"Upstairs, Downstairs\\", the popular 1970's British TV serial. Reflected in the relationship between the characters of the maid, Grace, and the mistress, Hannah, were shades of the relationship between Rose and Elizabeth, and later Rose and Hazel (characters from \\"Upstairs, Downstairs\\").  Mr. Hamilton the butler, with his speeches on duty, loyalty to the Family and the invisibility of a good servant, could easily be Mr. Hudson, the devoted family butler from \\"Upstairs, Downstairs\\".  The character of Emmeline in her scatty, 1920's flapper phase could easily be Georgina from \\"Upstairs, Downstairs\\".  And so on...<br /><br />But even aside from this, I thought the plot stayed static and somewhat, I'm sorry to say this, blah.  I think I solved the mystery surrounding the death of the poet quite a while before the answer was revealed (this being the mystery that the filmmaker is investigating, with Grace's assistance).<br /><br />The author seemed to be trying too hard to evoke an era she loves; perhaps loves too much.  I didn't feel drawn into this story or into these characters' lives.  Old Grace/young Grace; Hannah; Emmeline, or the poet Robbie Hunter - they didn't strike me as being anywhere near *living* people; they remain shades of the author's imagination.<br /><br />For me THE HOUSE AT RIVERTON doesn't succeed as a \\"family saga\\"; as a \\"WWI drama\\"; as a mystery, or, most unfortunately of all, as an original, satisfying piece of fiction peopled with believable characters.investigating, with Grace's assistance).      The author seemed to be trying too hard to evoke an era she loves; perhaps loves too much.  I didn't feel drawn into this story or into these characters' lives.  Old Grace/young Grace; Hannah; Emmeline, or the poet Robbie Hunter - they didn't strike me as being anywhere near *living* people; they remain shades of the author's imagination.         For me THE HOUSE AT RIVERTON doesn't succeed as a \\"family saga\\"; as a \\"WWI drama\\"; as a mystery, or, most unfortunately of all, as an original, satisfying piece of fiction peopled with believable characters.
031606792X|5.0|I couldn't imagine how the author could end this story in a satisfying way and had told myself I wouldn't buy the last one.  Yesterday, I weakened, bought it, and then sat and read it straight through.  I couldn't put it down!<br /><br />I don't want to give away the plot to anyone who hasn't read it yet -- there are too many nice surprises that should be discovered as you read it.  But I believe this is well written, well constructed, and contains a surprising end.<br /><br />I do agree with the criticism that Bells seems to have it all without adequate sacrifice -- but who cares??  There aren't too many happily ever after vampire stories, are there?  And this one truly is happy ever after forever.<br /><br />Thanks, for the lovely series, Ms. Meyer.  I hope you are working on your next book!

031606792X|5.0|Spoilers below)  Although Breaking Dawn has left many people with a sour taste in their mouth I found the novel to be just as intriguing as the first three installments.  When I sit down to read a book, I want to be entertained and become immersed in a good story.  I want to feel my feet lift off the floor, and I want to see the tale unfold in my head like I was actually a spectator present.   What has Stephanie Meyer presented us with if not an interesting STORY?  Granted, the whole novel twisted and turned down an unexpected path, but what's a story without risk? Without shock? Without surprise?     Reading over some posts that are less than appetizing with their low star rate and passionate words seems to me a total contradiction. Obviously the book was able to evoke emotion and diversity out of its readers. Even if it was not a good story, those factors alone show that the novel made an impact. That in itself should be appreciated.    Many people have also criticized on the fact that the novel is totally off base and unreal (Ex. Bella having a baby with Edward). But yet they must realize the story is only fiction? As much as some would hope to believe, we do not live in a world filled with vampires, werewolves, and mythical creatures. So what's the problem if the story veers off even more from our reality? After all, these story's don't take place in our world. If Stephanie Meyer decides its possible in the world she has created, then I don't see the problem.     Also If you look back at the first three books, each one has been gradually becoming more fictional, loosing more and more factors of reality. Why not go all out in the final book? It only seemed right since the previous three were building up to this finale.     Here's another question. How else could it of ended? In the end didn't we want Bella to become an immortal or at least have a happy life with Edward? Jacob to find closure and a way to move forward after loosing Bella? Weren't WE looking for closure? In these cases the novel undeniably delivered. True it might not have been in any conventional way expected, but at least it was interesting. And yes, Bella does get more than everything she could have wanted in the end, but so what? Doesn't the character we've followed through three novels deserve nothing less?  I'm glad she finally got her happy ending!    Yet, here is what disappoints me most. With the understanding that these fascinating novels are FICTIONAL, and are only telling an epic STORY, why do some feel the need to apply them to real life? Society has made it so that when we see an 18 year old having a baby or getting married it's instantly reiterated as promoting teenage pregnancy or underage marriage. Now this is what feels off base to me. If after reading one of these books someone says \\"Hmm I'm gonna try to have a baby and get married just like Bella,\\" It seems to me that they have seriously misunderstood the concept of a fictional story.  In no way did it feel like Meyer was trying to promote anything but the story and love of her main characters.    All in all, I wish people could realize and appreciate the story Stephanie Meyer has told. I see this story as her baby. She developed it, created it, and most importantly shared it. How can we bash someone for going out on a limb to share the story she imagined in her head? I don't think you have to love it, because a lot of people won't-that's just opinion, but I think this work should be appreciated and is definitely worth the read.    So once again I'd like to say kudos to Stephanie Meyer for going against the grain of reality and sharing her captivating story with a very-hard-to-please audience.
