031606792X|1.0|I waited for this book, because I wanted Meyer to show her stuff. Now I question her priorities. For her, apparently, the lack of alcohol and drugs and overt sex in the series makes it appropriate for the young adults who will be reading them. I would rather have had Bella smoke, get drunk, and have wild sex with Edward if that meant that Meyer could deepen Bella's character and complicate her decision to give up humanity. Instead, Meyer negates all complications and depth. Bella is perfect, and has been all along. She does not suffer for giving up humanity; instead, she makes the perfect vampire the very day she is created. Humans are so vapid in this novel that a human being gives up nothing for choosing to end her humanity. Vampires are the \\"clique\\" many hoped to belong to in Middle School, and they barely tolerate the presence of humans in their lives. Bella's earlier lack of communication and compassion for her human friends now makes complete sense. She's made it to the better clique; she did, the day she started school. The human friends have not. They can not, as they are inferior.     Compare this to the Harry Potter series, where \\"muggle\\" and \\"mudblood\\" applied to human beings were treated as racist, vicious terms. Where Rowling stressed that those who looked down on humans as inferior beings were wrong. Where Rowling encouraged us to judge others not by their overt powers, but by their inner strength and decency. Where no character was perfect, where everyone had to experience temptation and learn something about their imperfection and the consequences of their choices, even Dumbledore. Where Rowling repeatedly stressed love over power and beauty.     The more I write, the more angry I get at Meyer. I bought this for my daughter, and now I am furious that I did. I have no doubt that she will not \\"change\\" as a result of a novel that has less depth than the average Harlequin romance. I am annoyed as all hell that I had to accompany her to the midnight party, and spend the money on this piece of crap. I am disgusted that a capable author, and Meyer is capable, took a series with great potential, and tossed it in the garbage as she did.

031606792X|2.0|I will start by saying I am a HUGE Stephenie Meyer fan and have been since day one of Twilight.  The first three books managed to take readers to a whole new level of the vampire love genre and twisted them into a realistic point of view.  But unfortunately the final installment, I felt, fell short of the previous books.    *spoilers*    Instead of getting to read the grand finale of this epic vampire romance I felt more like I was \\"watching\\" an episode from Charmed or Buffy the Vampire Slayer.  I'm not saying the shows are horrible (for all the fans out there), I only feel that they lack in realism (yes, I know...they're not meant to be real but still...).  I mean, pregnancy?  Where did that come from?  I understand Meyer probably wanted to throw in a major twist but I really don't think that was the right way to go about it.  Others have pointed out, and I will agree with them, that some subtle messages in this book simply aren't right for the younger generations.  It really makes me wonder what the author was thinking tying up this beautiful story so sloppily.  I had thought she, and anyone else really, could stand more firmly on morals considering the first three books argued strong points such as the existence of souls and what is right and wrong.  Obviously having a child at the age of 18 is wrong (again, not trying to ruffle feathers here by rubbing people the wrong way-this is only my opinion).  I don't care how in love you are.  Bella's original \\"Don't want marriage.  Don't want kids.  Only want Edward for all eternity...\\" flipped you around in a 180 when all of a sudden-viola!  She was pregnant.  Well, darn that changes things...now Bella HAD to want this child unconditionally and didn't feel put out in the slightest!  What happened to Bella's thick headed personality?  I think the only one who \\"acted\\" accordingly to the situation was Edward himself.  And it seemed to me that Edwards \\"I have no soul\\" argument went flying out the window as it hardly even appeared in this book.  Wasn't that part of what made the others books stand out?    And Jacob.  While I LOVED that for a good portion of the book we got to listen to his thoughts, read his reactions first hand, and really get to know him better-imprinting on his first loves daughter is just...need I say it?  I will anyways, weird, wrong, twisted, and just plain weird.  I think the story would've felt more real had everything not been so neatly tied up.  Sure, we all want that happily ever after, who doesn't?  But, the way tensions built up in the third book I was expecting someone to take the blunt of all that was wrong with life and really make you feel for them.  That moment almost came when Bella \\"died\\" and Jacob nearly lost it with Rosalie and \\"Nessie\\" (I won't bash the name...I actually thought it gave this awful twist something humorous).  I honestly wanted Jacob to go out with a bang-or seemingly do so only to return towards the end with news of imprinting on someone else.    Oh, and I must mention all of those \\"see no evil\\" sex scenes.  I thought this was a teen read?  What I mean by that is that even if they weren't descriptively laid out it was horribly obvious that the hormones dominated a large portion of the story this time around.  I'll admit, the honeymoon was expected and even humorous but it was overdone throughout the story.  Sorry to dissapoint anyone but it does get annoying and I don't think there were many readers dying to get into the sex life of Bella and Edward.  Again, this only brings me back to the original problem behind this book-teen pregnancy.    My reasoning behind two stars is that while this book had its flaws it was still a rollercoaster of a read.  And while the idea of Bella being pregnant twisted the original plot oddly out of proportion it still delivered the dramatic \\"Change\\" that everybody was waiting for (though it didn't go as I had expected it to).  For those of you who are unsure as to whether or not to buy the book-I would borrow it from a library first to test the waters.

031606792X|1.0|Considering that Breaking Dawn is the end of the Twilight saga, I knew there would be a Hallmark-style tie up of loose ends. The plot travesty that ensued, however, has left a black spot on the series.     First, let me say, I did enjoy the first 80 or so pages. The wedding was fun to read about, and the honeymoon was just as enjoyable. However, when Bella became pregnant, the story lost its Twilight 'feel' for me.    In the past three books we have explored Bella's choices. Her choice to live in Forks, her choice to date a vampire and her choice to be best friends with a wolf, etc. These choices forced her to struggle with future problems that she may encounter, for instance never being able to see Charlie or Renee after the change.     This book, however, neatly wraps up all of Bella's choices in a nice bow, and seemingly hands her this perfect gift of life.     First, the idea of Bella having a child, when she in many ways is still a child herself, is preposterous. I don't recall in New Moon or Eclipse where Bella says she has to have a child. In some ways, she had a child already: Renee. I thought that part of her choice to become a vampire was that she would be forced to surrender some human moments, and giving birth was one of them.     Also, the idea that Jacob has imprinted on Nessie is insulting. We are expected to believe that the love triangle between Bella, Edward and Jacob, which has been brewing since Twilight, was a triangle only because Bella would be the mother to Jacob's heart-mate. So, we are now forced to believe that when Jacob kissed Bella in Eclipse, he was never in love with her, but instead an unborn egg inside of her. So, Bella never had to make a choice after all? She just needed to get knocked up with Edward's child.     Lastly, the Volturi conflict was ineffective. Since New Moon we have been led to believe the Volturi's would come after Bella, and that Aro wanted Bella, Alice and Edward at his side. In fact, with the conclusion of the Victoria's newborn army, it seemed that Breaking Dawn would be the Volturi's vs. the Cullen's. Although this is briefly described in a conversation, it never comes to a resolution. In fact, when the Volturi left, I felt that they would be on their way back to Forks in the next century for a show down.      Other concerns I have are the following:  1.) How did the good doctor, Carlisle, not figure out that Bella needed to drink blood while Nessie was still in the womb? He knew that Nessie was part vampire, because of the ultrasound not registering, how did he miss the blood nutrition?  2.) Rosalie and Bella become good friends, but is this a lasting friendship? To me, the friendship was a friendship of convenience and nothing more. Rosalie didn't change, nor did Bella.   3.) Bella lacked newborn thirst. This seemed to cheat the vampire system of overcoming the 'vegetarian' adversity.   4.) I'm an English teacher, so I'll be picky, but there were many grammar and spelling errors in the book. I can't blame Stephenie Meyer, because as a writer you're often too familiar with your writing and miss the errors, but I do chide her editors and the publisher for not double checking.      Maybe my expectations were too high for this novel, but I'm very disappointed with the outcome.
006054094X|5.0|I've been interested in different aspects of history for quite some time but the book, \\"1421: The Year China Discovered America\\" is the first to really light up my imagination!  Gavin Menzies' writing style is almost conversational making it an easy read but he has included enough references and quotes to thoroughly prove his premise that the Chinese discovered and mapped the world long before the European explorers \\"discovered\\" anything. I recommend 1421 to even the most casual history buffs as I believe his view of world exploration explains many of the questions that have been raised over the years.

031606792X|1.0|I would give this book 0 out of 5 stars if I could.    This is, without a doubt the worst book I have ever read. There was no plot, one-dimension characters, a build to a climax with no resolution, and poor writing in general.    First of all, this is not a children's book, and days after it's release I still see it in the children's section. This book is very graphic, and raises too many moral issues without any resolution or explanation. I would never recommend this book to anyone under the age of 14.    The first couple of chapters are good, but then it goes from bad to worse. Tension is built, problems arise but none are ever satisfied with a resolution. SM consistently takes the easy way out and creates \\"magical\\" solutions to every problem that arises. This continues to the climax of the book, where the Vulturi decide they were simply wrong and just leave.    The characters are almost new people, unrecognizable from the previous three books. This is not \\"growth\\" for growth implies a long and gradual process. This is more that the characters woke up and become completely new people without any explanation whatsoever. These new characters have no depth and consistently make questionable moral decisions without explanation.    The writing quality itself is unacceptable. Had this been turned in as an assignment in any creative writing class in the world, it would of received a failing grade. There is no structure, and I would consider it at a below high school writing level.    This book should have never been printed in the first place. It is a bad example of American literature and an offense to the written word. I am personally offended that I was sold this book that was supposed to be a quality ending to the Twilight Series. For those who have bought the book, return it; its the only message that can be clearly sent to SM, since now questions are being screen and approved during her book tour.     This book is beyond horrible, and I would not wish anyone, not even my worse enemy, the pain of having to read this disgusting excuse for a novel.

031606792X|5.0|Just as many who have written before me, I deliciously enjoyed the final book to the Twilight saga.  As greatly anticipated, I was not let down by the wedding or honeymoon in the beginning of the book, nor the unexpected portions to follow.      I was slightly taken aback by some of the more adult themes of the book particularly Bella's pregnancy.  However, I do feel everything in the book was very fitting for the next step in the character's lives.    *During one interview, Stephanie Meyer did in fact state that she thought an age advisory should be placed on the books, and after reading them, I think that the publisher's should have taken that suggestion.       Many other reviews have dinged Meyer for the characters changing to much and the relationship between Bella and Edward changing.  However, I believe that is a true tribute to the characters and the relationships they each represent. As we all go through major life events we are going to change and evolve, so why wouldn't these characters? As a newlywed in my mid twenties, I could relate to a lot of these changes.  Additionally as someone who has debated whether or not to have children, this book has placed a new perspective on life and family.  Therefore, I am happy that Stephanie Meyer included all of these unexpected life events and plot twists.      If I were to give one criticism it would be that the story conclusion was rather \\"neat\\".  I agree that I wanted all of the loose ends to be tied, including Jacob imprinting on someone. However, I was disappointed that there was not more life loss, that the overall sacrifice was not greater.     With all of these thoughts in mind, I was very please with the storyline conclusions, the way the book was broken up by perspectives, and the overall writing.
031606792X|1.0|When I started reading the Twilight series I realized it wasn't the best written, tight bit of literature ever.  But the first book was a guilty pleasure, so I kept going with the next two.  I enjoyed New Moon far more than Eclipse and was ready to throw in the towel, except the wait was going to be short for the fourth so I stayed on.    I wish I could take it all back.  The books have always read like a 14 year old girl just discovered her first enthralling encounter with a fictional relationship and decided to write a fan fiction based on it, but this time it was ten thousand times worse.  It felt so much like one of those movie series where the first one was well-received, then all the original cast and crew decided to move on but some stupid movie exec decided to squeeze a couple sequels out of it and RUIN the whole idea.    Some pre-teens and young teenagers will probably love this book, and people who choose to live in a fairy-tale world in their heads.  But this book can't possibly pass muster with anyone who has half a mind to notice the terribly OOC characters, the shoddy writing, the extremely unrealistic situations (Yes!  Even for a book about sparkly vampires!), the entire destruction of characters so many people have grown to love.    Sometimes ideas that come to you in dreams should stay that way, a dream.

1401216676|5.0|Great insight into why the Joker may be who is is, very easy read should take about an hour.
0739367676|2.0|CAUTION: REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS            I haven't been able to make myself finish the book - so maybe in the last quarter, maybe(and hopefully) it pulls itself out of mediocrity. Other reviewers have gone into more detail about why the final volume of a nearly-great series is such a let-down. But I'll tell you why it breaks my own heart. One of the primary weaknesses I felt through all the books is the way Bella's other family members are so uni-dimensional and unimportant. Her mom and dad are both from Forks, so why don't they have any family friends, aunts, uncles or grandparents? And Bella's Dad is so conveniently stupid and obsessed with sports & fishing, so he can be tangential to the story. And although Bella moved to Forks as a gesture of love and sacrifice to her Mom, she is not very close to her, and she plays a very thin role in the first three books. In Breaking Dawn, Bella's family are completely negligible, to the point that it sort of makes me sick. Who cares that there are people who are out of their minds with worry about Bella? The author does not treat real human beings with any sympathy. Yuck.     The addition of an infant into the family... it creeped me out more than a little bit. But I object to this plot twist mostly because of the inescapable truth: after marriage and children, total boredom ensues. I haven't been able to finish the book mostly because it's so incredibly boring. Jacob imprinting on Bella's child... the only adjective I can come up with is: ikky. The child's human/vamp hybridization, and her speed-growth and special skills: ikky. And her dietary habits: beyond ikky, into the land of gag.       Ms. Meyer, could you please re-write Breaking Dawn from the beginning? I would very much appreciate it, and I would buy it again, with my fingers crossed that the second try would be better.

0141439475|5.0|Did the people who made the Frankenstein movie even read this book? All of the things that I associated with Frankenstein are creations of the movie alone. No Igor, no lightning striking the body, no grave-robbing (not directly referred to anyway), no mountain laboratory, no villagers attacking the castle to burn it to the ground. Just a young college student seized with a fever to see what he is capable of creating. What he creates is a monster so terrible to look upon, that he is disgusted and horrified and flees from it. The creature is not yet a monster and only wants to be loved and cared for by its creator. But as it is attacked and maligned purely on the basis of its horrific appearance, it becomes a monster and strikes out to destroy everything its creator loves. It's a real tragedy told almost entirely as a narrative without action. It was a tough read in spots, but well worth it. I'm a big classic horror movie fan, but after reading this and Dracula, I'm a bit appalled at how far they strayed from the original.

031606792X|1.0|I've never been a huge fan of Meyer's writing, and that's probably putting it mildly, but at least the first three books in the series had a point. For Bella and Edward, it's been about the sacrifices you make for true love. In Eclipse, there was so much drama and indecision and we were left with the impression that Bella had made the ultimate sacrifice for love.    In Breaking Dawn, Meyer takes a total cop-out and cheapens the love story and what it ostensibly meant. In the end, Bella gives up nothing. She gets everything she ever wanted and more, she is not forced to choose between her human family and her (unrealistically perfect) vampiric life, or even between her love for Edward and her more platonic love for Jacob. She doesn't even have any of the challenges that newborn vampires usually face. I mean, we can go on about how Bella is a Mary Sue of the worst kind, but that has been true throughout the series. The biggest problem with BD on its own is that Meyer doesn't follow any of the conventions that she herself set up with the first three books. Nothing comes together and nothing makes sense.    Yes, it's a happy ending, but it's an impossible one, an overly-perfect one. Nothing is lost, there is no suffering -- it's just easy and cheap. And that's just plain lazy storytelling.

031606792X|4.0|I entirely enjoyed reading the \\"Twilight\\" saga: the first two books held my attention and were hard to put down.  I must admit that I thought \\"Eclipse\\" was the last book in the series, until I wrote my review and discovered that a fourth was on the way.  I agree with some other reviewers that the saga would've been stronger if \\"Eclipse\\" had been the end.  All said and done, I did enjoy the entire series, but wish Meyer could've reached a compromise somewhere between the third book and this latest installment.<br /><br />What Stephenie Meyer has accomplished with the \\"Twilight\\" saga is fascinating: she's written immensely long books that take no time to read and breathed some life into vampire legends.  Yet with \\"Breaking Dawn\\" she seems to be fulfilling more her own gratification than that of her readers.  When left at the end of \\"Eclipse\\", Bella and Edward had reached a tenuous decision: he would make her a vampire, after they were married and she had gone to college.  Bella had finally seemed to have chosen Edward over Jacob, and Jacob had taken off, presumably out of the picture.<br /><br />\\"Breaking Dawn\\" picks up the story right where it left off, with Bella and Edward getting married and in store for an interesting honeymoon to say the least.  The story shortly diverts to Jacob's point-of-view, offering readers some interesting insights into his thoughts and feelings, allowing readers to see the action from an entirely different angle, perhaps offered as a bone for those who prefer Jacob Black.  The story reverts back to Bella as narrator, after she has been changed and is exploring her newfound strengths. Yet even with the strange twists Meyer throws in, the plot seems formulaic - a danger they must face in a large-scale showdown - is cleverly resolved, but rather drawn out.<br /><br />I must admit that I wasn't expecting too much from \\"Breaking Dawn\\".  While it was just as readable and enjoyable as the previous three, I knew events would unfold whether I wished them to or not.  Having Bella get everything she wants resolves all of the tension and contradiction the previous three examined so successfully.  There are almost too many happy endings here to seem realistic, even for a book based on supernatural beings.  Stephenie Meyer is a gifted storyteller, and I read a quote from her that the books have gone on so long because she had a hard time giving up Bella's humanity.  I wish she would've struggled a little more with that issue.  Readers, especially younger ones, should know that \\"Breaking Dawn\\" is a much more grown-up book than even the previous three have been: hopefully there's some discretion as to who is reading this.  While Meyer is never explicit, there are certainly some scenes that ought to raise eyebrows, since this is considered a young adult book.aving Bella get everything she wants resolves all of the tension and contradiction the previous three examined so successfully.  There are almost too many happy endings here to seem realistic, even for a book based on supernatural beings. I wish she would've struggled a little more with that issue.  Readers, especially younger ones, should know that \\"Breaking Dawn\\" is a much more grown-up book than even the previous three have been: hopefully there's some discretion as to who is reading this.  While Meyer is never explicit, there are certainly some scenes that ought to raise eyebrows, since this is considered a young adult book.

031606792X|5.0|I finished the novel in twelve hours, and I must say that I was surprised by much in it.  I have also read some of the reviews, and I tried to think it over looking at the story from the one-star perspective.  I must say that I can't see their point.  Firstly, the message I got was not that it was okay to have lots of sex and a baby and that makes a good life.  I think the moral was get married and then sex becomes better, along with if you make a child, you have to deal with the consequences of having done so.  The trouble with the youth of today is that they have sex without much of a commitment to their partner, and then, they have a child without entirely accepting the changes that come with it.  My mother was eighteen when she married, and she had me when she was still quite young by today's standards.  She told me how her view of the world and her purpose in it changed with a child; she became a different kind of person, and that is how I saw the change in Bella as a natural effect of having another life depend on her.  Bella had always been protective of the ones she was with and most especially towards those she loved.  Remember the third wife in Eclipse, and how that story effected Bella?  Yea, she had some very immature moments, but we all do, really.  Yea, the Jacob thing was kind of a shock, but to me it fit somehow.  (Remember Emily, Sam and Leah?)  To me, Bella was never just defined by Edward any more than he was defined by her, and this was no exception.  Her life was complete with him and Nessie in it, but that was not going to be her entire life.  It is too early in it to say what she is going to do with all of her time anyway, and it never says that she isn't going to college so who knows?  Anyway, I always thought that there was more to the supernatural world than Bella understood or know about, and I was right.  There is so much to explore in this world that I doubt that this is the end of the Twilight books really.  Maybe of Bella and Edward'smain story, but there are other characters like Nahuel that I am really curious about.  Given time, I am sure we will meet up with the characters we have come to love and the ones we have only just met again.

075640407X|4.0|I was surprised to find that, instead of the epic fantasy of myriad plots and characters that the first chapter or so led me to think I was getting, what I had was essentially a biography! For a simple storyline, yes, it could probably be done faster. But here's what surprised me - though the book was long, the plot occasionally slow and redundant - I was never. ever. bored.  Not for one page.  Rothfuss' writing is such that even a slow part feels more like it's been \\"lovingly detailed\\" than \\"badly done.\\"  I found Kvothe to be a very compelling character - his naivete and his cleverness combine believably. B0015DYIH2|4.0|My daughter nagged relentlessly until I agreed to read the Twilight series, just to get her to be quiet. I enjoyed the books more than I expected I would, though I never fell into the madness of Twihardism.<br /><br />Breaking Dawn provides an obvious conclusion to the Twilight saga, following the logical progression of a modern fairy tale: Bella ends up with everything she wanted and some things she never knew she wanted.  This seems to bother the die-hard fans, but think for a moment about the contemporary Cinderella story:<br /><br />(1) Girl meets hardship (or makes a self-sacrificing choice)<br />(2) Girl meets metaphorical knight in shining armor<br />(3) Knight saves girl from physical harm (repeat as necessary)<br />(4) Girl saves knight emotionally<br />(6) Comeuppance for evildoers<br />(7) Happy endings for everyone else<br /><br />The happy ending is a foregone conclusion. The journey getting there is what makes the story interesting and Breaking Dawn doesn't disappoint on that level.<br /><br />There's been a great deal of complaining about the message of the story, which causes me to wonder if perhaps some people have difficulty distinguishing fantasy from reality. Though it is quite possible to tell a morality tale though fantasy, the genre is best suited for exploring things we would never wish to experience in real life. The characters aren't portraying an ideal lifestyle for readers to emulate; they're just doing things to move the plot forward. It's unfair to assume that the characters' opinions and actions have any meaning outside of the pages of the story.  The message of the story is simply that it's entertaining to vicariously experience imaginary characters doing things that are radically different than your real life.<br /><br />For those who insist on a deeper message to live by, I suggest that you preface the thought with, \\"When a trustworthy clairvoyant guides you and your love interest is vampire 86 years your senior, it's perfectly acceptable to...\\"

This lack of information is obviously a contrived oversight. Bella was obviously not ready to have a child because she mentions to Edward that she wants to attend college. Meyers never discusses Bella's disappointment in not  attending Dartmouth, in lacking those life experiences and loosing out on further intellectual and developmental growth. 0691131511|4.0|Because the Byzantine Empire lasted 1,129 years (from Constantine's founding of Constantinople in 324 AD to Sultan Mehmet II's capture of the city in 1453), the historian writing about the empire faces a daunting task. Write about it in the traditional chronological manner, and space limitations will force a laundry list approach with little meaningful content.<br /><br />What Judith Herrin (a professor of Late Antique and Byzantine Studies at King's College, London) has elected to do instead is to break the subject down into 28 topics under 4 general subject headings and then deal with each topic chronologically:<br /><br />I. FOUNDATIONS OF BYZANTIUM<br />  1. The  City of Constantine<br />  2. Constantinople, the Largest City in Christendom<br />  3. The East Roman Empire<br />  4. Greek Orthodoxy<br />  5. The Church of Hagia Sophia<br />  6. The Ravenna Mosaics<br />  7. Roman Law<br /><br />II. THE TRANSITION FROM ANCIENT TO MEDIEVAL<br />  8. The Bulwark Against Islam<br />  9. Icons, a New Christian Art Form<br /> 10. Iconclasm and Icon Veneration<br /> 11. A Literate and Articulate Society<br /> 12. Saints Cyril and Methodios, `Apostles to the Slavs'<br /><br />III BYZANTIUM BECOMES A MEDIEVAL STATE<br /> 13. Greek Fire<br /> 14. The Byzantine Economy<br /> 15. Eunuchs<br /> 16. The Imperial Court<br /> 17. Imperial Children, `Born in the Purple'<br /> 18. Mount Athos<br /> 19. Venice and the Fork<br /> 20. Basil II, `The Bulgar-Slayer'<br /> 21. Eleventh Century Crisis<br /> 22. Anna Komene<br /> 23. A Cosmopolitan Society<br /><br />IV VARIETIES OF BYZANTIUM<br /> 24. The Fulcrum of the Crusades<br /> 25. The Towers of Trebizond, Arta, Nicaea and Thessalonike<br /> 26. Rebels and Patrons<br /> 27. `Better the Turkish Turban than the Papal Tiara'<br /> 28. The Siege of 1453<br />  Conclusion: The Greatness and Legacy of Byzantium<br /><br />The core of the book consists of 333 pages, which means that each topic is limited to an average of 12 pages. As a result, the writing is information-dense, slowing the reader's progress. Additionally, the author's writing style is academic (i.e., somewhat tedious), although the shortness of the chapters makes reading the book manageable.<br /><br />There are 41 photographs of varying quality, many in black and white. They appear to have been chosen haphazardly. NOTE: A good source of high quality reproductions of Eastern Orthodox religious icons is [[ASIN:089236856X Holy Image, Hallowed Ground (Getty Trust Publications: J. Paul Getty Museum)]].<br /><br />As the above discussion suggests, this is a book that will primarily interest an academic reader. Those interested in a more comfortable approach may wish to consider Kenneth Harl's excellent course for the Teaching Company<br />[[ASIN:B001CGVW44 Great Courses World of Byzantium Parts 1 and 2 (365 and 366) (Teaching Company)]]<br /><br />UPDATE [04-06-2011]: Ms. Herrin wrote an essay, \\"The Glories of Byzantium,\\" which appeared in the Saturday/Sunday March 12-13, 2011 edition of the Wall Street Journal, in which she recommended some recent books on Byzantium:<br /><br />1. Re the military reasons for Byzantium's long survival, [[ASIN:185728495X Warfare, State And Society In The Byzantine World 565-1204 (Warfare and History)]]<br /><br />2. Same, [[ASIN:0674035194 The Grand Strategy of the Byzantine Empire]]<br /><br />3. Re Byzantium's historical significance, [[ASIN:0333989759 Empires and Barbarians]] and [[ASIN:1596913932 After Tamerlane: The Global History of Empire Since 1405]]<br /><br />4. Re the end of the Empire: [[ASIN:0300117868 The End of Byzantium]]<br /><br />She pays the traditional academic obeisance to Sir Steven Runciman's books, describing them as \\"well-researched and elegantly phrased books.\\" Well researched, definitely. But elegantly phrased? I think not; they suffer from the same stylistic problems that plague the work of Ms. Herrin and other academics.<br /><br />Somewhat surprisingly, or perhaps not so since he is a competitor, she fails to mention John Julius Norwich's eminently readable three volume history [[ASIN:0394537785 Byzantium: The Early Centuries]], [[ASIN:0394537793 Byzantium (II): The Apogee]], and [[ASIN:0679416501 Byzantium: The Decline and Fall]]. For those not up to that amount of reading, there is a shorter version \\"A Short History of Byzantium.\\" Both the research and the writing are superb.<br /><br />An upscale cruise line, Voyages to Antiquity, retained Norwich to provide historical background for its catalogs and to lead a trip or two a year. The catalogs are masterpieces in and of themselves.um: The Decline and Fall]]. For those not up to that amount of reading, there is a shorter version \\"A Short History of Byzantium.\\" Both the research and the writing are superb.    An upscale cruise line, Voyages to Antiquity, retained Norwich to provide historical background for its catalogs and to lead a trip or two a year. The catalogs are masterpieces in and of themselves.

I was ecstatic last week knowing that the time was almost up and I would be able to read Breaking Dawn.  I went to the midnight release party - which I've NEVER done before in my life, I'm almost 29 years old.  My 43 year old sister went with me and she was just as excited.  I was home by 12:30am and stayed up until 8:00 am reading on Saturday, until my eyes were crossing and I had to sleep, but the minute I woke at 12:30pm I began reading again.  I was finished by 3:00pm on Saturday.  At first I didn't know how to feel, it was such a STRETCH for me, the direction the book went in - and it didn't have the heart of the previous books, where was the passion and love and intensity between Bella and Edward that was demonstrated so beautifully in the other books, I was sorely disappointed in that they seemed like shadows of themselves.  Edward wasn't Edward, he seemed like a bit player in this story ... as was Bella, all weekend I continued to describe them as \\"Bella & Edward Lite\\" or \\"Diet Bella and Edward\\" ... and the baby ... WTF?!  I keep seeing images in my head of the scene in Spaceballs or Alien when the little monster comes out of the guy's stomach.  Overall, I'm just sad and disappointed.  I know that this must hurt Stephenie Meyer to see her fans so upset by this book, but unfortunately, it is what it is.  It could have been so wonderful, but it seemed rushed and without the depth of feeling of the previous books.  It speaks volumes to me that so many people are returning their copies and are so upset.  So far, the book is scoring 3 stars on Amazon when LITERALLY - every one of her other books are 4.5 stars - that says something right there.  Anyway, just wanted to add my two cents.  I still love Stephenie and what she has done for bringing a little more romance and love back into literature, but this book should be put in the furthest corner of the bookshelf and allowed to gather dust.  I certainly won't be reading it again as I have the others - and it's just a shame.

B0000YB7Z8|5.0|English prog rockers Jethro Tull's double live album Bursting Out was released in September of 1978.<br />The Bursting Out album was recorded on the band's 1978 European tour in support of their excellent but underrated album Heavy Horses. This album captures the lineup of lead singer/songwriter and flute player Ian Anderson, guitarist Martin Barre, keyboard player John Evan, drummer Barriemore Barlow, orchestrator/keyboard player David Palmer (now known as Dee Palmer) and bass player the late John Glascock at the top of their game.<br />We begin with Introduction By Claude Nobs who was one of the top music promoters in Europe. We follow with a stellar intro which gives way to a rocking version of the Heavy Horses album track \\"No Lullaby\\" which is a superb version. We follow with \\"Sweet Dream\\" which rocks alot harder than the studio version. We then have an acoustic portion starting with an excellent reading of \\"Skating Away On The Thin Ice\\". Next is an excellent version of \\"Jack In The Green\\" which is always one of my favorite Tull tunes. We then end the acoustic set with another track from the Heavy Horses effort being \\"One Brown Mouse\\".<br />The second side of the album start with an excellent version of \\"A New Day Yesterday\\" which has a harder edge than the studio version. Next we get to hear Ian's impressive flute playing on \\"Flute Solo/God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen/Bouree\\" and proves why he is rock's greatest flute player. We then have a short but powerful version of \\"Songs From The Wood\\". We end the first disc of this stellar two disc album with an excellent but condensed version of \\"Thick As A Brick\\". This version rivals the live version from Madison Square Garden found on the TaaB remastered CD from 1998.<br />The album's second disc and third side starts with an Introduction By Ian Anderson which then goes into a powerful version of the Songs From the Wood album cut \\"Hunting Girl\\" which is a killer rocker. Next is an excellent version of the title cut to 1976's Too Old To Rock and Roll To Young to Die. Next is the instrumental called \\"Conundrum\\" which is the drum solo spot from virtuoso drummer Barlow proving why Barriemore is an excellent drummer and Martin Barre's riff here showed why he is a great, yet underrated, guitarist. The title cut to 1975's Minstrel In The Gallery is next and is a great version.<br />The album's last quarter begins with an excellent and heavy version of \\"Cross Eyed Mary\\". Next is another exclusive instrumental \\"Quatrain\\" which is driven by a killer riff by Barre. We then follow with a killer version of the title track to 1971's Aqualung and is the best version I ever heard though the version from the 1981 video Slipstream (which is a bonus DVD on the remastered re-issue of 1980's A album/CD). Next is a great version of another classic \\"Locomotive Breath\\" which just rocks. We end with \\"The Dambusters March\\" which gives way into an instrumental which rocks and a reprise of Aqualung to end the album.<br />Bursting Out upon release reached the US Top 20 and went Gold immediately and rightfully so as this live album just kicks arse beginning to end.<br />The original US 1990s CD release wrongfully and inexplicably deleted Sweet Dream, Conundrum and Quatrain and much of the stage bantering to fit the album on one CD but this remastered 2-CD set released in 2004 restores the full album to its full length and how one first heard it when they either owned the LP or cassette or 8-track cartridge issue. If you want one live Tull album in your collection, Bursting Out is where to go for the best live Tull performance available.<br />HUGELY RECOMMENDED!To Rock and Roll To Young to Die. Next is the instrumental called \\"Conundrum\\" which is the drum solo spot from virtuoso drummer Barlow proving why Barriemore is an excellent drummer and Martin Barre's riff here showed why he is a great, yet underrated, guitarist. The title cut to 1975's Minstrel In The Gallery is next and is a great version.   The album's last quarter begins with an excellent and heavy version of \\"Cross Eyed Mary\\". Next is another exclusive instrumental \\"Quatrain\\" which is driven by a killer riff by Barre. We then follow with a killer version of the title track to 1971's Aqualung and is the best version I ever heard though the version from the 1981 video Slipstream (which is a bonus DVD on the remastered re-issue of 1980's A album/CD). Next is a great version of another classic \\"Locomotive Breath\\" which just rocks. We end with \\"The Dambusters March\\" which gives way into an instrumental which rocks and a reprise of Aqualung to end the album.   Bursting Out upon release reached the US Top 20 and went Gold immediately and rightfully so as this live album just kicks arse beginning to end.   The original US 1990s CD release wrongfully and inexplicably deleted Sweet Dream, Conundrum and Quatrain and much of the stage bantering to fit the album on one CD but this remastered 2-CD set released in 2004 restores the full album to its full length and how one first heard it when they either owned the LP or cassette or 8-track cartridge issue. If you want one live Tull album in your collection, Bursting Out is where to go for the best live Tull performance available.   HUGELY RECOMMENDED!

0143038419|4.0|This is a self-autobiography about the author's dissatisfaction with life, which leads to her divorce and one-year travels in the countries of Italy (eat), India (pray), and Indonesia (love).  She laughs, she cries, and she learns.  She makes fun of herself.  She isn't perfect, and perhaps that is what draws the reader in.  The writing in the book is fun and witty and I enjoyed her cunning quips..it can get a little much at times, however, as I feel she overuses her puns and metaphors.  Also, some of her situations and occurances in these countries seem a little \\"too perfect,\\" meaning the stories make great additions to the book, and I was left wondering if the stories were \\"glamorized\\" to make them more interesting for the book.  The people that rated this book low didn't like that the author cried to much, talked about herself to much, was too-self absorbed to see the poverty around her etc.  What these people fail to realize is that the book is NOT about noticing/commenting about third world conditions.  The author is trying to experience self-spritual, emotional and mental renewal during her trip.  The book is an autobiography of her life in these other countries and her SELF JOURNEY!  If you want a political or social commentary about these countries don't read this book.  If you want to read about a fun, (and at times) emotionally unstable woman, who is trying to heal herself and talk to God in the best way she knows how; by going other countries and experiencing life, read this book.  Don't judge or demean the way she is doing it...just enjoy the entertaining ride.

B0015D3Z4O|4.0|\\"Hard Candy\\" comes alive more and more with each listen.  There are so many different sounds on so many of the songs, I can't help but be more and more intrigued each time I hear them.    Despite featuring routine Neptunes' production and clichd lyrics comparing candy to dancing/sex, \\"Candy Shop\\" is a solid, sparse dance tune; \\"4 Minutes\\" also pulls through in the end thanks to its horn sections, though it too features a setback: at times, Justin Timberlake and Timbaland's busy production practically take over the song from Madonna.    Things really start getting interesting at track 3.  \\"Give It 2 Me\\" is a fantastic celebration of not only dance music, but the Queen of Dance Music as well.  The Neptunes' production builds gloriously throughout, and Madge is more than capably along for the ride.  The same can be said for the next song, \\"Heartbeat.\\"  This song stands out as one of the best on the album; you can practically feel your heart banging along with the Madonna's.  It's another wonderful celebration of a night out at the club.    \\"Miles Away\\" is the best Timbaland/Timberlake production here.  There is such longing in the soundscapes, in Madonna's voice, in lines such as \\"You always love me more, miles away.\\"  This is another standout and one of the more emotional songs on the album.    The same degree of emotion is found in the next two tracks, \\"She's Not Me\\" and \\"Incredible.\\"  The former hits its peak at the end of the song, with a hyper, throbbing beat and Madonna's warped, resounding vocals.  The latter hits its stride at the beginning, with its lighthearted production and bittersweet vocals.  These are challenging tracks for their whole durations, though, with the entire musical direction of the songs changing throughout them.    \\"Beat Goes On\\" and \\"Dance 2Nite\\" are both incredibly fun and retro odes to the freedom found on the dance floor.  \\"Beat\\" features a pretty good rap from Kanye West, and on \\"Dance,\\" Madonna and Justin vocally meet in the middlein a much more satisfying way then they do on \\"4 Minutes.\\"  By hiring the new kings of hip-hop and pop, respectively, it's obvious Madge still has her killer pop instincts intact.    The album's low point is the dull \\"Spanish Lesson.\\"  It's a nice idea in theory to have a Latino-flavored song on one's album, but Pharrell and Madonna don't pull it off in reality.  Its lyrics are pretty much nothing more than a literal Spanish lesson (like, \\"I say something lusty in Spanish,\\" \\"Now I'll translate it for you in English\\").  The best part of the song is the elastic rhythms at the end, and it's telling that there are no lyrics to be found here.    \\"Devil Wouldn't Recognize You,\\" is moody and clever.  However, it shows obvious influences from Timberlake's/Timbaland's \\"Cry Me a River\\" and \\"What Goes Around...Comes Around.\\"  It's a good song, but originality is lost.    The final track here is \\"Voices.\\"  It is probably the most philosophical song here and would not totally be out of place on her deeper albums like \\"Ray of Light\\" or \\"American Life.\\"  Its tune swirls around you like voices beckoning from all sides, and it includes the provoking question \\"Who is the master, who is the slave?\\"  Madonna's answer to that is found on \\"Hard Candy.\\"  She is a master of dance music, but she is not beneath making herself a slave to it either if her art is made better for it.  Throughout her career, that philosophy has paid of in spades, and \\"Hard Candy\\" is no different.  The beats didn't hit me in the gut as immediately as they did on \\"Confessions on the Dance Floor,\\" and the lyrics didn't hit me in the heart like those on \\"Ray of Light\\" did.  But there are still great rewards to be found here for the patient listener who can give an album, no, a work of art, time to kick off its shoes and groove for them.

031606792X|5.0|I began reading this book with great anticipation, waiting anxiously to see if Bella would marry Edward, turn into a vampire, and live happily ever after. For that reason, I was satisfied before even getting half way through the book - Stephenie could have stopped there and I would have been happy! But as I continued to read, wondering what else could she possibly put in this book to make it the perfect ending, the more I was drawn back into the book. It was a perfect mixture of love, romance, sacrafice, pain, manipulation, and anything else you could have wanted. I found myself crying and laughing with the characters, and to be honest, even envying them at times. Life seems boring compared to the lives of the Cullen family!    Sure its unrealistic, but I knew that when I read the first book and its probably what attracted me most to the series. I would have done the same, and besides, who can resist a happy ending where everyone is truly happy? My only complaint with Breaking Dawn and the entire series is that it is over. I'm not sure I'll ever find a book or series that I enjoy reading more than the Twilight Series, and in my opinion, Breaking Dawn was a perfect way to end the series.

True feminism is about choice. Bella knows what she wants and she has weighed the consequences. Yes through out the book she has been physically weak (human) mentally and emotionally she's shown more maturity and strength than most heroines.     2) Yes she's pregnant, and heaven forbid she's happy about it? Everyone reacts differently. And by no means does this glorify pregnancy. She spends over a hundred pages near death, with several broken bones and bruises. I'm sorry but that certainly doesn't make me eager for my own bundle of joy.     3) The fact that Jacob imprints on Bella's daughter actually made a lot of sense to me. She was the last part of Bella's humanity left. If he had imprinted on some other girl it would have made it cheap somehow I think.  And Stephenie practically spells it out for us, if nothing supernatural existed, if there were no Edward Bella and Jacob would have been perfect for each other. The part of her that was in love with Jacob lives on in her daughter. Which makes things right in a way I never pictured.     all in all I thought it was phenomenal. it left me dazzled. ^_^

B0017R5UAA|5.0|I would probably liken this wonderful debut by Fleet Foxes to Midlake with greater instrumental skills, a better engineering mix and strength in depth, but then most of you probably have not heard of Midlake either (if you like this album, check them out on [[ASIN:B000FVQYJK The Trials of Van Occupanther]]). So perhaps I have to fall back to a mix between  Simon and Garfunkel for the pristine singing, the Byrds and early Jethro Tull for the musicality and the breadth of instrumentation.     Whatever you do, do not expect this album to rock. It is a mix of subtle melodic ballads, such as the lead-off Sun It Rises and the folksy Tiger Mountain Peasant Song and faster more orchestrated songs such as Ragged Wood. It will be interesting whether on their next offering after this impressive debut, the group speeds up or remains etherally slow.

031606792X|4.0|This book was SO much better than I would have expected if I had read the negative reviews before the book.    First of all, this story belongs to Stephanie Meyer's imagination and not that of the readers!  It is truly amazing to see how many fans believe that they know better than the author what should have happened to these characters.  It is clear that so many of the readers became emotionally involved with the characters, and, while some of these fans were disappointed with the direction that this book took, it is presumptuous of them to assume that they know better than the author how this book should have been written.  It is her story to tell, not yours!    Secondly, for all of you who now believe that the story should have ended before or when Bella became a vampire, you would have been much more let down if that were the case.  While there was something disappointing in how quickly Bella adjusted to becoming a vampire, it is clear that the author either had to do this to move the story forward, or else she would have had to have broken the story into two books to give Bella (and the readers) time to adjust.    So many of the readers love Bella  BECAUSE they can relate to her being so normal.  However, everyone had to realize that when she became a vampire all of her awkwardness would disappear and she would become model beautiful.  Without a doubt, many readers wished this for her but were not ready to embrace the new, perfect Bella because she became more difficult to relate to.  In a way the author had written herself into a corner here, because it was impossible to have all of Bella's dreams come true without alienating some of her fans.      Stephanie Meyer wrote the story that SHE believed in, knowing full well that she could not make all of her fans happy.  With that in mind, I think that she stayed true to her own vision and wrote an AMAZING novel.  For all of you who are ripping the author apart online, look at how much joy her books have given youand give \\"Breaking Dawn\\" and Ms. Meyer another chance.  Don't you think she deserves it?

031606792X|5.0|I stumbled upon Twilight a short few years ago. I was struck by the cover. It was bold and simple and I felt that beneath the cover I'd discover an intricate tale. I was intrigued by Meyer's creations. I didn't know what to make of her sparkling vampires or the young boy so seriously crushing on an older girl (the relationship between Jacob and Bella) who was blatantly manipulating him. I was slightly disgusted by Bella. A self-absorbed teen who played into the typical average Jane with a pitiable self-esteem and was incredibly self absorbed but was viewed by all others as \\"special\\" and desirable. Unfortunately, I'd paid a lot for the book so I read it through to the end. Pissed off and appalled by the fact that this book had become a bestseller for young adults, I resolved to disregard any other books written by Stephenie Meyer.<br /><br />Fortunately, in this case at least, I have a very weak resolve so I picked up Eclipse when I should have been studying for an exam. I was pleasantly surprised by Jacob and his indestructible character. He was not ashamed of faults or weaknesses and his love for Bella was bitterly sweet. I still couldn't really stand Bella but Jacob really made me take note of the series. He was shockingly mature in comparison to Edward and Bella who seemed incredibly selfish and incapable of relating to the lives of lowly humans. I really wanted to see what would become of him and hoped that he'd find happiness and peace from the constant struggle his love for Bella placed him in.<br /><br />So it was a big surprise to me that with Breaking Dawn, I actually started to care about what happened to Bella and Edward. There are a lot of twists and turns in this last novel which will probably upset many and intrigue a few. I can't say that I'm ok with everything that happened in this novel as I believe that some parts were way too much for younger readers to handle. But I think it was fantastically put together and the ending was definitely an ending.Not overly sappy and not absolutely depressing (unless the pairing that you wanted didn't happen and you were utterly devastated).<br /><br />There are some themes that are questionable for younger readers depending on how you interpret the material. However, keep in mind that that people have different beliefs about what it means to love and be a family. The concept of choice and lack of choice is brought up on several occasions. As a strong believer in choice, I think that even the instances in which people in the novel seemingly had no choice as to their fate, they truly did. For example, Alice sees possible futures for vampires and humans but not the wolves. It's explained off as the result of the fickle nature of the wolves but are wolves really fickle? They live in controlled packs and the males imprint on their mates to ensure their line.. that doesn't seem very unstructured to me.<br /><br />But whatever. All I wanted to say was that I liked the book. It makes you think, gives a good thrill or two, and it's got a heavy helping of romance. What more could a person want?
031606792X|4.0|For all of the \\"nelly naysayers\\" that thought that this book was a cop-out, unrealisitic, anti-feminist, and providing the wrong message to today's teens, let's all remember that this is FANTASY fiction.    Just like JK Rowling (and I am not making a direct conmparison that SM is the next JK), with the characters developing, changing and getting older, the themes of the novel are more adult than young adult.      We already knew that Bella's path was to marry Edward as of Eclipse, which she did in this book.  THANK GOD. The baby thing - weird, but life throws a curve ball.  She made a choice to keep the baby when her husband wanted to abort it; again, another life choice.  So she gets everything in the end and she does not go to college in this book.  Big deal.  She is immortal and will have plenty of time on her hands to attend Dartmouth.  She and Edward could have deferred admission for a year - we do not know this.    At some point, the story has to end.  I think SM did a great job of sewing up the loose ends and providing a happy ending, which the majority of her fan base was demanding or should I say, hoping for.  I do not see this as a cop-out.  I think SM wove the rest of the story well so we have closure on all of the characters and open storylines, not just Edward and Bella.    If you are looking for SM to provide moral guidance to today's teens, then this is the wrong book for you.  The book is FICTION and not meant to be a guide.  If anything, what SM shows is that Edward and Bella abstained from sex and waited to be married before going all the way.  That should be the most important lesson of all. If you are a Twlight fan, and are interested in seeing how it all ends, then this is for you.      BTW, my fave book out of the four was Eclipse.

031606792X|2.0|This book does not have the same feel as the previous books in the series. SM has taken this above and beyond what the Twilight series should be about. It's too intense and in-your-face in all the WRONG places.    THE PROS:  - I really did appreciate the fact that Bella was finally turned into a vampire. I feel that that was the right decision.  - We really got to see Jacob's point of view. And I thoroughly enjoyed his book. It gave insight into how Jacob's mind works and it made him easier to understand now.    ....but the warm fuzzy feelings stop there.    THE CONS:  - The lack of ever questioning whether or not Edward was able to impregnant Bella to begin with. There was no forewarning about what would happen when the two would have sex. The entire family knew they would, they were getting married...it's a given it would come down to it, so why not do a little research beforehand and find out if it's actually a possibility. And if it is, bring that box of condoms with you on the honeymoon! It's too basic for SM to overlook. She did not address it for a reason.  - She just used Bella getting pregnant and having Nessie as a means to an end. 1) The most obvious reason, for Jacob to imprint on...which is just plain idiotic, since Jacob is to just drop all his hope and feelings for Bella and transfer that onto HER DAUGHTER instead?? Then Bella can be w/ Edward guilt-free and call it a win-win? That's ridiculous and really disturbing. And then 2), the less obvious reason for Nessie to exist in this story..is to create some drama over, be a catalyst to provoke the Volturi into causing havok. Nessie is really just an excuse to get the story moving. But it definitely was unnecessary and moved it into the wrong direction.  - SM has this fascination with impending deaths, someone/something coming after Bella and the Cullens, and constant need for every single character to make a self-sacrifice. Have we not had enough of that same exact bit in the past 3 books? It's been done time and time again, let it rest. It has been so worked over I wonder if that's the only way SM knows how to make a plot \\"exciting\\".  - SM focuses way too much on the action/Volturi in this book. Suddenly the entire issue w/ the Volturi is fleshed out into 100+ pages of preparation/worry for an attack...yet, when it comes right down to it nothing really happens. No throwdown, it's all pretense. It's a climax with no resolve!   - Instead of focusing on trying to create \\"exciting\\" action sequences and supernatural gory occurrences, she should have focused on the dynamic of Bella & Edward's relationship...the ways in which it could now be taken to NEW HEIGHTS since they are no longer limited by Bella's human drawbacks. Since they are now both vampires.  - SM lost the magic of what made Twilight so unique and a romance that was other worldly.  This book got way too mature, way too fast and took on too much of science fiction twist. It wasn't about the characters anymore.  - There's a huge disconnect from how Bella & Edward were in the past 3 books, to this book. There's no rhyme or reason--Bella should not be comfortable w/ becoming pregnant, she should have been terrified! Edward should have been more compassionate w/ the fact that she is pregnant instead of gunning for the \\"thing\\" to die. Once Nessie was born, Edward never took on a fatherly role...which is really quite shocking. The characterization is just completely out of whack in this book.   - Ending this series should have been geared towards the growth of Bella and Edwards as a couple now that they are both vampires and now that they are new parents. SM completely DID NOT address that and glazed over it, by making Bella completely skip over the whole newborn vampire phase. And instead it became about their impending deaths via the Volturi.  - And lastly, for some reason, I am very disappointed that the book did not end with a last scene of Bella and Edward together in the meadow...where it all started.    There was indeed a happy ending, everything worked out. But there were too many f**ked up things that happened along the way, overcasting a shadow on  the happy ending. It was not magical, there was no sense of awe. Instead, it leaves a bitter taste to the end of this series. What a way to go out...
031606792X|5.0|Stephenie Meyer in her own words said that she knew she couldn't make everyone happy, but that SHE was happy with this book. She has said all along that she writes for herself and is pleasantly surprised when other people enjoy it as well. I think that should kept in mind while reading this book.    (I am going to try not to spoil anything for anyone, so I apologize if some of this sounds vague!)    As others have mentioned, this book does change some from the previous books. Yes, there is not as much internal dialog from Bella, but really, after seeing things thru her eyes for 3 other books, do we really need to hear the same thoughts again and again? We would then be reading a book that would be over 1000 pages, not nearly 750. I think that it was smart on SM's part to realize that her readers understand who Bella is and not replay every thought she has. (In all fairness, I felt that some areas could have been a little more specific, but I don't want to spoil this book for anyone by mentioning specifics.)    I also enjoyed that we get to see things through Jacob's eyes for a while. Don't get me wrong, at first I was really freaked out when she switched to that view, but as mentioned before, was it really necessary to hear Bella talk about all the reasons why she was doing what she was doing? By the end of his perspective, I realized the necessity for that point-of-view, which is also why New Moon went the way it did (the first time I read New Moon, I didn't understand why Edward left and Jacob saved the day, but by the second time through, I realized why that book, and what had transpired, was necessary).     Please keep also keep in mind that this a fanatsy (almost sci-fi) book. SM has mentioned over and over that she doesn't have \\"messages\\" in her books. For those that are really trying to put some there, then you are doing the book a great disservice. For those that feel this book may be a little mature for the YA group, well, it is. SM herself said that she thought about putting an age warning on the book, but her publishers didn't do it.  What can really be expected when the main character is making adult decisions? She has already made it perfectly clear in the other books that Bella is a more mature 18 yr old than most. How else could she be ready to become a vampire (as she decided to do at the end of Eclipse)?    All in all, this book made me laugh, made me cry and everything in between. There were plenty of twists and turns, which is a pretty typical SM theme. Some people have said the ending is anticlimactic, but when ending an entire series, there is a need to wrap things up, but this story's ending was not overly done. And, yes, I will go there-this is a much better final book than Harry Potter's final! I still have questions, but if every small question is answered, where is one's imagination?    While reading, try not to rush it and skip ahead. If you take your time, you will realize why things are written as they were. Just enjoy getting into a fantasy world and take a break from your every day life!
